story:
Who is this Nikki girl anyways?

My name is Nikki McGaughey and as anyone who knows me knows, I love animals.  My facebook is a testament to that, as my friends are bombarded with daily doses of dogs, rats, and whatever exotics are on my plate at that point in time.
I have been a dog trainer for two years now, and absolutely adore my job.  However, as it is very difficult to make a living wage as a dog trainer, I have been soul searching for years.  I have had internships various places, most notably at Tamarack Wildlife Rehabilitation and Education Center, where I spent a summer caring for rehabilitated raptors, raising mourning doves and baby opossums.  This past summer I completed an internship at the Erie Zoo where I worked with hoofstock, small mammals, and primates.  Working with the white cheeked gibbons, siamangs, and orangutans was wonderful.  Seeing their individual personalities, struggling through the orangutan spit until they finally accepted me (mostly) and having the female, Dasa, come up to the glass just to spend time with me changed my life.  I realized that helping conserve primates through research is my calling.
I have already been interviewed and accepted into this well established, competitive internship program based in Panama.  Now it is up to help from people like you to help me.  By funding this trip, you will help me reach my dreams.  Working at Alouatta as an intern will be the next step in my life. I can help with mantled howler monkeys, and take that experience and use it to further my education in graduate school.

Where Will My Money Be Going?

The internship for two weeks to one month is $850 plus tax.  This ends up as being $918 for the experience gained and time taken by staff to train. This money is due by October 31st.   Happy Halloween!
Airfare is not included, and from what I gather, it is around $580 for a round trip flight from Erie to David, Panama.
After these major expenses, simple things like taxi to and from the airport, supplies, such as bug spray and sunscreen, both of which I will need copious amounts of, and Panama-specific clothing are all essential, and like all good things in life, are not free at all.
As much as I'd love to reach it, I'm not sure $2000 is a realistic goal.  If I do not reach my goal, all of the money will go towards the internship still.  As I graduate in December and the internship starts January first, it is likely that I will be as broke as broke can be at that point in time, unless this whole McDonald's monopoly thing works out in my favor.

    The Impact

    This internship will of course help me.  The experience will help my resume, give me that extra edge that I need to in order to get into graduate schools.  I am applying to five different schools for physical anthropology, and hope to hear back from them as soon as possible.
    This internship will also help mantled howler monkeys.  At Alouatta, they care for orphaned and injured monkeys, and other animals that need their help.  They also do research on howler monkey cognition, populations, and diet.
    The real question though, let's be honest.  How does this internship help you, the funder? To answer that we will need a time travel device, and since I am a big Dr. Who fan, let's jump in the Tardis for a Jiff. We are whirring to the future, approximately 2020 in the United States.  A young woman, we'll call her Darla, sits in a lecture hall dreaming of making the world a better place and helping animals.  Her professor, Dr. McGaughey approaches. "Why are you so dismal miss Darla?"  "Well Dr. McGaughey I am not sure what to do with my life." she replies.  Dr. McGaughey ponders this and says, "Darla when I was your age, I felt the same.  A new college graduate, searching for purpose in this world.  That was when I began looking at internships, and found one for a place called Alouatta.  I was aware that it was very competitive, but applied anyways.  I got the interview and eventually the position, and then I realized cost.  No one seemed excited.  They all just spoke of cost this and cost that. I was disheartened.  Then finally I realized, I could do this.  I would reach out to friends, family, coworkers, anyone who would listen.  I would swallow my pride and ask for help.  And it came.  Help came by the fives.  One five dollar donation here, one there, and boom! I had my goal. I could go to Panama, learn all I could, not feel guilty about the cost and the damper that it would put on my bank account.  I went, and now here I am.  Doing field research on great apes, and my discoveries about their culture not only led to their conservation, but better understanding of human origins.  That Darla, is the finest example of caring I have seen.  Do not give up on your dreams."  Darla went on to create her own indiegogo and continue the cycle of excellence thanks to contributors like you.  Whiiirr Whirrrr Whiiiirrr.  And now you are back into your own time, 2014, still in the United States.


      Risks & Challenges

      There are obvious risks associated with traveling to Panama.  Due to the possibility my mother is reading this, I will not share all of these risks, but some are worth mentioning.

      For example, during my interview I consented to my mother that I would ask about dangers there.  I was promptly told that it was safe, we wear bullet proof pant things that are impenetrable to snake fangs.  I mean, come on guys, that's safe, right?  He also told me about his worst case scenario, I mean he's lived there a few years, he knows the ins and outs, so I braced myself.  He said that the worst that had happened to him was he was crossing a stream and a bee stung him multiple times and he woke up three days later.  I mean worse has happened right? 

      There are health risks, but other than that, you have a sound investment.  I am already accepted and willing to help all the monkeys of the world, if only you will help fund me.

        Nikki that's a nice story, but I'm broke!

        If you cannot help fund me, at least share my story.  I hope I have made you smile once or twice as you read through this, share this smile with a rich friend or two.   Any support is more than welcome.  Thank you so much for even considering helping a middle class girl reach a dream she never thought possible.

story:
UPDATE (5/13/12): We are no longer seeking founding sponsors for recognition on our homepage. Thank you to those who contributed. After weeks of sifting through proposals and discussions with web design companies, we have selected a company to build our new website. We feel they will be able to deliver exactly the product we are looking for and we are excited to work with them.

UPDATE (5/2/12): We are actively seeking sponsors at the $1,000+ level for the construction of our new website. Individuals and businesses that contribute at least that amount will have their company logo and name placed on the home page with a link to their website, FOREVER (only 15 spaces available). If you are interested, you can donate here or contact us at admin@sustainablefriends.org. This is not only a great business opportunity, but also a great way to be a part of the next GREAT environmental website!

UPDATE (4/27/12): We have attached screenshots of two proposals to give everyone an idea of what we've been receiving from web design companies. We have omitted the rest of the proposal and the company identities to protect their intellectual property.

 

Hello everyone,

My name is Bobby Khaksari. A few friends and I have come up with a website concept we feel is game-changing and will LEAD THE WAY to a more sustainably developed world. It is called Sustainable Friends. No fancy youtube video here. Instead, we put our energy into creating a simple website that highlights what we aim to do. You can go to www.sustainablefriends.org to learn more.

In a nutshell, we have decided that in order for us to achieve our goal, the current site and platform will not suffice. It needs to be rebuilt from scratch, with custom programming and graphics. This will give the site a more professional look, complete functionality, and presence.

This is a topic that we are extremely passionate about and we hope everyone else is too. At the very least, we hope you visit the site to learn more about our goals and sign the petition when the final site is launched.

What We Need

We had no idea at first, but creating a custom, professional website with the functionality we have envisioned and the intent to rival sites like Green Peace and Friends of the Earth, costs a pretty penny. We have submitted an 8-page Word document with detailed site requirements to ten different web design companies and have received bid proposals from them. After crunching the numbers, we have come up with a 30-day fundraising goal of $15,000. Donations will be used to:

  1. Build and launch the initial website
  2. Receive support and website adjustments for the first six (6) months (the estimated time it will take us to finalize everything, work out the bugs, and learn how to administer the site ourselves)

All funds will be used for these two purposes. Any funds that are raised and left over after six months will be re-donated to other environmental causes. We are open to suggestions about this! If we don't reach our goal, we will save whatever amount is raised and continue fundraising until the goal is reached. We're not stopping until we get there!

What You Get (The Perks)

Be sure to check out the perks you get in return for donating. We will not be providing any material goods. We don't really believe in that. Instead, we will be recognizing people (and/or any GREEN entity you want to promote) on our home page and/or on a dedicated "founding donors" page for the entire life of the site (forever?). If you don't want to be recognized, please let us know. Our anticipated launch is late August 2012.

The Impact

In order to realize any tangible change, it takes participation and cooperation from many, many individuals. And what better way to reach and engage the highest amount of people than on the world wide web! Just like votes in an election, your participation and efforts that stem from using the SF website will add up to measurable results. Together, we will reduce climate changing greenhouse gas emissions, bring people out of poverty responsibly, and preserve habitats, biodiversity, and natural systems that provide humans with countless life-sustaining services. As the famous Native American saying goes:

"Humankind has not woven the web of life. We are but one thread within it. Whatever we do to the web, we do to ourselves. All things are bound together. All things connect."

We all have a stake in this, and it isn't the environment that needs to be saved, it's us.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, please spread the word about Sustainable Friends! Share our pages on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, and any other social media platforms you can think of. Tell your family, friends, and co-workers. At the absolute minimum, sign the petition!

If you are a "green" business, non-profit, or website, add yourself to our list of "friends". If you are an expert, create a profile and answer questions from the public.

To put it simply, join the movement!

Contact

If you have any questions, concerns, or comments, feel free to email us at admin@sustainablefriends.org.

story:
Short Summary

I am an old man, owner of a authentic, natural park on the croatian hills, but it is in a poor condition. I want to make it a place where people can stay and discover the true croatia, far from the touritic industry.

By helping me, you will be part of a smal but important to me eco-friendly project, plus you can receive seeds of my production to plant Pyrethrine, wich is a natural insceticide ! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need to buy a big tent to be the center of the park, where people can chat and meet, a new brush cutter, a moving machine, and some seeds for the garden that will be part of the park, opened for the campers.

The Impact

  • Build a place where eco-tourists will be welcome as they merit !
  • Share my plants knowledge

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Come to see me, and help me with my project, I love to host people !
    • Sharing is caring ! Please tell all the people that can be interested in about this project !

story:
English/Italiano


Who We Are 

The Sea Musketeers www.seamusketeer.com

Jasmine Spavieri    Science Journalist and Biologist

See more of my projects here: http://jasminespavieri.azurewebsites.net/

Chiara Marina Grioni  Filmmaker and Photographer

 See some more of my work here: http://www.chiaraobscura.com/

The Sea Musketeers are an educational outreach society that endeavour to protect the oceans through creativity and spirit of adventure.

With this project, we aim to bring the forefront of marine research to the classroom.

THE PROBLEM

We use billions of plastic bags and bottles every year, some of them only a single time, before we throw them away. Most of this plastic waste is not recycled, and a vast amount accidentally ends up in our rivers, lakes and oceans. Sunlight and waves can fragment the plastic, but this only turns it into smaller pieces that end up in the marine food chain.

In oceans and lakes, bits of plastic act like sponges and soak up toxins from the ecosystem. Hundreds of species in the ocean ingest plastic unwittingly. Today, we know that these toxins, have ended up in our food chain.

But there is still a lot to discover... 

Are plankton, animals at the bottom of the marine food chain, eating tiny bits of plastic? 

Is this plastic entering our food chain as well?

OUR MISSION - Sail into the Atlantic

In October, we will sail into the Atlantic Ocean on a discovery expedition aboard a 72ft oceanographic vessel, the Sea Dragon. The vessel will enter the North Atlantic Gyre, departing from the Azores Islands and landing in Lanzarote, the Canary Islands.

The aim is to investigate tiny plastic fragments, known as microplastics. On-board biologists from Exeter University will be looking for evidence that plankton are ingesting microplastics in the open ocean.

The Sea Musketeers will collect video footage, photographs and information to create a free, online educational resource. Our objective is to bring ocean exploration to schools as well as the public eye. We want to educate but mostly ro INSPIRE SOLUTIONS.

Teachers will be able to use these resources to enhance their curriculum and engage their students about this important topic.

WHY IT MATTERS

Knowledge is power!

The sea is a giant playground of opportunity, but only if its harnessed with knowledge and understanding. The Sea Musketeers want to give future generations the ability to make greener, smarter, more informed and forward thinking choices. This educational pack is a step towards the type of information that is invaluable in a future that will be driven by renewable technology and sustainable living.

The project has an international scope and if fully funded, our digital resources will be simultaneously developed in English, French and Italian. 

    What in the world is a Gyre?

    Ocean gyres are rotating current systems in the oceans. Floating pieces of plastic at sea are swept into these massive circular currents. The plastic can be trapped there for decades…Plastic pollution can travel around the planet in five main ocean Gyres, where it collects in large patches and even forms giant floating plastic islands, like the notorious Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

    HOW YOU CAN HELP

    We would like you to help us fund our voyage aboard the Sea Dragon in order for us to create a compelling, current and truthful account of our oceans today.

    In return for your donations we will make you part of our expedition - keeping you up to date along the way about our scientific goals and our voyage itinerary aboard the majestic Sea Dragon. We will also send you exclusive photographs of our fantastic voyage and Sea Musketeer swag to help you reduce plastic pollution.

    Donations from £10 upwards will help us reach our £18,000 goal.

    £8000 will fully fund our voyage aboard the Sea Dragon expedition

     £10 000 will cover costs for filming, photography and sailing equipment

    £14 000 will allow us to collect interviews, information and develop content

    £18 000 will cover shooting and editing of video and photography as well as post-production

    Any extra funding will help us reach out to schools and communities and give our project the maximum educational impact!

    If we don't reach our entire goal, we will try our best to collect any information possible and share it through our webpage. 

    THE VOYAGE

    In October 2014, we will jump aboard Pangaea Explorations’ yacht, the Sea Dragon, and sail into the North Atlantic Gyre in a voyage of scientific discovery.

    Pangaea Explorations are an exceptional group of scientists, sailors and educators that sail the seven seas. 

    THE CREW

    The Sea Dragon crew will be a mixture of filmmakers, scientists and designers:

    ·  Experts from the University of Exeter

    ·  The award winning Sea Chairs designers from Studio Swine will aim to collect enough plastic during the voyage to create a sea kayak.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Get the word out!

    Help in any way you can. Share this campaign with all your friends and family - anyone who cares about the planet and a plastic-free ocean.


    Chi Siamo

    The Sea Musketeers www.seamusketeer.com

    Le Sea Musketeers si occupano di divulgazione scientifica. Seguiamo le orme di famosi esploratori come Jacques Cousteau per proteggere i mari ispirando avventura e creatività.

    Attraverso questo progetto, vogliamo portare la ricerca e l’esplorazione marina direttamente nelle scuole e al pubblico in generale.

    Jasmine Spavieri             giornalista scientifica e biologa

    Chiara Marina Grioni      regista e fotografa

    Jasmine, giornalista scientifica; ha oltre cinque anni di esperienza nella stesura di materiale didattico e nell'allestimento di mostre ed esposizioni per alcuni dei migliori Istituti di formazione scientifica. Ha una Laurea in Chimica e un Master in Scienze Biologiche. Per conoscere i suoi progetti, visitate il sito: http://jasminespavieri.azurewebsites.net/

    Chiara è fotografa e regista; ha conseguito un Master of Arts in Giornalismo Fotografico e Fotografia per Documentari; ha anche una gran passione per l'oceano ed è una PADI Dive Master certificata.

    Per conoscere i suoi progetti, visitate il sito: http://www.chiaraobscura.com/

    IL PROBLEMA

    Usiamo milioni di sacchetti e bottiglie di plastica ogni anno, spesso una volta sola, prima di buttarli via. La maggior parte di questi rifiuti di plastica non è riciclabile, e una gran parte finisce incidentalmente nei nostri fiumi, laghi e mari. La luce del sole e le onde possono frammentare la plastica, riducendola a piccoli pezzettini, i quali terminano nella catena alimentare marina.

    Qui agiscono da spugne ed assorbono tossine, come per esempio i pesticidi, anch’essi nell’ecosistema. Centinaia di specie ingeriscono questi frammenti di plastica.

    Oceanografi ed esploratori si imbarcano per mari e oceani, ma difficilmente le loro ricerche sono accessibili a tutti. Il nostro compito é quello di avvicinare il pubblico a queste importanti scoperte.

    • Quali sono gli effetti della plastica sulla vita marina?
    • In che quantità le tossine finiscono nella nostra catena alimentare?
    • Chi si sta occupando di queste ricerche?
    • In che modo possiamo utilizzare queste indagini per creare un futuro sostenibile?

    Le Sea Musketeers vanno in avanscoperta…

    IL NOSTRO PROGETTO

    In ottobre saliremo a bordo della Sea Dragon, una barca di 22m. Salperemo con la spedizione "Gyre to Gaia" dove navigheremo sulle acque del vortice dell'Atlantico del Nord, dalle isole Azzorre a Lanzarote, nelle Canarie.

    La ricerca a bordo esaminerà gli effetti della plastica sulla vita marina. Biologi marini, esperti in microplastica della Exeter University, indagheranno se lo zooplancton – gli ultimi animali della catena alimentare marina – stiano ingerendo della plastica.

    Lungo il tragitto raccoglieremo fotografie, video ed interviste per documentare il problema dell'inquinamento da materie plastiche nei nostri mari. Raccoglieremo materiale esclusivo scientifico con storie di esploratori, artisti, scienziati e giovani tecnici e ingegneri, che contribuiscono a salvare gli oceani in modo decisivo e con soluzioni innovative. Vogliamo creare risorse online e renderle accessibili agli insegnanti, per rendere più agevole il loro compito di coinvolgere gli studenti.

    Il nostro scopo è di EDUCARE ma soprattutto di APPASSIONARE per trovare soluzioni. 

    Affronteremo i seguenti argomenti:

    •  Esplorazione e biodiversità

    •  Innovazione e tecnologia

    •  Vortici e riciclaggio

    •  Pesca e sostenibilità

    Se completamente sovvenzionato, il progetto sarà di portata internazionale, svilupperemo risorse digitali contemporaneamente in italiano, francese e inglese.

    Vogliamo dare alle generazioni future l'opportunità di comprendere che cos'è la sostenibilità e di compiere scelte più ecologiche e più informate. Il kit formativo che vogliamo creare potrà dare loro una serie di conoscenze che si riveleranno preziose, in un futuro che sarà determinato dalla tecnologia rinnovabile e da uno stile di vita sostenibile.

    I 5 Vortici Oceanici sono dei sistemi di correnti a spirale che si formano negli oceani. I rifiuti costituiti da materie plastiche sono trascinati intorno al pianeta e trasportati da questi cinque vortici sub-tropicali. Continuano ad accumularsi, fino a formare vere e proprie isole di spazzatura galleggianti, dove la plastica può restare intrappolata per decenni.

    Il Vortice più grande si trova nell’oceano Pacifico (Great Pacific Garbage Patch).

    IL VOSTRO AIUTO

    Chiediamo il vostro aiuto per finanziare il nostro viaggio sull’imbarcazione di ricerca oceanografica Sea Dragon.

    Attraverso filmati esclusivi dei vortici dell’Atlantico del nord daremo vita a un racconto di grande impatto sullo stato attuale dei nostri oceani.

    In cambio delle vostre donazioni, vi terremo al corrente dei progetti e dell’itinerario, vi manderemo fotografie esclusive da bordo della fantastica Sea Dragon, e degli oggetti creati appositamente dalle Sea Musketeers per aiutarvi a ridurre l’inquinamento causato dalla plastica.

    A partire da £10 potrete aiutarci a raggiungere il nostro obiettivo finale di £18,000.

    Un totale di £ 8000 finanzieranno la nostra spedizione sulla Sea Dragon.

    Un totale di £10.000 copriranno le spese per i filmati, le foto e l’equipaggiamento

    Un totale di £ 14.000 ci permetterà di intervistare esperti, raccogliere informazioni e sviluppare contenuti

    Un totale di 18.000 copriranno le spese di montaggio ed editing di video e foto, e la post-produzione

    Ogni ulteriore contributo ci aiuterà a raggiungere più scuole ed avere così un impatto maggiore. Se non riusciremo a raggiungere i contributi necessari, faremo del nostro meglio per raccogliere il maggior numero di informazioni e condividerle attraverso il nostro sito.

    Il nostro viaggio a bordo della Sea Dragon fa parte di spedizioni organizzate da Pangaea Explorations, formata da un gruppo eccezionale di scienziati, marinai e ricercatori.
story_txt:
English/Italiano


Who We Are 

The Sea Musketeers www.seamusketeer.com

Jasmine Spavieri    Science Journalist and Biologist

See more of my projects here: http://jasminespavieri.azurewebsites.net/

Chiara Marina Grioni  Filmmaker and
Photographer
 See some more of my work here: http://www.chiaraobscura.com/
The Sea
Musketeers are an educational outreach society that endeavour to protect the
oceans through creativity and spirit of adventure.
With this project, we aim to bring the forefront of marine research to the classroom.
THE PROBLEM
We use billions of plastic
bags and bottles every year, some of them only a single time, before we throw
them away. Most of this plastic waste is not recycled, and a vast amount
accidentally ends up in our rivers, lakes and oceans. Sunlight and waves can
fragment the plastic, but this only turns it into smaller pieces that end up in
the marine food chain.
In oceans and lakes, bits of
plastic act like sponges and soak up toxins from the ecosystem. Hundreds of
species in the ocean ingest plastic unwittingly. Today, we know that
these toxins, have ended up in our food
chain.
But there is still a lot to discover... 
Are plankton, animals at the bottom of the marine food chain, eating tiny bits of plastic? 
Is this plastic entering our food chain as well?
OUR MISSION - Sail into the Atlantic
In October, we will sail into the Atlantic
Ocean on a discovery expedition aboard a 72ft oceanographic vessel, the Sea Dragon. The vessel will enter the North
Atlantic Gyre, departing from the Azores Islands and
landing in Lanzarote, the Canary Islands.
The aim is to investigate tiny plastic fragments, known as microplastics. On-board
biologists from Exeter University will be looking for evidence that plankton are ingesting microplastics in the open ocean.
The Sea Musketeers will collect video
footage, photographs and information to create a free, online educational
resource. Our objective is to bring ocean exploration to schools as well as the public eye. We want to educate but mostly ro INSPIRE SOLUTIONS.
Teachers will be able to use these resources to enhance their curriculum and engage their students about this important topic.
WHY IT MATTERS
Knowledge is power!
The sea is a giant playground of opportunity, but only if its harnessed with knowledge and understanding. The Sea Musketeers want to give future generations the ability to make greener, smarter, more informed and forward thinking choices. This educational pack is a step towards the type of information that is invaluable in a future that will be driven by renewable technology and sustainable living.
The project has an
international scope and if fully funded, our digital resources will be
simultaneously developed in English, French and Italian. 

What in the world is a Gyre?
Ocean gyres are rotating
current systems in the oceans. Floating pieces of plastic at sea are swept into
these massive circular currents. The plastic can be trapped there for decades…Plastic
pollution can travel around the planet in five main ocean Gyres,
where it collects in large patches and even forms giant floating plastic
islands, like the notorious Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

HOW YOU CAN HELP
We would like you to help us fund our
voyage aboard the Sea Dragon in order for us to create a
compelling, current and truthful account of our oceans today.
In return for your donations we will make you part of our expedition - keeping you up to date along the way about our scientific goals and our voyage itinerary aboard the majestic Sea Dragon. We will also send you exclusive photographs of our fantastic voyage and Sea Musketeer swag to help you reduce plastic pollution.
Donations from £10 upwards will help us reach our £18,000 goal.
£8000 will fully fund our
voyage aboard the Sea Dragon expedition
 £10 000 will
cover costs for filming, photography and sailing equipment
£14 000 will allow us
to collect interviews, information and develop content
£18 000 will
cover shooting and editing of video and photography as well as post-production
Any extra funding will help us
reach out to schools and communities and give our project the maximum
educational impact!
If we don't reach our entire
goal, we will try our best to collect any information possible and share it
through our webpage. 
THE VOYAGE
In October 2014, we will jump
aboard Pangaea Explorations’ yacht, the Sea Dragon, and sail into
the North Atlantic Gyre in a voyage of scientific discovery.
Pangaea Explorations are an exceptional
group of scientists, sailors and educators that sail the seven seas. 
THE CREW
The Sea Dragon crew
will be a mixture of filmmakers, scientists and designers:
·  Experts from
the University of Exeter 
· 
The award
winning Sea Chairs designers from Studio Swine will aim to collect
enough plastic during the voyage to create a sea kayak.
Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out!
Help
in any way you can. Share this campaign with all your friends and family -
anyone who cares about the planet and a plastic-free ocean.





Chi Siamo
The Sea Musketeers www.seamusketeer.com
Le Sea
Musketeers si occupano di divulgazione scientifica. Seguiamo le orme di famosi
esploratori come Jacques Cousteau per proteggere i mari ispirando avventura e
creatività. 
Attraverso
questo progetto, vogliamo portare la ricerca e l’esplorazione marina direttamente
nelle scuole e al pubblico in generale.


Jasmine
Spavieri             giornalista scientifica e
biologa
Chiara Marina Grioni      regista e fotografa


Jasmine, giornalista scientifica; ha oltre cinque anni di
esperienza nella stesura di materiale didattico e nell'allestimento di mostre
ed esposizioni per alcuni dei migliori Istituti di formazione scientifica. Ha una
Laurea in Chimica e un Master in Scienze Biologiche. Per conoscere i suoi
progetti, visitate il sito: http://jasminespavieri.azurewebsites.net/

Chiara è fotografa e regista; ha
conseguito un Master of Arts in Giornalismo Fotografico e Fotografia per
Documentari; ha anche una gran passione per l'oceano ed è una PADI Dive Master
certificata.
Per conoscere i suoi progetti, visitate il sito: http://www.chiaraobscura.com/
IL PROBLEMA

Usiamo milioni di
sacchetti e bottiglie di plastica ogni anno, spesso una volta sola, prima di
buttarli via. La maggior parte di questi rifiuti di plastica non è riciclabile,
e una gran parte finisce incidentalmente nei nostri fiumi, laghi e mari. La
luce del sole e le onde possono frammentare la plastica, riducendola a piccoli pezzettini,
i quali terminano nella catena alimentare marina. 

Qui agiscono da spugne ed assorbono tossine, come per
esempio i pesticidi, anch’essi nell’ecosistema. Centinaia di specie ingeriscono questi frammenti di plastica. 
Oceanografi
ed esploratori si imbarcano per mari e oceani, ma difficilmente le loro
ricerche sono accessibili a tutti. Il nostro compito é quello di avvicinare il
pubblico a queste importanti scoperte. 

Quali sono
     gli effetti della plastica sulla vita marina?
In che quantità
     le tossine finiscono nella nostra catena alimentare?
Chi si sta
     occupando di queste ricerche?
In che modo
     possiamo utilizzare queste indagini per creare un futuro sostenibile?

Le Sea Musketeers vanno in avanscoperta…

sulla vita marina. Biologi marini, esperti in microplastica della Exeter

Lungo il tragitto raccoglieremo fotografie, video ed
interviste per documentare il problema dell'inquinamento da materie plastiche
nei nostri mari. Raccoglieremo materiale esclusivo scientifico con storie di esploratori, artisti, scienziati e
giovani tecnici e ingegneri, che contribuiscono a salvare gli oceani in
modo decisivo e con soluzioni innovative. Vogliamo creare risorse online e renderle
accessibili agli insegnanti, per rendere più agevole il loro compito di
coinvolgere gli studenti. 
Il nostro scopo è di EDUCARE ma soprattutto di
APPASSIONARE per trovare soluzioni. 
Affronteremo i seguenti argomenti:
• 
Esplorazione e
biodiversità
• 
Innovazione e
tecnologia
• 
Vortici e riciclaggio

• 
Pesca e
sostenibilità
Se completamente sovvenzionato, il progetto sarà di
portata internazionale, svilupperemo risorse digitali contemporaneamente in italiano, francese e inglese.
Vogliamo dare alle generazioni future l'opportunità di
comprendere che cos'è la sostenibilità e di compiere scelte più ecologiche e più
informate. Il kit formativo che vogliamo creare potrà dare loro una serie di
conoscenze che si riveleranno preziose, in un futuro che sarà determinato
dalla tecnologia rinnovabile e da uno stile di vita sostenibile. 


I 5 Vortici Oceanici sono dei sistemi di correnti a
spirale che si formano negli oceani. I rifiuti costituiti da materie plastiche
sono trascinati intorno al pianeta e trasportati da questi cinque vortici

di spazzatura galleggianti, dove la plastica può restare intrappolata per
decenni. 
Il Vortice più grande si trova nell’oceano Pacifico
(Great Pacific Garbage Patch).
IL
VOSTRO AIUTO

Attraverso filmati

grande impatto sullo stato attuale dei nostri oceani.

In cambio delle vostre donazioni, vi terremo al corrente
dei progetti e dell’itinerario, vi manderemo fotografie esclusive da bordo
della fantastica Sea Dragon, e degli
oggetti creati appositamente dalle Sea
Musketeers per aiutarvi a ridurre l’inquinamento causato dalla plastica. 

A partire da £10

Un totale di £ 8000 finanzieranno la nostra spedizione
sulla Sea Dragon. 
Un totale di £10.000 copriranno le spese per i filmati,
le foto e l’equipaggiamento 
Un totale di £ 14.000 ci permetterà di intervistare
esperti, raccogliere informazioni e sviluppare contenuti

editing di video e foto, e la post-produzione

story:
Our Trip to Japan

Hi! We are Nora and Heather. If you're reading this, then you probably already know us! We've been planning on taking a trip to Japan for a long time now. We have basically all the details figured out, like the hotel, the flight, and sightseeing! Now we just need your help. :)

What We Need and What You Get

We'd like to go from late March to early April 2015. The trip is much more expensive than we planned. Adding up the flight and hotel, our goal is to raise $3,000, which would cover most of those. That's where you come in - even just a few bucks puts us a little closer! 

We have tons of perks lined up for people willing to help us out! 

Even if we don't reach our entire goal, every cent you donate will go to the trip. (IGG takes a small fee - 4% if we reach our goal, and 9% if we don't.)

There will be other perks that will be listed on a separate page - look out for this! We'll be posting the links to the campaign and additional perks regularly! 


Ways You Can Help

Even just a dollar helps us out, but if you can't contribute, you can still share this as much as you can and tell your friends! 

And that's all there is to it. We're really excited to get this going, so please share it and donate if you can!


Thanks so much! <3

story:
The Guna have been doing conservation the right way for hundreds of years

Reclining in his hammock and fiddling with his handmade flute, Santiago Campillo, the leader of Armila's folk music group Gammibe Gun Galu, explains: “The songs we play are the songs God taught to each animal so that they could greet him with music when he visited mother earth.”  This rhythmic, soothing music he references, reminiscent of singing birds and lumbering tapirs (a cuddly-looking relative of the rhino), embodies the spirit of the Guna culture.  It is only appropriate that their music be the music of other animals: Guna tradition upholds the value of other species and lays the foundation for a harmonious relationship between man and nature.

Luckily for the rest of the world, the indigenous Guna are the stewards of one of the world's disappearing treasures: leatherback sea turtles.  Thousands of these enormous creatures nest in the 4km of beach of Guna village of Armila, Panama, making it one of the world’s most important nesting sites for this critically endangered species.  As over-exploitation causes the leatherback to disappear from the Pacific ocean, this incredible extraordinary concentration is made possible by the Guna's culture, which prohibits the consumption of sea turtles or their eggs.  Instead, Armila’s residents allow their ancient kin (as tradition still calls them) to nest in peace.

But times are changing.

Both turtles and the music face an uncertain future.  Population growth and diminishing availability of fish have brought the human-turtle relationship to a critical head.  Western influences are wearing away at the Guna culture, and long-held taboos that prohibit the exploitation of turtles are going with it.  New financial pressures on families means that certain elements of their culture, such as the town's unique musical tradition, are being left behind.  If their needs are not addressed, both the music and the turtles may succumb to the same fate of their counterparts elsewhere: gradually (or rapidly) fading away.

This campaign emerged from the combined effort of Armila’s Sea Turtle Commission and the local music group, Gammibe Gun Galu, along with the support of the local, state, and federal government, to simultaneously safeguard their culture and their precious population of sea turtles.     

 

            What We're Doing

Your donation will be directly used to form the base of a sustainable, multifaceted conservation project in the town of Armila.  These amounts represent the amount necessary to launch this project; any additional funds raised will continue to flow directly into the community.

 

 1) $1000 to jumpstart a sea turtle monitoring program in Armila.

Science forms the necessary base for any successful conservation program.  Local young people and commission members are poised to do the work.  They just need the equipment so they can produce data so that the national government and the global community will recognize the importance of their beach.  Your donation will pay for tagging equpment, scales, measuring tapes, ponchos, notebooks, and turtle-safe headlamps for researchers and students.

 2) $2,000 (matched 2:1 by The Aquatic Resources Authority of Panama) to start a community-run aquaculture project in Armila.

Fish, Armila's primary source of protein, are becoming scarce due to climate change and population growth.  Residents have already begun to eat species that they have never resorted to before.  To keep the pressure off the turtles and ensure a stable source of protein through the coming years, the community wants to follow the lead of other Panamanian communities by cultivating tilapia.  The government has agreed to provide consultants, training, feed, and baby fish; however, Armila has to raise the money needed for a cement tank so that the tilapia don’t pollute their river.

3) $1,500 to produce Gammibe Gun Galu's first recording.

Through sale of their first professional recording, Gammibe Gun Galu, the nation's most respected Guna music group, will be able to raise sufficient funds to meet their regular needs AND the needs of Armila's conservation efforts.  They need this initial capital to turn their high-quality recording into a high-quality product that taps into markets that digital downloads can’t reach.

   -$900 to print and ship the first 250 copies of "Gammibe Gun Galu," which will be sold in stores and at shows, with 100% of profits benefiting the group.

   -$500 for preloaded USBs to be distributed throughout the nation.  Handheld speakers are the “it” music playing device in the indigenous nation of Guna Yala.  With USB’s, people will be able to listen to a recording of their own music rather than just blasting Jennifer Lopez (no offense J-Lo), which will positively impact the preservation of their music throught the nation.

   -$100 digital registration of CD for sale online

These projects will be managed by the Sea Turtle Commission of Armila, the family-run musical group Gammibe Gun Galu, and the environmental agency ARAP.  Donations will be managed by 501(c)(3) Ocean Revolution, with 100% of funds raised going directly to the community.  If you would like to make a tax deductible donation to this project, please contact morrison.mast@gmail.com.

 

            What you get

For a $5 donation, your name will be displayed on a plaque that will be permanently displayed in the congress building in Armila.

For a $10 donation, you (or your loved one) will receive the above, plus a personalized card from the musical group Gammibe Gun Galu, stamped with the official seal of the Guna General Congress and the Town of Armila.  This card signifies the town of Armila's utmost gratitude for helping to preserve an ancient way of life, and an even more ancient wildlife phenomenon.

For a $20 donation you will receive all of the above, plus a digital download of Gammibe Gun Galu's full-length CD, featuring a wide range of traditional folkloric repertoire.*

For a $25 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus a hard copy of Gammibe Gun Galu's first professionally recorded album.  Listen to the tracks at gammibegungalu.bandcamp.com.*

For a $100 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus an original 8.5x11" print of your choice from www.morrisonmast.com.  You can view an album of photos from Armila at morrisonmast.com/armila.*

For a $250 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus one of three framed molas (see media tab for photos) handmade by Armila resident Gladys Crespo.*

For a $500 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus a set of handmade potholders and an oven mitt from Armila (see photo above and in gallery).*

If you're feeling particularly generous, for a $2000 donation you will receive all of the above plus a week-long stay, meals inculded, at Cabañas Ibedi al Natural, Armila's ecotourism destination.  International and domestic transportation not included.  Please contact us directly if you would like to claim this perk.*

 

*Additional charges may apply for international shipping.

If you have any questions about how your donations will be used or managed, please contact us at morrison.mast@gmail.com or achaigibson@gmail.com.

   -$500 for preloaded USBs to be distributed throughout the nation.  Handheld speakers are the “it” music playing device in the indigenous nation of Guna Yala.  With USB’s, people will be able to listen to a recording of their own music rather than just blasting Jennifer Lopez (no offense J-Lo), which will positively impact the preservation of their music throught the nation.
   -$100 digital registration of CD for sale online
These projects will be managed by the Sea Turtle Commission of Armila, the family-run musical group Gammibe Gun Galu, and the environmental agency ARAP.  Donations will be managed by 501(c)(3) Ocean Revolution, with 100% of funds raised going directly to the community.  If you would like to make a tax deductible donation to this project, please contact morrison.mast@gmail.com.
 

            What you get
For a $5 donation, your name will be displayed on a plaque that will be permanently displayed in the congress building in Armila.
For a $10 donation, you (or your loved one) will receive the above, plus a personalized card from the musical group Gammibe Gun Galu, stamped with the official seal of the Guna General Congress and the Town of Armila.  This card signifies the town of Armila's utmost gratitude for helping to preserve an ancient way of life, and an even more ancient wildlife phenomenon.
For a $20 donation you will receive all of the above, plus a digital download of Gammibe Gun Galu's full-length CD, featuring a wide range of traditional folkloric repertoire.*
For a $25 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus a hard copy of Gammibe Gun Galu's first professionally recorded album.  Listen to the tracks at gammibegungalu.bandcamp.com.*
For a $100 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus an original 8.5x11" print of your choice from www.morrisonmast.com.  You can view an album of photos from Armila at morrisonmast.com/armila.*
For a $250 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus one of three framed molas (see media tab for photos) handmade by Armila resident Gladys Crespo.*
For a $500 donation, you will receive all of the above, plus a set of handmade potholders and an oven mitt from Armila (see photo above and in gallery).*
If you're feeling particularly generous, for a $2000 donation you will receive all of the above plus a week-long stay, meals inculded, at Cabañas Ibedi al Natural, Armila's ecotourism destination.  International and domestic transportation not included.  Please contact us directly if you would like to claim this perk.*
 
*Additional charges may apply for international shipping.
If you have any questions about how your donations will be used or managed, please contact us at morrison.mast@gmail.com or achaigibson@gmail.com.

story:
FROM VIDEO: On Oct. 26- 29 of this year, over a thousand youth from across the country will converge on Ottawa for Powershift to discuss, strategize, and act on the most pressing environmental issues of our time.

This year, you can help bring frontline environmental defenders from two First Nations to join in on the action.

[Melissa Elliot, Six Nations of Grand River]

Six Nations youth are currently organizing against Enbridge's plans to pipe tar sands bitumen from Sarnia to Montreal, and eventually Maine. This nearly 40 year old pipeline is almost identical to Enbridge's 6B pipeline, which ruptured and sent millions of litters of diluted bitumen into the Kalamazoo river in July 2010. This spill devastated the area, and chemicals specific to the transport of dilbit poisoned nearby residents with a gas that induced vomiting, rashes, and a burning of the eyes and throat. Over two years after the spill, residents are still sick and complain that the clean-up is far from complete.

Beyond the threat posed by the pipeline to the surrounding area, pipeline infrastructure allows for the mass transport of tar sands, and thus the expansion of the most destructive project on the planet.  The tar sands account for more than 16% of emissions in Canada, but this is expected to increase three or four times in the next decade if the tar sands are allowed to expand. 

In Aamjiwnaang First Nation, a lawsuit put forth by EcoJustice and community members targets the Ontario government's approval of a Suncor tar sands smoke stack which has been knowingly operating at above acceptable human health limits. Aamijiwnaang has 63 chemical refineries within 50 km of the community and Community-monitoring has reported that 40 per cent of the population requires inhalers to breath and 39 per cent of women have experienced miscarriages. It is one of the most blatant cases of environmental racism in North America. 

The Green Teens are a Youth group in Aamjiwnaang that organizers around Environmental issues. Members of the Green Teens worked on the 60 minute film "Indian Givers" which invites the audience on a journey with the characters by stepping into their lives as they reveal the survival of their spiritual identities in today's world. Indian Givers is one of the many gifts we are offering in exchange for your contribution to them to Powershift. 

[Vanessa Gray, Aamjiwnaang/Sarnia Green Teens]

all music: Illogik

story:
Why Our Country Needs A Delivery Driver App So Drivers Can Make Home Deliveries Of Healthy Local Food From Small Farms To Every Home In America!

Society has evolved in a symbiotic relationship with small farms.  Small farmers would raise high quality food with close oversight and attention, and people in the cities would buy the food, in turn providing a living for the small farmer.  The food chain was short.

With the industrialization of food, the food chain became long with dependencies in the middle.  Small farmers were forgotten.  Food quality went down and disease went up.  The small farms never went away, they just haven’t had an outlet for their food.

In the recent global pandemic food shortages were felt everywhere.  Store shelves were empty when we desperately needed them to be full.  Where will we get our food during the next crisis when big food factories shut down again?

Diet related diseases continue to rise every year and our food supply is not providing us with food that is healthy enough to sustain a disease free life.The current long-chain food model is fragile during crisis and disease causing.  It’s not serving society very well.  It has too many dependencies in the middle of the chain, which only makes food cost more than it needs to.  Together we can remove 90% of those high priced, unnecessary dependencies. 

The solution is a delivery driver app for small farm food so that the average household can get the convenience of home delivery of fresh local food at a reasonable price.  With crowdfunding we will build a delivery driver app into the already existing online FarmMatch.com small farm marketplace.  This will cost about $150,000 in software development.

With a small farm food delivery driver app, we create a battalion of drivers that delivers fresh healthy local food from small farms to homes in cities.  In doing so, we tap into our nation’s vast food supply that sits dormant in the countryside.  All that food is made available to people in cities, and creates a more secure food system for society.  It also gives us as individual's access to better quality food so that we can live healthier lives and make more memorable experiences with our loved ones.

There are delivery driver apps for the restaurant industry and for the grocery store industry, but what about small farms?  Together we can democratize and create a food system that serves the people and not big food corporations.  

Your support makes a huge impact!  Please donate and help get the word out too!  Isn’t $50 or $100 worth having a delivery driver app for small farm food? Imagine how the world will change!

Our Story

At the age of 10 years old I (Max Kane) was diagnosed with degenerative crohn’s disease at the University of Chicago.  I ate a diet of industrial food and experienced horrific abdominal pain.  A nutritional mentor coached me on changing my diet away from industrial food, and I started buying food from local farms in my area.  My health blossomed!  I put on over 50 pounds of healthy athletic weight, and my health got to the point where I didn’t need medications anymore.

I eventually saw the need for technology for small farms and FarmMatch.com was born with the mission to serve society by creating a healthier, more secure food system that will serve generations to come.

 

What We Have Accomplished

FarmMatch.com was founded in 2012 and since then the web app has been working in beta to build features around the needs of a small local food chain society.  The app has successfully facilitated over 600,000 orders of local food to thousands of homes in America while pushing over $30 million dollars in sales to small farms.

 

 

 

 

Perk Options

Bumper sticker options:


           Big Pharma                          Big Box                       Zombie Chow                  Find your Farmer

T-Shirt options:


Find Your Farmer         Zombie Chow               Big Box              Not a Dating Site      Food is Health

story:
The project

Breaking The Brand of Rhino Horn in Viet Nam

This campaign follows the success of our pilot RhiNo campaign 'Is it worth the risk?', where after raising $30,000 we were able to place 19 adverts in three key business and the top selling women’s magazines; including 2 consecutive months in Heritage, the in-flight magazine of Viet Nam Airlines. 



To keep the pressure on the primary users of rhino horn in Viet Nam Breaking The Brand wants to launch a 5-week follow up campaign 'Will your luck run out....'. Rhino horn gifts and use in a 'millionaire detox drink' spike leading up to and over the Vietnamese New Year (Tet) celebration. Lunar New Year falls on February 19 next year, so we want to have the adverts up and running from early January 2015. 

On Breaking the Brand's recent visit to Viet Nam we have been able to verify that our campaign strategy works and that we have selected the right magazines to publish the adverts in. We now have an established relationship with a media buying agency in Ho Chi Minh City who are helping us to optimise ad placement. In addition to the magazines used, light box and poster ads will also be placed in the exclusive California Fitness and Yoga Clubs in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City. 

The new ads will be produced pro-bono by Three Wise Men, the former partners of Grey Group Melbourne. In Viet Nam New Year celebrations center around the notion of luck - making sure that you get rid of 'bad luck' from last year and setting yourself up for (better) luck next year. Given the spirituality and superstition centered around New Year our ad design will pick up on these themes and focus the users' minds on 'will your luck run out' if you continue to use rhino horn

Rhino poaching continues to rise in Africa and, with 969 rhinos are slaughtered, we are going to see more than the 1,004 rhinos poached in South Africa last year at the end of this year. 



We urgently need to focus funds on demand reduction campaigns in Viet Nam. We are working with local agencies in Viet Nam to fine-tune our messaging and approach, but we are in the unique position of being able to use hard-hitting messages


How The Funds Will Be Used 

100% of funds raised will go into producing and publishing the ads in Vietnamese magazines targeting the primary users of rhino horn. See the image above for the ads we used in our pilot campaign, which we launched in mid-September. 



In addition to the magazines, light box and poster adverts will also be placed in exclusive California Fitness and Yoga Clubs in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, which are frequented by our target audience.

We need a total of $30,000 to run a 5-week campaign in publications and locations that are best suited to reaching the primary rhino horn users. With $10,000 we can produce the new ads (cost is around $1,000 for image processing and translation) and buy placements in one of the magazines for 5 weeks. This is the minimum viable campaign. Any additional funds we raise via Indiegogo will go into placing ads in additional magazines.


The These Adverts Can and Will Make a Difference

We have successfully run a pilot campaign in Viet Nam; Breaking The Brand raised $30,000 to place 19 adverts in three key business and the top selling women’s magazines; including 2 consecutive months in Heritage, the in-flight magazine of Viet Nam Airlines. 
For more information please visit:
www.breakingthebrand.org and
www.facebook.com/niabtb

Feedback has included: 

Vu Thi Quyen, Executive director and Founder of Education for Nature in Viet Nam: “I often use your work as good examples for our staff in the office. I love your messaging style as you keep things simple but very creative at the same time. I believe that your messaging works well for Vietnamese. 

Dr. Stephen Saunders, Department of Marketing, Monash University: “Congratulations on the launch of your advertising campaign. As an academic interested in consumer studies, I have always been a strong supporter of marketing initiatives that directly target the end-user, and surprised that there are not more organisations such as yours that prioritise a consumer-oriented strategy in tackling the rhino horn problem. I think that your current campaign strikes a good balance between awareness, education, stigmatisation, shock and emotional response. Something that has been lacking, in my opinion, in many of the other campaigns that seem to broadly focus on general education and awareness”.

Also in a recent visit to Viet Nam to get some initial feedback and first impressions of our pilot campaign, a conversation with one Vietnamese businessman proved interesting. He said: 

“When I saw the adverts I told a friend whose child has cancer; I know they were using rhino horn. My friend was shocked and wondered why the people of Viet Nam weren't been told about rhino horn poisoning. The family said that they will finish the piece of horn that they have, but they won’t buy any more as they don’t want to risk giving their sick child poisoned rhino horn.” Whilst this is just one story and we didn't hear it directly from the family it does provide a glimmer of hope for the rhino. Like anywhere in the world, in Viet Nam what you hear from your peer network has an impact on what you buy and do. If this family are talking to their peer group about their new concerns regarding using rhino horn, our hope is that over time this massage will spread, including on social media. Similarly, we hope that people, such as this family, may talk more openly to local conservation groups and the media about their decisions to stop buying rhino horn.

Risks & Challenges

We don't foresee any risks or challenges for this project. All the necessary relationships are in place and the concept is proven. We are asking:

1. International Supporters to help raise $10,000 via this Indiegogo Campaign

2. Australian Supporters to raise $8,000 via Australian based crowdfunding campaign

3. Supporting individuals, organisations and companies to pledge larger individual donations to raise $12,000

We have relationships with NGOs in Viet Nam and have established a relationship with the ad buying agency in Viet Nam who have demonstrated an understanding of Breaking The Brands campaign objectives. Their local knowledge of the primary target groups has resulted in selecting the right publications to target key rhino horn users. The has already proven to be successful in our pilot campaign roll out.

story:
INSPIRING LEADERSHIP:  SUPPORT OUR PLANET BY DONATING TODAY!  

Homeward Bound is a groundbreaking leadership, strategic and science initiative and outreach for women, set against the backdrop of Antarctica.

The initiative, turned global movement, aims to heighten the influence and impact of women with a science background in order to influence policy and decision making as it shapes our planet.

Launched in 2016, Homeward Bound gathered the first 76 of a targeted 1,000 women from around the world, all with critical science backgrounds, to undertake a year-long state-of-the-art program to develop their leadership and strategic capabilities, using science to build conviction around the importance of their voices. The inaugural program culminated in the largest-ever female expedition to Antarctica, in December 2016, with a focus on the leadership of women and the state of the world.

The vision of Homeward Bound Projects is to:

Over ten years, we want to build a global collaboration of 1,000 women who have a scientific background.  Support them into leadership roles, encourage them to stay, to help shape policy and decision making, networked to each other, each in their own way fighting for change, all collaborating for a shared vision.

Project Objectives:

  • To elevate each participant’s leadership capabilities.
  • To educate the team on the science of what is happening to our planet.
  • To refine participants’ skills to design and execute strategy, and to create plans for future collaborations as women working towards a sustainable future.
  • To enhance these skills, over a 10-year target, with 1000 women networked and skilled to affect change.
  • To create active, non-hierarchical collaborations among the women both in small groups and as a collective.
  • To have a global focus.
  • To contribute to and elevate the broader societal conversation about the role of women in leading the world toward a more sustainable future.

In order to meet the global focus objective, we want to support women scientists from parts of this planet that can't subsidize this trip themselves. Through your donation, we'll offer a scientist from the developing world a chance to use her voice to shape policy and dialog about issues that affect us all.

story:
About us

Bulk Market® is a social enterprise on a mission to tackle plastic waste, supporting suppliers who are making a difference to people's lives and the environment.

Ingrid Caldironi, Founder

Like many others, I used to believe that stuff gets recycled, and there was no other way of living without creating a lot of waste. After reading about Lauren Singer, with years of rubbish fitting in a jar, I've decided to go zero waste. But companies don't make it easy for people to avoid waste. Bulk Market® was born to fix this.

Bruna Martins, Operations

Animal lover, adventurer and the perfect zero waste sidekick, expert in managing operations and procurement for healthy food chains.

 

How we can be part of the solution -->

 

We've been featured on ---> 

We will also divert a lot of plastics from landfilling by transforming yogurt pots and fruit crates into shop fittings --->

Follow us and spread the word --->

Instagram: @bulkmarketuk

Twitter: @bulkmarketuk

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/bulkmarketuk

story:
Make your home a Pono Home and save!

Greening our homes is the biggest opportunity to help us break our dependence on fossil fuels and reduce our exposure to petrochemical ingredients. In every home across America, even the best intentioned citizens may not know some of the simplest green changes they can make (or how to make them): 

  • What temperature their water heater should be set to for maximum efficiency (120 F), or how to set it (ummm...)
  • How many lumens of light that are ideal in their bathroom (errr..., what?)
  • How many gallons of water are wasted per minute in the shower 
  • What the difference is between a power strip and a smart strip or how to install them for maximum efficiency
  • How to identify potentially carcinogenic ingredients in personal care products....

The list goes on, and it quickly gets overwhelming, causing many people to do...nothing. Meanwhile, hard earned money goes to pay utility bills that come with a big carbon footprint, leaving less to spend on healthy food and nontoxic personal care products. 

We think there's a better way, which is why we invented Pono Home. 

Pono Home is a green home consulting service currently doing business in Honolulu County. It was recently selected for inclusion in Hawaii's clean tech incubator, the Energy Excelerator, beating out hundreds of innovative and qualified clean tech startups: 

"Pono Home provides simple, easy-as-pie energy efficiency solutions for homeowners and renters.  Our Energy Excelerator selected Pono Home for our 2014 cohort (from more than 200 companies that applied) because we love that they turn home energy efficiency from complicated to delightful.  It's companies like Pono Home that not only are helping people save money, but also are helping the state reduce our dependence on imported oil."                --Dawn Lippert, Senior Manager, Energy Excelerator

Read more about the Energy Excelerator's 2014 clean tech startup cohort and award winners here!


What happens during a Pono Home visit?

Our service is pure convenience. Rather than recommend what you should do, we just make your home healthier and more efficient from top to bottom. 

Here's a sampling of our services:   

Clockwise from top left: checking and installing water efficiency at the tap; testing appliances for energy use to show you how much you can save with simple behavioral changes; a sampling of the energy efficient lighting options we can install, cleaning condenser coils to maximize refrigerator efficiency; water efficiency for the toilet; and showing drivers how to drive more fuel-efficiently. Other services are more oriented toward ingredients in food and personal care products, and others, like cleaning out the dryer lint vent, are not only good for efficiency but make your home more fire safe, too!

We show up with the hardware and know-how to make your home greener, and we make it happen, right on the spot. In just a few hours, your home will be cleaner, healthier, and more efficient. In many of our initial house visits, the service has paid for itself by reducing utility bills in anywhere from 2-6 months, with nothing but savings thereafter for you and your family. Best yet, much of the installations we do you can take with you if you move, and much of what you can learn during those hours will save you money and reduce your exposure to toxic stuff for the rest of your life, no matter how many times you move. 

So whether you're homeowner or renter, the benefits are crystal clear!


What You Get For Your Support!

This campaign is about helping residents cut their utility bills and reduce our dependence on foreign oil, single-use plastics, and toxic ingredients. As a thanks for your contribution, you can choose as your rewards...


$5 (Honolulu only)

The Pono Home coupon guide. Find savings on all sorts of other green services around Honolulu.Check out http://ponohome.com/coupons/ for more. 


$40 (Anywhere)

A whole slew of cool sustainability goodies for this level of support. You'll get: 

  • Two magnets to place directly on your washer/dryer and dishwasher so you and your family can reference energy and water saving practices right at the point of use. Every time. Use these magnets right, and it's $8500 worth of savings over the life of your washer/dryer and dishwasher! 
  • Green Living Ideas, an e-book that includes a bunch more information to help you save money and have a healthier home that we simply can't cover in a 2-3 hour house visit.  
  • The Hawaii-based sustainability board game, GBO Hawaii, which is all about the transition from a dirty economy to a clean one. See who's the smartest green business investor in your household with this game that gives you points for your triple bottom line return on investment. 
  • If you're in Honolulu, we'll also include the coupon booklet, above. 





 

$59 (Honolulu)

15 early birds can get the Pono Home service at a pretty good discount. It's the same service, and we'll still donate $20 to one of our nonprofit partners (of your choice). Get on it! 


$80 (Honolulu)

Pono Home service at your place. Any of the Pono Home Service packages you see there include our full home assessment. This includes cleaning of your refrigerator condenser coils, lint removal from your dryer lint trap and vent, a lighting audit, a vampire power energy audit, toilet and sink leak checks, toxic ingredient inspection, adjustment of settings on your appliances for maximum efficiency, insulation check, tire pressure check, and many other efficiency checks on our 188 point checklist. In addition, you also get the e-book, the magnets, the board game, and the coupon guide.

PLUS, for each service bought through this campaign, we donate $20 to the environmental group listed there. For instance, buy the $80 Pono Home Service: Blue Planet Special, and we'll donate $20 to the Blue Planet Foundation. You save on your utility bills, we earn your business, and great local non-profits get money to continue their mission to make the world a more pono place to live.  A true win-win-win!


OUR NONPROFIT PARTNERS

More info on the nonprofits we are fundraising for in this campaign: 
  • Sustainable Coastlines
  • Sustainability Association of Hawaii
  • The School for Examining Essential Questions of Sustainability (SEEQS)
  • Kanu Hawaii
  • Blue Planet Foundation
  • Surfrider Foundation


$700 (Anywhere)

Get gift certificates for 10 Pono Home services, to give out to friends as gifts. You'll make a lot of friends in Honolulu (a good thing) with this one. You also get to choose the nonprofit that will receive 10 x $20 worth of donations from us!



$1200 (Anywhere)

Get gift certificates for 20 Pono Home services, and you'll all of a sudden have a lot more friends. You also get to choose the nonprofit that will receive 20 x $20 worth of donations from us!



$4500 (United States)

Pre-buy a franchise of Pono Home, wherever you are in the U.S. Pono Home is planning rapid expansion via franchising, and you can be a part of it by pre-buying your franchise right now (the price will likely be at least double this later on). The income potential is good, and the job is so damn fun that I'd do it for free (but don't tell our customers that). 

Plus, every single day, you get to work with your hands, with people who need help, and make a positive difference for them that you can see right away. Every. Single. Day. Check out PonoHome.com/Franchises or email us if you want more to discuss your career with us (info [at] PonoHome.com). We'd love to empower you to have the most fulfilling, gratifying, financially sound, and impactful career you could dream of. 




People are Starting to Talk

Listen to these experts in the clean tech world... 


"For the challenges that face the world today: an energy crisis, a climate crisis, and socioeconomic crises, Pono Home delivers a home run.”  -Zach Shahan, Site Director of CleanTechnica.com, the world’s #1 clean energy and green tech news site

"This is exactly what Hawaii, and the world, needs." -Jeff Mikulina, Executive Director, Blue Planet Foundation

"Inconvenience and lack of knowledge are two of the biggest barriers to the adoption of residential energy efficiency solutions, and Pono Home addresses those squarely. They don’t stop at simply identifying a smart change; they go ahead and make it happen. Every kilowatt hour avoided is fossil fuel that we don’t import--and carbon pollution that we don’t export. Pono Home is a sensible, brilliant solution for tapping into the power of efficiency.”  -Catharine Lo, Communications Director, Blue Planet Foundation


Customers are also talking about Pono Home... 

"I had a great service from Pono Home, they have all the bases covered to reduce your home electricity use.  It's been a couple months since the service and it appears that Pono Home is saving me about $20/month on a 3 person home on the electricity bill.  I would highly recommend this service.  It is comprised of many small adjustments and maintenance things that I didn't know about or was too busy to do myself."   -from Scott H., Pono Home customer, on the Pono Home Yelp page. 

"Being in the business of keeping abreast of environmental and conservation issues, I figured I already had a good handle on the items that could reduce my impact on the environment and my electricity bills...I was gladly reassured of my wise decision to hire Pono Home as they spent 2 hours finding bulbs, vampire loads, dust monsters choking my appliances and other issues I didn't even know existed...I highly recommend their services..."    -from Kahi P.


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't pitch in? No sweat, we love you for reading anyway. Please just post to your Facebook wall or let a friend know they can be a part of the solution. Thanks so much! 

In addition, you can help by helping yourself! Cut your footprint and rid your home of toxins by using our learning resources for both health and efficiency. You'll find all sorts of resources like creating a natural drain cleaner, ingredients to avoid in personal care products,  identifying the most common GMO ingredients, how to run your kitchen most energy efficiently, what is the cost of solar power, panels, and energy, as well as the payback, and fun things like the best kale recipes. :) Thanks again!

story:
The Vision

The world is moving into a period of widespread water stress and competition with huge implications for food security and ecological balance.  Now imagine—instead of giant water projects that devour energy reserves and irresponsibly batter water resources (think Three Gorges Dam), we pause, and figure out how small farmer-managed irrigation systems in places like Nepal have remained entirely self-reliant for thousands of years under stressor after stressor.

The Project   

Hi, I’m Rachel Murray and in 2010, I decided to carry out my vision of finding smarter innovations for sustainable irrigation by entering a graduate program at the University of Wisconsin’s Nelson Institute for Environmental Studies (named after Gaylord Nelson, former Governor of Wisconsin and founder of Earth Day). 

For the last two years I have formed collaborations with several major international organizations, the Nepal Department of Irrigation, and universities in the United States and Asia, to develop an integrated project to piece together the puzzle of how ancient small-scale farmer-managed irrigation systems in Nepal are adapting to the modern shocks that are threatening all water and crop systems in our world—climate change and the unintended effects of globalization. 

Starting this July, 2013 through January, 2014, I will be living in the farming communities of three middle hills districts (Kaski, Palpa, and Syangja) in Nepal, collecting data on a wide range of variables in the physical and social sciences, to shed light on the web of complex mechanisms that form sustainable farmer-managed irrigation systems.  I will also be asking community members what challenges are the biggest barriers to their success, such as women's access to resources and decision-making power, to look towards future interventions that are fitted to each community's unique situation and sensitive to their actual needs.

This project will uncover what makes farmer-managed irrigation systems in South Asia resilient, flexible, and enduring because, after all, we will all have to move towards sustainable, regional innovations in food production and water security for ourselves, and for our children.

How You Can Help Make This a Reality

Your help can make this research project a success, and here’s how:  While the above organizations have generously offered assistance with office space, expert consultation, translators, field sites and data sharing, I need your help with technological funding.

Doing this project right requires recording hundreds of interviews; collecting and compiling 30 years of weather, crop, land use and ownership, and economic data; and recording, organizing and analyzing my own direct field observations about every facet of these irrigation systems.

I need your support to fund the following research equipment:

  • A weather- and damage-resistant laptop for the field
  • Weather-proof recording equipment
  • Mobile field mapping and data collection software
  • A handheld GPS unit with high sensitivity and expandable storage
  • Solar chargers for the field

You can also help out by spreading the word about this campaign via emails, Facebook, Twitter, or your own blog, for any of your friends and family you think might be interested in investing in food and water security.

Others I'm Working With

  • International Water Management Institute
  • International Network of Participatory Irrigation Management
  • Nepal Department of Irrigation
  • University of Pokhara Institute of Forestry, Nepal
  • Arizona State University
  • Asian Institute of Technology  

Interested in More Information?  Read on...

How better research can help us avoid costly failures

Irrigation development failures are almost always based on a faulty understanding of the problem's true nature.

An irrigation specialist once told me about a government irrigation project in Nepal that included installing a modern concrete head water structure to replace the one that the farmers maintained annually, assuming that this installation would increase productivity.

Later they were shocked to find out that agricultural productivity had actually gone down. The decrease in productivity was a result of the collapse of a complex internal hierarchy and the disintegration of the community structure wherein upper-end users made yearly agreements to provide tail-end users with water because the tail-end users provided maintenance throughout the year.

This maintenance was either not required with the new dam or the farmers felt no ownership over the infrastructure, their attitude being—the government built it and it was their job to maintain it with their own money and materials. This not only decreased the overall productivity of the local agroecosystem, but had the insidious effect of making the community less self-reliant and more dependent on the government.

To date, the developed world has spent substantially more on food aid to developing nations than it has spent on agricultural interventions to help these nations feed themselves. Research needs to find ways to empower  governments and citizens rather than ways to provide them mainly with food assistance.

While it is tempting to ignore the plight of those who seem so distant, globalization and climate change have made the world much smaller and entirely interdependent. This situation is not just a humanitarian disaster, but a threat to both democratic values and national interests.

Our futures are tied together with developing countries in a world facing formidable global challenges, including scarce natural resources and the effects of climate change amidst ever-growing populations.

Education and research must recognize that there is an obligation that comes with knowledge. With the knowledge gained from FMIS research such as mine, local, regional, and global agencies can prove effective leaders in sustainable crop production by recognizing that local users, under certain conditions, are able to offer better institutional solutions and enforce rules at lower cost. The key to global food and water security requires a new understanding of the ways in which these systems are adapting to social and environmental flux.

story:
Erica Klopf and the Florida Gulf Coast University Food Forest 

In May of 2011, a group of passionate students, faculty, and staff at Florida Gulf Coast University launched a permaculture project on their campus called the FGCU Food Forest.  I was blessed with the opportunity to play a key role in the design and installation of this amazing project.  Since its inception, over 12,000 student-volunteer hours have been logged there on work days that are 100% student organized.  Thousands of pounds of food have been grown naturally and made available free to students 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  

I have been accepted to give a Lightning Talk about our project at the Permaculture Your Campus International Conference being held at the University of Amherst this June, and have received a full scholarship to attend the conference.  Now, I am asking for help to fund my travel costs to Massachusetts.  

This is important because it is an opportunity for the FGCU Food Forest project to be connected to the greater national and international network of permaculture projects on universities.  This network will support and expand the availability of permaculture projects on campuses and strengthen this movement.  With your help, the FGCU Food Forest and our our special subtropical region of Southern Florida will be represented on an international level and become a part of this network.  

to read more about the conference visit this link 

http://www.umasspermacultureconference.com/index.html

to read more about the FGCU Food Forest visit this link 

http://fgcufoodforest.weebly.com/

To read more about me please visit my resume website here 

http://ericalynnklopf.weebly.com/

What you are funding

This will fund my plan ticket to Boston and travel to and from Amherst.  If the total is not reached, I will unfortunately be unable to go to the conference and represent the FGCU Food Forest.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help me raise these funds by sharing this with those who might be interested in supporting this innitiative.  Thank you so much and have a great day!
