This will fund my plan ticket to Boston and travel to and from Amherst.  If the total is not reached, I will unfortunately be unable to go to the conference and represent the FGCU Food Forest.   
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please help me raise these funds by sharing this with those who might be interested in supporting this innitiative.  Thank you so much and have a great day!

story:
We are Cardboard Reality Farm & Studio a small business, permaculture farm, art shop and animation studio owned and operated by bekky O’Neil & Keith Del Principe.  We are artist-ecologists, first generation farmers with a passion for biodiversity and the environment.  We met twelve years ago while volunteering with Bread & Puppet Theatre in Vermont, in 2008, and have been making art and learning to grow things ever since.

In 2016 after graduating together from the Film Animation Program at the Mel Hoppenheim School of Cinema at Concordia University in Montréal, we moved away from city life to bekky’s family’s farm in Northumberland County, Ontario, and began the enormous task of converting it into a working organic farm.  A few years later we opened a brick & mortar studio and farm shop in Historic Downtown Cobourg, Ontario.

This year has presented a series of challenges for many of us running small businesses.  Covid-19 has impacted us all, with many of us working hard to keep afloat in this strange new time.  Since August of 2018 we have been renting a beautiful (& very small) shop in Historic Downtown Cobourg, which we cleaned up, painted white and worked hard to fill with goods and furnishings from the farm.

The space has been very special to us over the past two years, allowed us to connect to a wider community in our new setting, and changed our business in immeasurable ways.  But the closure and subsequent drop in business (with Cobourg usually being such a vibrant tourist town) is more than we can continue to weather.  The truth is: the pandemic wiped out our shop.  In Cobourg, we primarily made money serving community art workshops - a service we can’t continue to offer in a space that size due to physical distancing requirements.

And so, when our lease is up at the end of August we will close our shop in Cobourg, and adapt to an on-farm based business.  Our aim is to continue to serve the community by migrating our shop to a site on our farm situated adjacent to Highway 45.  We will be winding down on workshops (for the time being), transitioning our retail model further online (we’ve already launched our new website) and continuing to invest in the farm and selling at market.

This funding will allow us to unify our project, once and for all combining farm and studio.  Our farm work has been increasing in volume and scope, so much so that an on site location will allow us to go deeper into our fruit and vegetable program and animation practice without having to give up the retail side of our operation.

But in order to do so we need your help.  Since 2016 we have been farming with minimal tools, making up for our lack of funds and equipment with hard work and passion.  Now we need an investment to take our evolving business to the next level.


What We Need & What You Get

We’re raising $25,000 (including $2000 to cover Indiegogo’s 8% platform and transaction fees) to transition from our brick & mortar shop in Cobourg to a location on the farm where visitors and tourists will be able to purchase our goods directly, and to purchase a farm truck to allow us to expand our work & transport our goods to market.  These funds will also be used to help us move our goods, supplies and furnishings from Cobourg to the farm in Roseneath.

 

On Site Farm/Studio Shop

The shop, where we will continue to sell artwork and goods from the farm, will be the first step towards building the arts & education centre we have always envisioned, allowing us, in the future, to offer artist residencies, workshops and courses, and to make work from participating artists, interns, and collaborators available for sale on site.  Keeping our studio and retail space on the farm will save us about an hour in the car, (not to mention fuel) for each day the shop is open.

The area we live in has changed tremendously since 2016.  Back then, besides locals nobody had heard of Roseneath, just North of Alderville First Nation, and we felt that we had to bring our goods into the larger community of Cobourg to sell our work.  Now in the age where being in a small, confined downtown shop can be another stressful experience in a world full of stressful experiences, we want to work to build a space where visitors can escape all that, and we are sitting just north of one of the fastest developing economies in the province.  

We would like to purchase a modified shipping container to place on the property, close to Highway 45, which will be used as a gallery space / art shop where we can sell our products and produce.

 

Farm Truck

A much needed farm truck (for which we already have some money saved) will allow us to transport our goods to market, assist with building projects on the farm, and guarantee that there is always transportation on the farm for safety reasons

For the past 5 years we've been out here with one station wagon, generously on a long term loan from family, and while it has served us well, from building projects to market days, opening the shop to transporting animals to the vet, it’s time we had an appropriate vehicle that will not only allow us to scale up our operations, but also to open the opportunity for us to participate in more than one market or event on a given day, and to allow the potential for one of us to travel for craft shows, while the other holds down the fort on the farm.

We’ve just purchased a Kubota RTV, which will be our farm workhorse, allowing us to save our backs by transporting materials goods, from feed to wood, across our acreage.  A corresponding truck will bridge the gap, allowing us to move goods from the forest or the field to the farmhouse, to market.

 

Perks

We know this is a big ask, but we can’t do it alone.  We’ve set up a series of perks from the studio that we are excited to offer as a thank you for believing in our mission.  

  • Shout Out on our Website
  • Credit in bekky’s Forthcoming Animated Documentary about the Farm
  • Set of Cardboard Reality Farm Postcards
  • Cardboard Reality Patch
  • Cardboard Reality Face Mask
  • 2021 Cardboard Reality Permaculture Calendar
  • Silkscreened “Support Small Farms” Shirt
  • Silkscreened “Support Small Farms” Tote
  • Custom Family Portrait (Muppet Style)
  • Custom Pet Portrait (Realistic)
  • Seeds from our Farm: Seed Saving Collection
  • Private Farm Tour

 

If we are not successful in meeting our full fundraising goals we will continue to fundraise for this project through animation contracts and farm/studio sales.  Our priority if we are not 100% funded is to allocate the successful amount towards a farm vehicle, and if we have to take more time to build the new shop, or begin with a smaller roadside farm stand that is the approach we will take.

 

The Impact

Our project is bigger than this campaign, but without these resources it’s going to be a long road.  Here’s what we think is special about Cardboard Reality Farm & Studio:

  • We’re growing without the use of pesticides.
  • We’ve created a young orchard and bountiful perennial garden using natural farming techniques.
  • We practice no-till permaculture farming, which benefits the soil structure structure, and allows a complex ecosystem and refuge for wildlife to develop alongside our crops.
  • Since 2015 we have been working to transform 80 acres of monocrop into a thriving ecosystem.
  • Our farm is a closed loop, all inputs we use in our growing system come from the farm.

 

We have been farming for 5 years, did a CSA for one of those years, another we grew a giant field of pumpkins.  We believe farming is an art as well as a science.  Each year we’ve had more success in farming, but we’ve outgrown our resources.

  • At the studio we provide access to accessible cheap art.
  • We share our creative skills with the community, and aim to both provide tools and inspire.
  • We continue to develop artwork and films about sustainably agriculture - bekky’s MFA thesis film, What Does a Garden Know? will be released in the fall.
  • At our shop in Cobourg we have served hundreds of customers, took custom orders from family portraits to woodworking, and most recently put together Covid-19 Care Packages.
  • We taught workshops to dozens of students of all ages, with subjects stretching from silkscreening to indigo dyeing to stop motion animation, all of whom showed excellence in their new skills.

 

We love what we’ve built and while we are sad to say goodbye to the studio in Cobourg, we are ready for the next chapter of Cardboard Reality’s adventure.

We’ve said it before and we’ll say it again:
We believe that good food & good art make the world a better place.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to help us out, but don’t have the finances to contribute?  There are so many other ways we would love your support:

You can share our campaign online, and let your network know what our farm or studio meant to you!  (You can share right through Indiegogo!)

You can shop online at our new web store at www.cardboardreality.ca to support our small business AND get cool stuff!

You can increase our reach by following us on Facebook, Vimeo & Instagram for updates with new work and events.

  • Facebook: www.facebook.com/cardboardreality
  • Instagram (Farm): www.instagram.com/cardboardrealityfarm
  • Instagram (Studio): www.instagram.com/cardboardrealitystudio
  • Vimeo: www.vimeo.com/cardboardreality

 

If the one time gesture isn’t your thing you can become a sustaining member of our community through Patreon, with all sorts of other exclusive updates and perks you can find us at: https://www.patreon.com/cardboardrealityfarmandstudio

story:
Engineers without Borders San Francisco Nicaragua team needs your help to raise the remaining funds that are needed to complete the first phase of the El Limon's Water System Improvement Project. 

We are a group of Civil, Electrical, and Chemical Engineers who provide engineering design  and project management assistance to a small community in Nicaragua.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

About 1100 dollars are needed to pay for the remainder of materials and skilled labor that is needed to complete this phase of the project.  We will be sending a at least one engineer from our team to oversee the implementation trip, but ideally we would like to send at least two. Their travel expenses would amount to about 800 $ each. Anything raise above this amount will be saved for future phases of the project.  Please take a look at the perks to the right for gifts you can receive for donating to our project. 

Project Background

El Limon is a farming community of over 60 families near the major town of Estelí, Nicaragua. 

In 2007 El Limon’s water committee was formed to manage the installation of the solar-powered water distribution system, and since the installation the water committee has monitored and operated the system, collected funds for maintenance, received complaints from the community, hired engineers to service the system, and administered the utility bills. When the existing system ceased to provide sufficient water to all members of the community, the water community initiated contact with the EWB-SFP team to identify potential solutions for this issue.

The Need

A safe, dependable water supply is essential to the socio-economic development of an agrarian community, and before the installation of the solar-powered water pump river water was the primary water source for El Limon. River water is extremely contaminated with pesticides that leach in from nearby farms, and was used for bathing and laundry. 

El Limon had already stood out as a forward-thinking and engaged community that has provided neighboring communities with leader in sustainability. However, the existing system does not provide sufficient supply to all families in the community. 

Our Response

During the November 2013 assessment trip, the EWB-SFP project team performed interviews and surveys, and realized that El Limon’s storage tank did not reach sufficient capacity for there to be enough head to reach many homes in the village. Because the pump is solar powered, insufficient water is pumped on cloudy days to meet demand and the storage tank was not filled at night. After performing a feasibility study, a hybrid grid/solar powered solution was proposed because if the system were connected to the grid, then at night time the community could switch the pump on, and let the tank fill up so that in the morning there would be enough head to reach the homes at the extremities of the village. Additionally, on cloudy days they could connect to the grid and have enough power to continue to pump water. 

The Future

Our team has committed to working with this community for the next 5 years. Once we have complete converting their solar powered water system to a hybrid  system, we will work with the community to identify other needs they may have. One possibility is a waster water improvement project, or rain catchment implementation project.

story:
Short Summary

Hi!  I'm going to build a tiny house that will be around 140 sq ft. In the past few years of downsizing (into my current 80 sq ft space) I have had to talk my friends & family out of giving me any physical gifts so I'm using this birthday to enable those who have expressed wanting to help me toward my tiny house to do so. While I have some friends that will help with the build, many are too far to do that or can't afford the time but still want to pitch in somehow. I think this is a very weird but effective way of having you contribute and know exactly where your gift ends up.  Can I buy this myself? Yep..I HAVE TO! but if the the funds come from you and your name lives on with it, well, that's just a perk for me and my heart.

  • I like to make a big deal of my birthday and this "gift" pinpoints your gift to something I will have in my daily life and be important to me...and know you were behind it.
  • If you want to immortalize your name in association with my composting toilet, this is your chance.
  • Any support you give will show me the support you are expressing toward my tiny house life...even if you still think it's a little far out.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The Nature's Head composting toilet cost, taxes & shipping will be $1000. It's comes with great reviews and a friend has one on his boat that they sail with for 3 months at a time. No smells, normal size, easy to maintain. 
  • Perks will be weird. Your name in lights in association with a composting toilet? Yeah, it's weird but hilarious. I'll think of you whenever I go. How sweet is that?
  • If your generosity goes beyond the $1k for the NH toilet, funds will go towards solar, rainwater catchment, and solely to the creation of the tiny house & ways to make it more environmentally friendly. The perks will be similar in that your name will live on with the project component.

The Impact

Your contribution will make a statement. First, that you accept my choice and second, that composting toilets are cool.  Right now the majority of the population poops into clean, potable water. I'm opting out of that. Less flushing from me!

    Risks & Challenges

    Composting toilets are illegal in many municipalities. They're actually illegal in my county. (Hmmm...maybe I should do an Indiegogo for bail money?)  Codes need to change and I want to be an example of how sustainable this choice is.  I expect "red tape" challenges along the way but your support will help me know that people believe in the tiny house movement.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      You'll see that the smallest contribution is $5 but if you can't throw that at me, throw some friends my way if you know they know me but might not know about this (yes, I still have friends who aren't on "The Facebook" or "The Twitter"!)  This campaign is only a short time-frame but I hope it's long enough to reach people to whom it matters and support my weird goal.

story:
Hi, we're Evan Granito and Kammer Offenhauser. We're activists. We're also permaculture designers, raisers of food, lovers of food, lovers of live music, and lovers of people.  We're human beings doing our best to play our parts in the evolution of how we relate to our environment, food and communities. We're teaming with world-renowned artist The Polish Ambassador to bring as much action to his stop in Michigan as possible and we need your support! Please read on to understand who the Polish Ambassador is and why this project is an exciting opportunity to inspire change on a local and national scale--in the local organic food movement, ecology and habitat restoration, and the ethics and actions of touring musical acts.

The Polish Ambassador's first-of-its-kind--make sure that one sinks in first-of-its-kind--fall Permaculture Action Tour is bringing together permaculture educators and community organizers to inspire and educate people about how we can make a shift towards a more sustainable and regenerative way of living, and channel this energy into local project builds in each of the cities they visit--getting people to take action to build the world they want to see. An oft repeated mantra of "think globally, act locally" embodies the energy, impact and magnitude of this campaign. This is a musical tour that celebrates and unites lovers of music and community change in a 30-city, two-day dance of music and local projects that get people working with the earth and their communities on various local community gardens, natural building projects and all manners of endeavors that weaves sustainability, political activism and world transformation. 

This specific project is a co-created effort between Michigan organizers, the city of Kalamazoo and the incredible services of the Polish Ambassador's team. This project is to transform an underused public space in an underserved neighborhood in Kalamazoo. The project will demonstrate the beauty, function and sustainability of permaculture design with an edible landscape showcasing a bio-mimicked food forest. Layers of fruit and nut trees, nutrient-cycling support species, edible ground cover, aromatic and medicinal herbs cohabit with flowers harmonically supporting each other and the soil in an edible and educational symbiosis. Proper signage will create a lasting educational liaison for all who come and interact with this living, fruitful and abundant community hub. 

Public food forests are springing into existence world-wide and are becoming a place of community celebration, pride and opportunity. Check out the country's first, Beacon Food Forest in Seattle, their video here gives you everything you need to know about the absolutely groundbreaking importance of this project. These nationally recognized projects are on the cusp of affecting communities everywhere and this will put Kalamazoo and Michigan on the map as a progressive example of people caring about their community health, ecological restoration and opportunity.Here'swhat's happening in the always exciting Austin, TX. Kalamazoo's food forest will have an additional perk to help ensure its maintenance and support; it will be a component of a larger community funded project,Riverview Launch. The site is on a 6-acre parcel that connects the frequented Kalamazoo River Valley Trail to several other parks, downtown Kalamazoo and core urban neighborhoods. Several other cooperating organizations have already made this place a growing center for sustainable urban programming and community fun, learning and work. The Kalamazoo Community Land Bank purchased it and is excited to share this site with the Permaculture Action Tour and install a food forest that can be maintained as part of what already happens at the site. This is a huge key in determining the success or failure of a public food forest, staffed sites ensure protection, care and maintenance of our edible investments. We're incredible grateful and appreciative of the opportunity to connect with this project and add a permaculture fingerprint. At its core this is a project to connect deeper a community to clean, radically local and fresh organic food as an experiential way for Kalamazoo to join other leading-edge communities in creating the beauty and change we wish to live in.

www.PermacultureAction.org

Join and help us spread positive change and create a new, free public space of abundance for a grassroots neighborhood in Kalamazoo, Mi as part of The Polish Ambassador's evolutionary tour.

What We Need

We need to raise at least $7,500 to support the permaculture educators and local community organizers collaborating with the Polish Ambassador by providing educational material, tools, trees, plant material, seeds, plant protection, irrigation supplies, signage, landscaping materials, and experiential learning opportunities outside the show. Your donations will keep this project of the permaculture action tour supplied for the future, bring in key-note speakers like David Milarch of The Archangel Ancient Tree Archive and more, educators and help us document and publish everything we do so everyone can benefit. 

The funds will be distributed to these areas:

  • Fruit and Nut Trees for the edible walking tour including chestnut, ginkgo, cherry, apple, apricot, paw paw, mulberry, plum, pear, persimmons and more
  • Nitrogen-fixing support species including black locust, goumi berry, honey berry, sea berry, buffalo berry, bay berry, autumn olive, and more
  • Edible understory including strawberry, raspberries, blackberries, gooseberries, currants and more
  • Tree tubes to provide ideal growing conditions and browse protection for our most valuable investments: the Trees, as trees mature and become viable nursery stock for expansion, these tubes can be reused to grow an ever-increasing living library
  • Herbs and flowers
  • Soil creating and nitrogen fixing ground cover.
  • Custom and beautiful lasered wood signage
  • Teaching Materials 
  • Educator Fees (For bringing in bona-fide Permaculture studs and key-note speakers like David Milarch of Arch Angel Ancient Tree Archive)
  • Fuel costs for transporting, trucks, trailers, the Bobcat and the necessary equipment to get this project lifted
  • Reward Fulfillment
  • Documenting the Project, Editing Video, and Creating Media

$7,500 will enable us to make this project happen. This budget will be used along with the physical contributions from supporting Michigan farmers, organizations and people who care about these kinds of passion projects coming into reality. Raising beyond $7,500 will allow us to provide more materials to site, permanent tools and facilities where we're building the garden and permaculture food forest system. Funds raised beyond the goal will also allow us to put more energy towards creating the permanent dedicated volunteer group to tend this system into its mature forest-like setting and creating partnerships with schools and youth programs, neighborhood groups and others that want to get active and expand this system. Funds will also help publicize this project in a way that will inspire other creatives, doers, community leaders and artists to follow suit, and spread this message further through learning materials, social media, publications, and artistic mediums. Documentation starting from this very Indiegogo campaign, to the organization of community groups representing generic outreach maps for communities across the country to replicate this project as a way to create public spaces that secure genetic diversity and heritage in a living, edible library and inherently contain the ability to propagate (multiply and expand) from the original donations gathered here by this campaign. Your donations expand the network of transformative work that is already being done across the country to redefine our world's relationship to their food and the growing process. Further financial support will funnel into future projects of the the The Polish Ambassador's nationally and globally expanding projects. 

Impact and Magnitude

In a far-observing sense, your contributions go directly to the people it touches most often.  Volunteers can watch this plot of seedlings grow and expand as fruit trees mature, the forest grows in height and density, animals reclaim habitat in an edible ecosytem that values the exchanges of bacteria, fungus, trees, our flighted friends, woodland creatures and humans alike. Fruits of this project's labors become obvious to all who interact with it, play within it and grow up with a veritable Garden of Eden in their community. More importantly, Kalamazoo and Michigan garner national attention and traction in the local food movement and the Permaculture wave that is a design science permeating open minds globally. It offers itself as a documented replicable model that interacts with diverse social groups

Confirmed Days:

 Kalamazoo, Mi October 25 & 26

WHAT: The Polish Ambassador's Show

WHEN: October 25, 2014

WHERE:  Kalamazoo State Theatre

81868 Lost Valley Ln, Dexter, Oregon 97431

FACEBOOK EVENT: Click Here

CLICK FOR MORE INFORMATION & DETAILS

WHAT: Permaculture Action Day, Food Forest and Garden Install with Key-note Speakers, Yoga, Music, Food and more.

WHEN: October 26, 2014
11:00am-6:00pm

WHERE:Riverview Launch 
1523 Riverview Drive
Kalamazoo, Michigan

story_txt:
Hi, we're Evan Granito and Kammer Offenhauser. We're activists. We're also permaculture designers, raisers of food, lovers of food, lovers of live music, and lovers of people.  We're human beings doing our best to play our parts in the evolution of how we relate to our environment, food and communities. We're teaming with world-renowned artist The Polish Ambassador to bring as much action to his stop in Michigan as possible and we need your support! Please read on to understand who the Polish Ambassador is and why this project is an exciting opportunity to inspire change on a local and national scale--in the local organic food movement, ecology and habitat restoration, and the ethics and actions of touring musical acts.The Polish Ambassador's first-of-its-kind--make sure that one sinks in first-of-its-kind--fall Permaculture Action Tour is bringing together permaculture educators and community organizers to inspire and educate people about how we can make a shift towards a more sustainable and regenerative way of living, and channel this energy into local project builds in each of the cities they visit--getting people to take action to build the world they want to see. An oft repeated mantra of "think globally, act locally" embodies the energy, impact and magnitude of this campaign. This is a musical tour that celebrates and unites lovers of music and community change in a 30-city, two-day dance of music and local projects that get people working with the earth and their communities on various local community gardens, natural building projects and all manners of endeavors that weaves sustainability, political activism and world transformation. 
This specific project is a co-created effort between Michigan organizers, the city of Kalamazoo and the incredible services of the Polish Ambassador's team. This project is to transform an underused public space in an underserved neighborhood in Kalamazoo. The project will demonstrate the beauty, function and sustainability of permaculture design with an edible landscape showcasing a bio-mimicked food forest. Layers of fruit and nut trees, nutrient-cycling support species, edible ground cover, aromatic and medicinal herbs cohabit with flowers harmonically supporting each other and the soil in an edible and educational symbiosis. Proper signage will create a lasting educational liaison for all who come and interact with this living, fruitful and abundant community hub.

story:
My name is 'Vey' Hugh Finlay (from Ireland).  I have been on the Invincible America Assembly for 5 years.  As an active flier, I fly for over an hour in every program. 


My sense of duty demands that I do the program well, for the sake of America and my own Enlightenment.


Please help me to continue to be on the Invincible America Assembly.  I need $3,000 to be on IAA for another two years.

The money will allow me to do an MUM academic course (Postgraduate Certificate in Maharishi Vedic Science) which will extend my student visa and allow me to stay on IAA.

Any contribution, even $10, will be gratefully accepted.

I thank you from the bottom of my heart, and America will also thank you.

Jai Guru Dev

Vey

story:
STRETCH GOAL: 500 USD for 1 month testing 

We have seen so much interest in what we are doing so we want to take it to the next level to ensure the success of this project and best possible development of the technology. 
With the extra 500 USD we will be able to enter a small 1 month long test phase. We will operate the machine in a village for 1 month and collect plastic trash that is not valuable to pemulung or informal trash collectors. We will experiment with different kinds of plastic and ways to wash and dry dirty plastic. Here is what we will spend on:
  1. Build a small shed and sorting facility - 160 USD
  2. Hire a worker for 1 month to collect plastic and run the plastic to fuel plant - 200 USD
  3. Buy 2 large drums for plastic washing - 40 USD
  4. Buy a weighing scale to weigh plastic and fuel samples - 100 USD
You are all invited to come and check it out for yourselves if we reach the goal! 


Update 3/11/14: We have received 100% of our funding goal in 24 hours - THANK YOU contributors for getting this project off the ground!!!


Short Summary

We are a group of 4 young men that have been in Bali, Indonesia since our childhood. Being aware of the local waste situation we have come up with an idea that we believe can make a difference. 

We believe that Indonesia is so full of creative potential that can make a difference and that empowerment is needed. Our idea is to create a machine that lets communities take on the plastic waste problem themselves. It is a single building block to a comprehensive problem.

We discovered the machine in Denpasar Bali, it was invented by Ida Bagus Ketut Atmaja. Pak Aji as he likes to be called created a backyard plastic distillation that converts plastics back into fuel. The fuel then burns up to 70 times cleaner than open fire burning of plastic and we believe it can used for tractors, generators, farming appliances and other machinery.

Immage above: Pak Aji's plastic to fuel machine. It has many safety hazards and design problems.

Our goal is to take Pak Aji´s invention and to increase its potential, viability, safety and effectiveness. The device can be built for about 500 USD and it has the potential to create 1 L of fuel from a little more than 1 Kg of plastic waste.
If every town had one of these machines, people would no longer be throwing their plastic away into the environment.

We are asking for funding to build a safe plastic to fuel machine and research and discover the hidden details and make a first complete overview of the real potential of such a machine in Bali.


The Impact

We wish to make this machine an open source project. This means that all our materials, designs, and steps will be documented and assembled into a manual for anyone to build the machine themselves. All parts will be locally sourced and easy to obtain. This will allow any village in Indonesia to raise the money needed to build the machine (roughly 500 USD) and build their very own plastic to fuel machine. The machine can be run by the village or a local activist.

Image above: The beginnings of plastic to fuel machine, design version 5.0

Right now we are asking for funding to build this machine and tinker with it. The next step will be to analyze the fuel and come up with viable and safe use for it. We are already in the process of involving universities to help with the analysis. A private research university in Germany, Jacobs University Bremen, where Maitri Fischer, one of our team members studied, has all the equipment and expertise to analyze the fuel and help research a potential use. They have agreed to help and are waiting for our proposal.

This project has immense potential to better one of the most serious environmental issues Bali has - waste disposal. Something like 40 percent (if not more) of trash generated by households ends up in the environment - rivers, ravines, rice fields, mangrove forests, construction sites etc. Although a lot of plastic is recycled by the "pemulung" a significant portion is left behind. With this machine we have the ability to take that plastic that is not being recycled to recycle and reuse it. 

Our dream is to give plastic value and that people will start saving their plastic and recycling it by bringing it to their village collection points for a monetary return or for fuel. This will significantly reduce the amount of plastic entering the environment.


What We Need

We believe we need a total of 1000 USD for materials to build version 5.0 of the plastic to fuel machine. The end product should be a machine that can be built with 500 to 600 USD, but we need a bit more money to tinker and upgrade parts as we progress as well as install pressure sensors and temperature gauges to keep the machine safe. Leftover funds if there are any will go into shipping cost of fuel samples, analyzing the fuel and experiments.

We are not profiting from this in any way. We have already started buying materials with our own money. We are committed to see this project through.

We want to remain completely transparent throughout this project so we will post all receipts in the photo gallery and give continuous updates. We are accountable to all our donors, you can come bye and see everything for yourself whenever you want.

Risks & Challenges

We have received a lot of input already from FB groups and a lot of people are concerned with the quality of fuel produced by this machine.

Our first step is to make a safe and operable machine. The next stage will be to analyze the fuel and find a safe and reliable use for it. This is not the first time someone is doing plastic pyrolysis - converting plastic to fuel. There is a wealth of information on it in peer reviewed journals.

It will be important to find out what kind of fuel is produced from what kind of plastic and come up with an optimal mix for Indonesia that produces a fuel that can be used safely. According to our research, the resulting fuel will likely have to be further distilled or mixed with diesel fuel to produce a safe fuel for engines.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like this project but want to contribute in another way, here are some ideas:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Share it on social media and rant about it to your friends. Getting other to contribute is just as good.
  • If you want to pitch in with your advice or ideas please feel free to contact us.

story:
As many of you may know, our dear friend Chaya/Samantha's bike was stolen from outside her apartment earlier this week.  Her greatest mode of transportation, her ability to carry tons of lumber from Home Depot on two wheels, and her avoidance of the CTA to save the environment is no longer possible.

Chaya without a bike wouldn't really be...Chaya.  She really needs our help!  Please help Chaya/Samantha afford a new bike.  Pledge as little as $1 or $20, whatever you can!

story:
What We are Doing

On April 26, 2014 we will begin the Ohio River Water Walk. We will start this Walk in Pittsburgh, PA at the confluence of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers and carry a vessel of Ohio River water to the confluence of the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers in Cairo, IL.  This 981-mile journey is a ceremony, and every step is a prayer for the water. 

This is the 3rd Nibi (Water) Walk we have taken. In 2011, many Indigenous women and our supporters walked from the four directions, carrying the healing salt water from four oceans, to the heart of Turtle Island, Lake Superior. In 2013, we walked 1752 miles along the Mississippi River, carrying healthy, drinkable, water from Lake Itasca to Venice, LA, where the Gulf is considered to be a dead zone due to hypoxia. 

This year, we will walk the most polluted river in the United States, the life force of North America, the Ohio River. In light of the recent chemical spill in the Elk River, 300,000 people living in the Ohio River’s watershed are now living with water rendered undrinkable, not even safe for use in washing clothes. Now more then ever, the Ohio River and the people living along its vast watershed need our prayers and solidarity.


What We Need & What You Get

Our needs are very basic. The Nibi Walks are all volunteer ventures that bring people together to act on behalf of the water that gives us life.

We need walkers to join with us, whether it is for one day or the entire walk. Walkers will be asked to follow certain protocol but all are welcome to walk. Come walk with us!

We need people who are willing to host us in their community and provide housing and/or food. If you live along the route of the walk, please consider holding an educational event to raise awareness in your community. And please consider providing a meal or lodging for the walkers to help us on our way.

We need people to help spread the word about the walk and the need to care for our water. Please help share the news of the walk on social media and contact media in your community to make sure they know we are coming through your town!

And, we need funds. We need to raise $10,000 to support this Walk. These funds will be used as follows:

$5,000:  To rent an RV. This is important because we want to ensure the walkers have a place to rest and if needed, to sleep.

$1500:  Gas for the 981 miles

$1500:  Food and snacks for the Walkers

$2000:  Lodging at motels for those nights we don’t have hosts

Please consider a donation! Your support will go far in helping the Walkers on their journey.

We have successfully walked to Lake Superior from the Four Directions (2011 Mother Earth Water Walk) and the entire length of the Mississippi River (2013 Mississippi River Water Walk). Without support from people all over the world, those walks would not have been possible. Our perks are a way to show you how much you are appreciated, and we have some cool ones this year! 

$10:  A thank you on Nibi Walk’s web site (if you want to remain anonymous, please let us know when you donate)

$25:  Above, plus a personal e mail with photos of the walk on the very first day

$50:  Above, plus the Ohio River Water Walk original poster

$100: Above, plus a set of four greeting cards of original artwork by Sharon Day, shipped by June 30, 2014

$250: Above, plus a fine art print of Dana Tiger’s Nibi Walk painting on archival cotton paper, shipped by June 30, 2014

$500: Above, plus a fine art print of Amy Cordova’s Ohio River Walk painting on cotton archival paper, shipped by June 30, 2014

$1000: Above, plus Nibi Walk music CD upon its release, shipped by December 1, 2014

$5000:  Above, plus a talk in your town by one of the water walkers (within the United States), by December 1, 2014.

This is the 3rd
Nibi (Water) Walk we have taken. In 2011, many
Indigenous women and our supporters walked from the four directions, carrying
the healing salt water from four oceans, to the heart of Turtle Island, Lake
Superior. In 2013, we walked 1752 miles along the Mississippi River, carrying
healthy, drinkable, water from Lake Itasca to Venice, LA, where the Gulf is
considered to be a dead zone due to hypoxia. 
This year, we will walk the most polluted river in
the United States, the life force of North America, the Ohio River. In light of
the recent chemical spill in the Elk River, 300,000 people living in the Ohio
River’s watershed are now living with water rendered undrinkable, not even safe
for use in washing clothes. Now more then ever, the Ohio River and
the people living along its vast watershed need our prayers and solidarity.What We Need & What You Get
Our needs are very basic. The Nibi Walks are all volunteer
ventures that bring people together to act on behalf of the water that gives us
life. 
We need walkers to
join with us, whether it is for one day or the entire walk. Walkers will be
asked to follow certain protocol but all are welcome to walk. Come walk with
us!
We need people who
are willing to host us in their community and provide housing and/or food. If
you live along the route of the walk, please consider holding an educational
event to raise awareness in your community. And please consider providing a
meal or lodging for the walkers to help us on our way.
We need people to
help spread the word about the walk and the need to care for our water.
Please help share the news of the walk on social media and contact media in your
community to make sure they know we are coming through your town!
And, we need funds.
We need to raise $10,000 to support this Walk. These funds will be used as
follows:
$5,000:  To rent an
RV. This is important because we want to ensure the walkers have a place to rest
and if needed, to sleep. 
$1500:  Gas for the
981 miles
$1500:  Food and
snacks for the Walkers
$2000:  Lodging at
motels for those nights we don’t have hosts
Please consider a donation! Your support will go far in
helping the Walkers on their journey.We have successfully walked to Lake Superior from the Four Directions (2011 Mother Earth Water Walk) and the entire length of the Mississippi River (2013 Mississippi River Water Walk). Without support from people all over the world, those walks would not have been possible. Our perks are a way to show you how much you are appreciated, and we have some cool ones this year! 
$10:  A thank you on
Nibi Walk’s web site (if you want to remain anonymous, please let us know when
you donate)
$25:  Above, plus a
personal e mail with photos of the walk on the very first day
$50:  Above, plus the
Ohio River Water Walk original poster
$100: Above, plus a set of four greeting cards of original
artwork by Sharon Day, shipped by June 30, 2014
$250: Above, plus a fine art print of Dana Tiger’s Nibi Walk
painting on archival cotton paper, shipped by June 30, 2014
$500: Above, plus a fine art print of Amy Cordova’s Ohio River
Walk painting on cotton archival paper, shipped by June 30, 2014
$1000: Above, plus Nibi Walk music CD upon its release,
shipped by December 1, 2014
$5000:  Above, plus a
talk in your town by one of the water walkers (within the United States), by December
1, 2014.

story:
(日本語バージョンは英語の後にあります。Japanese version is after English.)


Hi, we are Momoko Kobayashi and Tomoko Mitsuya and both live in Japan. 

We are  volunteers at OrcaLab (www.orcalab.org; www.orca-live.net/community) which is known internationally as an orca research station located on Hanson Island in British Columbia, Canada. We keep going back to OrcaLab every summer to help Dr. Paul Spong and Helena Symonds. The summer is the busiest season because the orcas known as Northern residents come back to the area from the north. OrcaLab has a hydrophone network that allows us to keep track of the orcas in the area without chasing them. The most important work the volunteers do is the recording of the orcas calls. The recording needs some technique and training, so we teach the new volunteers at the beginning of the summer. It will be the 17th summer that Tomoko has been to Orcalab and 6th for Momoko. Tomoko has been brushing up on her skills of  recording and analyzing the orca calls.  Now she is the most trusted volunteer. Momoko has been helping them with her photo skills. For the rest of the year, we work as part-timers to earn money to travel to Canada. It's getting more difficult to get enough money to travel because of the economy situation in Japan and the depreciation of JPY.  So we would like you to help us continue volunteering by helping with our plane and bus tickets and the groceries for the stay. It will be a great help. We love orcas, nature, Paul and Helena. Please let us keep helping them!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $3,000 each. It will cover our cost of transportation, hotels in Vancouver, the food for the stay and perks.

Every donation will go to the trip and be greatly appreciated.

We have lots of perks you might be interested in!

  • A thank you message via email from Tomoko & Momoko - 10 USD
  • A hand written ORIGINAL post card (printed by Canon SELPHY CP910) from OrcaLab - 30 USD
  • 3 landscape photos taken by Momoko Kobayashi by Canon 7D with 100-400mm lends - 55 USD
  • A cool Japanese style orca T-shirt designed by a block print artist Hide Futakawa - 100 USD
  • Best recordings of orca calls of 2014 selected by Tomoko Mitsuya - 100 USD
  • Best recordings of orca calls of 2015 selected by Tomoko Mitsuya - 100 USD
  • 5 nature photos (wild animals, landscapes) taken by Momoko Kobayashi by Canon 7D with 100-400mm lends - 100 USD
  • 5 orca photos taken by Momoko Kobayashi by Canon 7D with 100-400mm lends - 100 USD
  • Sound set (including best recordings of orca calls both of 2014 and 2015) - 195 USD
  • 10 best photography of 2015 taken by Momoko Kobayashi by Canon 7D with 100-400mm lends - 195 USD
  • Many thanks box (including all perks) - 500 USD


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help us by sharing this. Please tell your friends about our campaign!

Thank you so much!


Japanese version

はじめまして。私たちは三屋智子と小林桃子と申します。私たちは毎年夏、カナダのブリティッシュ・コロンビア州にあるオルカラボ(www.orcalab.org; www.orca-live.net/community)というシャチを長年研究している研究所でボランティアをしています。夏はオルカラボにとって最も忙しい季節で、ノーザン・レジデントと呼ばれる個体群のシャチが鮭を食べに研究所の近くの海域にやってきます。この個体群のシャチは家族ごとに特徴的な方言があります。水中マイクから聞こえて来るシャチの方言を聞き分けることによってオルカラボでは物理的にシャチを追いかけることなく彼らの動きを追跡することができます。ボランティアの主な仕事はこのシャチの声を録音することです。この録音作業には経験が必要で、夏の始めに新人のボランティアのトレーニングをするのも私たちの仕事の一つです。三屋にとっては今年で17年目、小林にとっては6年目の夏です。三屋は長年の経験によりシャチの方言の聞き分けを習得し、今ではポール博士と奥さんのヘレナさんに最も信頼されています。小林は写真の技術でシャチの個体識別などで博士夫妻を助けています。二人とも日本にいる間はアルバイトをしてカナダへの渡航費用を稼いでいますが、円安の影響もあって苦しい状況です。そこでみなさんのお力をお貸し願いたいのです。目標金額は1人3000ドル（約36万円）、合計6000ドル（約72万円）です。この金額が集まれば、カナダまでの渡航費、バンクーバーのホテル代、オルカラボ近くの島までのバス代、夏の間の食料費、寄付の特典にかかる費用をまかなうことができます。いただいた寄付金は全てオルカラボへの渡航費に充てさせていただきます。これからもオルカラボでボランティアを続けられるよう、お力添えをお願いいたします。

寄付していただいたお礼にTシャツやシャチの美しい声を録音したレコーディング、オルカラボで撮影した写真などをご用意しております。詳しくはリストをご覧ください。

寄付が難しい場合でも、このキャンペーンをお友達やお知り合いの方とシェアしていただけるだけでも大変な助けになります。よろしくお願いいたします。

寄付の方法はこちらで説明しています。

story:
Bref résumé

Le Huitième Feu est une coopérative de solidarité formée le 7 janvier 2013 par des membres allochtones, autochtones et métis de la communauté de Clova et compte maintenant 46 membres.

Elle regroupe des spécialistes dans des domaines à la fois variées et complémentaires : tourisme, foresterie, produits forestiers non-ligneux, éducation, cartographie et sciences environnementales.

L’un des enjeux du Huitième Feu  est de diversifier les potentiels de mise en valeur de Clova et de ses environs grâce à des projets concrets, viables et novateurs dans une approche de développement durable auto-régulé et de respect des valeurs des Premières Nations.

Laboratoire d’un développement rural alternatif durable, qui tient compte des dimensions économiques, sociales et écologiques, la coopérative souhaite améliorer le lien communauté-territoire dans une perspective d’économie collaborative et adaptative.

Dans sa volonté de promouvoir les richesses du territoire, le Huitième Feu souhaite afficher un niveau de prélèvement forestier respectueux en assurant la conservation et la protection des écosystèmes.


Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

La Coopérative de Solidarité du Huitième Feu désire partager l’un des joyaux de la forêt boréale à un large public. Il s’agit des champignons. Elle profite de plusieurs atouts : d’une part une connaissance étendue grâce à son réseau d’experts mycologues et d’autre part d’une bonne situation de production pour pouvoir se lancer dans la commercialisation des champignons forestiers.  Mais pour pouvoir finaliser son projet, elle a besoin d’investir dans un atelier de conditionnement. Cet outil  lui permettrait de prendre en charge l’ensemble des activités nécessaires à la commercialisation de champignons, de la cueillette au conditionnement.

Voici les différents éléments que nous souhaiterions acquérir :

  • Chauffe-eau
  • Compresseur
  • Nettoyeur à pression
  •  Chauffage
  •  Ventilation
  •  Instruments de contrôle
  • Ameublement de base avec tray
  • Réfrigérateur

L'impact

La Coopérative de Solidarité du Huitième Feu a, depuis sa création, démontrée sa détermination et son envie de promouvoir le territoire tout en mettant en avant les Premières Nations.
Elle profite ainsi du soutien de la municipalité de La Tuque et des communautés autochtones locales du Nitaskinan.

D'autres façons d'aider

N'hésitez pas à participer à notre projet. Vous pouvez également nous soutenir via les réseaux sociaux:
Notre site internet: Le Huitième Feu
Notre page Facebook: Page Facebook Huitième Feu

story: Hey my name is Jared and I'm in the Millikan Middle School Civics Academy. I'm trying to get a tree planted for the new LA River Green-way in Studio City California. Please help me get there. THanks!

story:
The Goal 

My name is Emily Hunter, I am a young environmental activist that is fundraising to join her next campaign. DeforestAction: Project Borneo is a global action campaign driven by young people to helprestore the Borneo rainforest, save Orangutans and build a sustainable local economy. 


The project is led by acclaimed conservationist Dr. Willie Smits and Orangutan Outreach. If I achieve my fundraising goal, I will get the opportunity to participate in DeforestAction on the ground in Indonesia later this summer!


I have already raised $5,000 to sponsor 2,500 square meters of land to be protected for 100 years in Borneo. My next goal is to raise $2,000 to send me to join DeforestACTION. All proceeds raised go directly to airfare and the necessary gear I will need. Please help send me to Borneo so I can help make a difference!


The Activist

Over the last eight years, Emily Hunter has been an environmental activist tackling global crises. Emily is the daughter of Greenpeace's founding president, Robert Hunter, and first women to save a whale, Bobbi Hunter. 

Emily herself has worked on numerous environmental campaigns: She has battled on the high seas of Antarctica to save whales with Sea Shepherd; she was taken hostage in her attempt to protect the Galapagos Islands from illegal poaching; put a spotlight on the Canadian tar sands (the second largest oil project next to Saudi Arabia) with a TV documentary; stood on the protest front-lines at the Copenhagen climate summit;  and recently published her first book called The Next Eco-Warriors, a collection of short stories by the next generation of eco-activists. 

Currently, she works as a freelance reporter for IMPACT, a TV-documentary series on MTV News Canada, covering environmental and social justice issues that affect generation Y. DeforestACTION is all her passions in one - climate justice, animal rights and media as a tool for change! 

The Impact

The forest of the world are disappearing fast. If we don't do something soon, they will be destroyed, taking away the habitat of orangtuans and advancing climate change. 


In Indonesia alone, a forest the size of 300 football fields is being cut down every hour - to make way for palm oil plantations (product used in cooking oils, cosmetics, cleaning products & biofuelds). Currently, half of the annual global tropical timber comes from Borneo. Some estimate, the Borneo rainforest (the oldest rainforest on Earth) will be gone in a matter of a few decades. 

Deforestation accounts for roughly a quarter of all greenhouse gas emisions, according the United Nations. Stopping deforestation is an urgent priority to ensure life on this planet can continue. 


To learn more about deforestation:

  •  Check out this 8 min documentary Of Forests & Men, narrated by Edward Norton.

story:
We're raising funds for an e-book about Enbridge Northern Gateway, Kinder Morgan, and the efforts to bring tar sands oil from Alberta to British Columbia's beautiful, wild coast.

The first draft is already finished, and it's a very comprehensive book, which covers everything from:

  • a historical timeline of these pipelines projects
  • explainers about Enbridge, China's Sinopec, and the major companies involved 
  • powerful testimonies from First Nations against the pipeline
  • useful, up-to-date maps and charts 
  • key political players involved in promoting oil sands exports to Asia 
  • potential environmental damage caused by oil spills

The eBook is an initiative of the Vancouver Observer, winner of the 2012 Excellence in Journalism award from the Canadian Journalism Foundation.  The book is edited by sustainability writer Carrie Saxifrage, one of Canada's leading environmental spokespeople. Contributors to the book include Alexis Stoymenoff, Barry Saxifrage and David P. Ball.

Why are we doing this?

Oil companies like Enbridge are spending millions of dollars on advertising its pipeline projects, saying it will bring jobs and boost economy. But that's not the whole picture: Enbridge doesn't have the funds to cover the cost of a major oil spill, and the pipeline will attract hundreds of giant oil tankers to the BC coast every year.

In January, there was a poll showing that 42 per cent of British Columbians support the project even though 55 per cent were not familiar with the project. While more people know about it now, there's still a troubling amount of people who don't know what these projects imply for BC.

In May, Enbridge Northern Gateway Commercial VP said those opposed to the pipeline "don't know the issues".

Well, we're trying to make sure people know the issues, and the risks. News coverage is ephemeral and scattered, but a book allows people to get all their facts in one place.  

And when oil spills happen, they're long-term. As we reported in April, the damage on communities and wildlife continues, even 23 years later. 

Please help us get the book out to people so they can make an informed decision and not just leave things a handful of authorities. This is what our democracy's all about. 

And the decision around these pipelines will determine what kind of BC we leave behind for future generations.

The first draft is already finished, and it's a very comprehensive book, which covers everything from:

a historical timeline of these pipelines projects
explainers about Enbridge, China's Sinopec, and the major companies involved 
powerful testimonies from First Nations against the pipeline
useful, up-to-date maps and charts 
key political players involved in promoting oil sands exports to Asia 
potential environmental damage caused by oil spills
The eBook is an initiative of the Vancouver Observer, winner of the 2012 Excellence in Journalism award from the Canadian Journalism Foundation.  The book is edited by sustainability writer Carrie Saxifrage, one of Canada's leading environmental spokespeople. Contributors to the book include Alexis Stoymenoff, Barry Saxifrage and David P. Ball.
Why are we doing this?
Oil companies like Enbridge are spending millions of dollars on advertising its pipeline projects, saying it will bring jobs and boost economy. But that's not the whole picture: Enbridge doesn't have the funds to cover the cost of a major oil spill, and the pipeline will attract hundreds of giant oil tankers to the BC coast every year.
In January, there was a poll showing that 42 per cent of British Columbians support the project even though 55 per cent were not familiar with the project. While more people know about it now, there's still a troubling amount of people who don't know what these projects imply for BC.
In May, Enbridge Northern Gateway Commercial VP said those opposed to the pipeline "don't know the issues".
Well, we're trying to make sure people know the issues, and the risks. News coverage is ephemeral and scattered, but a book allows people to get all their facts in one place.  
And when oil spills happen, they're long-term. As we reported in April, the damage on communities and wildlife continues, even 23 years later. 
Please help us get the book out to people so they can make an informed decision and not just leave things a handful of authorities. This is what our democracy's all about. 
And the decision around these pipelines will determine what kind of BC we leave behind for future generations.

story:
Project Polar Bear

 Project Polar Bear: Helping To Preserve Sensitive Arctic Environments Using Innovative, Award-Winning Green Technology

Each year, thousands of new oil wells are drilled in environmentally sensitive areas. When these wells are finished, a gasoline or diesel generator is installed to provide electrical power to instruments monitoring pressure, flow and other parameters in the completed well. These generators run continuously for 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year – and each generator dumps about 2 pounds of carbon into the environment for every gallon of gasoline or diesel that they consume. With close to 50,000 remote wells being finished per year in environmentally sensitive areas in Canada, United States and Russia, there are millions pounds of carbon poured into the atmosphere with each day that they operate, and that amount is produced every hour of every day, all year long.

Well drillers and operators have tried to find alternatives to this wholesale dump of harmful greenhouse gases into the atmosphere – but Arctic conditions are some of the most extreme of environments on Earth. Well operators have few choices when it comes to producing electric power for their completed wells. They’ve tried solar cells, but with the sunshine almost non-existent for months during the winter, not much power can be produced. What little can be produced must be stored to batteries, and the cold freezes these batteries and renders them useless.  Another “green” technology is the use of windmills, but during winter months, there is either too little wind or too much wind – but rarely is there “just the right amount” to produce power for the completed well. Of course, windmills must also store their power to batteries, and batteries don’t survive Arctic winters. When a battery freezes and cracks, it spills acids and harmful chemicals into the environment, and causes irreparable damage to the sensitive ecosystem beneath the generator. Finally, fuel cells have been tried, but fuel cells, while being extremely expensive are also extremely sensitive to low temperatures – and during the winter, it’s not unusual to see -60°F (-51°C) – far below where fuel cells operate efficiently (or at all). Unfortunately, oil well operators must rely on gasoline and diesel engine power generators - and because of the harsh environment, they must also maintain them regularly because of the effects of the harsh winter on piston motors. With gas or diesel generators, there’s always the danger of a spill of oil, gasoline, diesel or coolant into the environment, making their widespread use that much more damaging.

Nitro-Turbodyne has created an alternative to these gross polluters with its Remote Instrumentation Power Generation Unit (RIPGU). The RIPGU uses a patented, revolutionary device known as a Micro Flash-Expansion Turbine (MFET) as the power generator. 

75mm MFET

The MFET has only 1 moving part and is maintenance-free, so it doesn’t use grease or oil for lubrication like a piston motor does, nor does it require any coolant…because it doesn’t burn any fuel at all. Instead, the MFET direct-injects, then flash-expands Liquid Nitrogen (LN2) within the turbine itself. LN2 flash-expands to 696 times its volume from liquid to gas. The turbine works this way: if the MFET pulls in 696 cubic inches of air and direct-injects 1 cubic inch of LN2, once the LN2 expands, you will get a total of almost 1400 cubic inches of gas coming out of the back of the little turbine at higher speed and pressure than the air that it took in. LN2 is used because it is made from the air that we breathe – since our air is almost 80% nitrogen, LN2 can be made inexpensively and is 100% renewable. No one controls the stock of air that we breathe, so the fuel price can only go down as competition to produce it goes up. LN2 is also very common and available in large quantities at oil well sites, and is used to “finish” an oil well as it is completed.  LN2 is commonly available for about $0.09 per liter (or about $0.34 per gallon). Best of all, since it’s made from air, once it’s flash-expanded in the MFET, it’s returned to the air without any combustion, oxidation or heat. Since there is no heat produced, it doesn’t produce greenhouse gases, carbon-laden by-products or anything that harms the environment. It’s a perfect fuel – inexpensive, renewable, and absolutely NO emission of greenhouse gases…or any other chemical that can harm life in an environmentally sensitive area.

Using LN2 is a perfect fuel for sensitive environments - since there is no combustion of volatile fuels or gases, the MFET operates quietly, continuously and efficiently – and without damaging the environment or harming an already threatened ecosystem. Your contribution to this Indiegogo project not only helps the environment in a very big way, but it also helps to further research and development into the use of the MFET for power generation and other applications. Better yet - you get some pretty cool swag for helping to save the Arctic, too.

What’s Project Polar Bear’s Goal?

Our goal is to eventually replace each and every gasoline and diesel power generator in the Arctic. Since we can’t gain acceptance from all users immediately, we’ll starting by replacing 12 generators in 12 locations above the Arctic Circle – at completed wells – for the duration of an entire winter (typically September through April) - the most extreme weather condition for any generator. We’ll use these 12 units to demonstrate and prove the ability of the RIPGU to operate without carbon emissions, noxious gases, harmful fuels and excess heat – as well as the RIPGUs ability to provide clean, renewable power generation for months at a time without the need for maintenance or without harming the delicate environment or ecosystem of the Arctic.

RIPGU Enclosure Drawing

The technology behind the MFET has won 2 international awards in clean tech competitions; we’ve demonstrated that we can produce clean, maintenance free and quiet electrical power that will revolutionize the renewable energy field. Based on data gathered from the operation of the MFET, improvements are continually being made to increase its efficiency and to allow it to be operated in the harshest of environments.

During the time that they’re in operation, each unit will be monitored continuously for LN2 consumption, oxygen levels, power output, temperature inside and outside the RIPGU, vibration, and other parameters that will be used to demonstrate the RIPGU as a clean and environmentally sound alternative to gasoline or diesel power generators. That data that we gather will also be used in the design of future MFET applications such as power generation for remote villages in undeveloped and under-developed countries, transportation and other applications where low-cost, quiet, renewable and environmentally friendly electricity is needed.

We currently have interest from several oil companies and operators of well sites and geophysical observation stations that are willing to deploy RIPGU in environmentally sensitive areas. We have executed an agreement with a consortium of universities to test two of our units for their possible use in geophysical observatories. Operation of the RIPGUs in a harsh Arctic environment will prove that replacing polluting, hot, maintenance intensive gasoline or diesel generators will be not only possible, but will allow operators of remote wells and observation stations to reduce their carbon footprint to zero, as well as remove heat and greenhouse gases from their production sites. Because RIPGUs simple, inexpensive and durable, we know that they will be adopted for widespread use to supply electrical power at most remote well sites and geophysical observatories throughout the world. Once in full production, RIPGUs will cost about $2000 per unit - about the same cost as the current gasoline or diesel generators that are in use, but with none of the pollution or harm to the environment.

With climate change having the most profound effect on the Arctic regions, it’s a logical place to start healing the environment by removing gross-polluting sources such as gasoline and diesel power generators at remote well sites. You can make a profound difference with your Indiegogo contribution -- and help to prove there is an alternative to polluting our pristine Arctic wilderness.

What’s Project Polar Bear’s Budget?

We are looking for a total of $76,000

  • $10,640 in fees collected by Indiegogo (9%) and Paypal (5%)
  • $29,800 will be used for materials, sensors and electronics for producing 12 RIPGUs
  • $7,520 will be used to build re-useable, carbon-neutral and green manufacturing fixtures for future RIPGU production. These fixtures will also be used to produce future RIPGUs.
  • $3,280 will be used to obtain outside machine-shop services for completing 12 RIPGU enclosures
  • $5,180 will be used to obtain operating permits to operate the RIPGUs from the United States
  • $9,480 will be used to provide shipping of the 12 units to Pt. Barrow, Alaska or Paulatuk, Northern Territories, Canada
  • $10,100 will be used to provide travel for our Engineers to support on-going Project Polar Bear operations during the winter deployment

For every $2,000 we raise above the requested amount, we’ll build another RIPGU and deploy it into the field – to help further reduce the amount of carbon that gasoline and diesel generators dump into our atmosphere.

Polar Bear Platinum Display    

Project Polar Bear website: http://www.nitroturbodyne.com/polarbear.html

Please be sure to visit us on Facebook athttps://www.facebook.com/groups/181647661944213/

Or on Twitter at http://twitter.com/#!/nitroturbodyne

story:
This July, 2000 young people are converging in Melbourne for Australia's largest ever climate summit, Power Shift 2013.

Power Shift is a 3 day summit that is going to be held in Melbourne, from the 13 till the 15th of July. It is a summit for young people run by young people. There will be a range of inspirational speakers like James Hansen, Tim Flannery and Samah Hadid. Plus the young people that attend will gain leadership experience and learn new skills for creating change.

With a federal election set for September, Power Shift is a chance for young people  to influence how ambitious the parties are with their policies.  Whether it be climate change, overseas aid or any other progressive issues, Power Shift is the place for young people to be.

The NSW branch of the Australian Youth Climate Coalition hope to send 300 people to Melbourne. There are already heaps of passionate and energetic people that want to go, but financially, are finding it difficult to afford. There is the cost of tickets, travel and accommodation to think about, which can all add up to over $300.

So we need your help! Any money that you donate will go directly to help a young person from NSW attend this transformative weekend, and help to put climate change on the election agenda.

$100 will buy someone a ticket for Power Shift.
$120 will help cover the cost of accommodation for one person.
$200 will get three people from Sydney to Melbourne and back!

Of course we're not asking just for these lump sums!  $5 and $10 are just as helpful and would help immensely.

So if you care about climate change or if you care about the outcome of this election, donate now to help get a young person to Power Shift and help change the game on climate!

If you're an international viewer, don't think this isn't for you! Australia is one of the highest emitters of greenhouse gases per capita. We are also one of the largest exporters of coal in the world. What happens this election is not just important for this country, but will change the very nature of the fossil fuel industry worldwide. Help us keep our dirty coal and gas in the ground and let's build a renewable energy future together!

You're welcome to come to the summit too - tickets and more info at: https://www.powershift.org.au/

story:
Short Summary

We are a new fraternity on the University of Iowa's campus with a focus in community service. Over the past three months, we have made tremendous strides in improving our sustainability by creating an Environmental Improvement position, becoming the first fraternity on campus to possess a recycling service, and are currently looking at methods to reduce our energy use. 
A large project we would like to begin soon would be creating a 16' by 36' garden along the side of our house, where we intend to grow produce for our meals. In addition to the produce garden, we possess a 18' by 68' plot of land in the front of our house, which we would like to fill with various flowers and shrubs. Our hope is that this would serve as a model for the rest of Greek Life on campus, as well as aid us in further improving our sustainability.

What We Need & What You Get

We are a new fraternity with a minimal budget, so all funding for the garden will derive from these donations. We are looking for materials to build a basic fence, gardening tools (shovels, trowels, rakes, etc.), seeds and fertilizer, and if funds permit, a composting bin.

Realistically, we estimate to only need about $250, but any additional funding will be saved and used for future expenditures (seeds, tool replacements, etc.). 

Aside from undying gratitude, we are looking to compensate you for your help.

Perks are as follows:

$1-$15: An email with our picture thanking you for your assistance.

$16-$30: A handwritten letter as well as a picture of us giving you a thumbs up.

$31-$50: We will make a video of us dramatically singing a song of your choice (Cannot guarantee the quality of the song).

$51+: We will air-mail you produce or tea from our garden when our first harvest takes place.


The Impact

We are the first fraternity on campus to be making efforts at sustainability improvement. As a result, we have begun to be exemplified by our campus' Greek Life Offices. We are hoping word will spread and other greek chapters will follow suit. This garden will allow for one more method through which we can improve our sustainability, as well as potentially serve as inspiration to others in the community. With your help, we can make our campus a little more Green.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, but would still like to help, there are two things you can do:

1. Spread the word. Share this page with friends or family who would be able to help our cause.

2. Donate tools/gardening supplies.


CONTACT INFO:

If you have any questions regarding our garden or fraternity, do not hesitate to email me at cartercranberg@yahoo.com.


Thank you again for taking the time to assist our cause.

story:
Remember the Wilcox Family? They're almost done.

Brett and David (father and son) are the first father-teen son team to run across America. David will be the 2nd youngest to accomplish this feat... completing before his 16th birthday. Kris and Olivia (mom and daughter) are the support crew, driving the truck and camper, planning the itinerary, cooking the food, and shooting the film. They began in California in January and are now in western Pennsylvania. They ran an Indiegogo campaign last winter, hoping for more than $40,000... but when they only raised $8000, they decided to go ahead anyway.

My name is Owen Kindig. I'm just a friend of the Wilcoxes from their home town of Sitka, Alaska. I believe in what they are trying to do ... to call attention to the terrible ecological dangers of GMOs and the pesticides they implant directly inside the DNA of the plants and animals and insects of our ecosystem.

In the last 180 days, the Wilcoxes have spent $166 a day on this crusade. They have attracted attention all across America, have been interviewed by newspapers and even Dan Rather Productions, and spoke at Monsanto Headquarters in St. Louis on May 24 -- not inside, of course, but across the street at the March Against Monsanto.

During that same period of time, the Monsanto company has spent $16,000 a day, just in its efforts to lobby the U.S. Congress.

What the Wilcox Family Needs

They need operating cash, and they need help in paying off the loans they have taken out to take this vital message across the United States. The different gift levels will spell out the costs they need to recoup.

What You Get

Depending on your contribution, you get the satisfaction of knowing you are making a difference in the struggle to defeat these industry giants and their government allies.

Every dollar this campaign raises (beyond the small percentage kept by indiegogo) will directly pay off the costs of the journey. At one time  a movie or book was hoped for as a by-product of the run. That seems unlikely at this point. Both Brett and Kris quit their jobs before the run began -- but the good news is that the health system where he worked has offered him his job back upon his return... so the family will have an income again when they get back to Sitka.

    The Impact

    In spite of their power in the halls of Congress and the courts, Monsanto and the other chemical companies who trade in environmental poison are going to lose in the long run. But the greatest joys come to those who work to fight and defeat these forces now, when real sacrifice and dedication are needed to warn our nation of these destructive, immediate perils.

      Risks & Challenges

      Power and money are on Monsanto's side. The only ones who love "terminator technology" are the ones who get their paycheck from it. There is a lot ridicule and conventional wisdom on the side of agribusiness and government. But in Vermont, the state has passed a GMO labeling law, and other states are considering the same. Monsanto is suing the state of Vermont but legal experts say the law and common sense are on the side of the people. The danger to bees is causing a major review of the poisons Monsanto and others use, which are linked to colony collapse disorder. In spite of the leading administrators of the Department of Agriculture being former Monsanto employees, scientists and activists and consumers are making a difference, slowing and even halting the spread of GMOs in the United States... just as they have been halted in Europe.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute, please read about the topic, and speak up at every opportunity. Write an encouraging email to the Wilcoxes. Go to a March Against Monsanto rally. Carry a sign and talk to your neighbor. 

      Get the Buycott app, so that you can use your economic power to avoid buying the products that use GMO foods.

      Thank you for your support! Help the Wilcoxes finish strong!
