They ran an Indiegogo campaign last winter, hoping for more than $40,000... but when they only raised $8000, they decided to go ahead anyway.
My name is Owen Kindig. I'm just a friend of the Wilcoxes from their home town of Sitka, Alaska. I believe in what they are trying to do ... to call attention to the terrible ecological dangers of GMOs and the pesticides they implant directly inside the DNA of the plants and animals and insects of our ecosystem.
In the last 180 days, the Wilcoxes have spent $166 a day on this crusade. They have attracted attention all across America, have been interviewed by newspapers and even Dan Rather Productions, and spoke at Monsanto Headquarters in St. Louis on May 24 -- not inside, of course, but across the street at the March Against Monsanto.
During that same period of time, the Monsanto company has spent $16,000 a day, just in its efforts to lobby the U.S. Congress.   What the Wilcox Family Needs
They need operating cash, and they need help in paying off the loans they have taken out to take this vital message across the United States. The different gift levels will spell out the costs they need to recoup. 
What You Get Depending on your contribution, you get the satisfaction of knowing you are making a difference in the struggle to defeat these industry giants and their government allies.
Every dollar this campaign raises (beyond the small percentage kept by indiegogo) will directly pay off the costs of the journey. At one time  a movie or book was hoped for as a by-product of the run. That seems unlikely at this point. Both Brett and Kris quit their jobs before the run began -- but the good news is that the health system where he worked has offered him his job back upon his return... so the family will have an income again when they get back to Sitka.

  The Impact In spite of their power in the halls of Congress and the courts, Monsanto and the other chemical companies who trade in environmental poison are going to lose in the long run. But the greatest joys come to those who work to fight and defeat these forces now, when real sacrifice and dedication are needed to warn our nation of these destructive, immediate perils.

  Risks & Challenges Power and money are on Monsanto's side. The only ones who love "terminator technology" are the ones who get their paycheck from it. There is a lot ridicule and conventional wisdom on the side of agribusiness and government. But in Vermont, the state has passed a GMO labeling law, and other states are considering the same. Monsanto is suing the state of Vermont but legal experts say the law and common sense are on the side of the people. The danger to bees is causing a major review of the poisons Monsanto and others use, which are linked to colony collapse disorder. In spite of the leading administrators of the Department of Agriculture being former Monsanto employees, scientists and activists and consumers are making a difference, slowing and even halting the spread of GMOs in the United States... just as they have been halted in Europe.
Other Ways You Can Help

 If you can't contribute, please read about the topic, and speak up at every opportunity. Write an encouraging email to the Wilcoxes. Go to a March Against Monsanto rally. Carry a sign and talk to your neighbor. 
Get the Buycott app, so that you can use your economic power to avoid buying the products that use GMO foods.
Thank you for your support! Help the Wilcoxes finish strong!

story:
Most people aren't aware of the risks posed by Northern Gateway.

Help us reach them.


Last December we raised $8,602 to publish our independent analysis of the risks of Northern Gateway. We built a website, published reports, and developed infographics and animations to explain our arguments.

Now we need to make sure this content is seen, and not just by people who are already engaged. We plan to buy advertising to promote our message, to ensure that it reaches a broader audience that might not otherwise be exposed to this issue.


What we do: 

Concerned Professional Engineers independently investigates the engineering aspects of megaprojects like the Northern Gateway pipeline.  


Picking up where the regulatory process leaves off: scientific analysis of megaprojects.


The National Energy Board's Joint Review Panel (NEB JRP) was supposed to conduct an independent, thorough, and science-based investigation of the Northern Gateway Project. We participated in the official JRP process and tried to get answers to our many questions and concerns from Enbridge and their consultants. No answers were provided and we were again disappointed when the Joint Review Panel released their report with its 209 conditions.

There are many, many areas where critical risk factors are not justified and are backed up merely with assumptions. The Joint Review Panel, despite it's mandate, was comfortable with trusting the assumptions of Northern Gateway and their consultants. We weren't. That's why we started CPE, and that's why, in December 2013, we raised $8,602 to build our website and start publishing infographics and animations explaining the issues.


Our goal: stop preaching to the choir

Now we want to take the next step.  We want to reach people who are outside of our social network, who are outside of your social network, and who wouldn't otherwise be exposed to information from the other side of the argument.  We want to reach people who, for whatever reason, are either unaware of the risks posed by this project, who presume the regulators must be doing a sufficient job, who have only been exposed to advertising by Enbridge, or those who are just too busy to research the issue on their own.


Why we need money: advertising

To date we have relied only on organic (unpaid) growth to spread our message.  While we would prefer to continue with organic growth only, we understand that social networks often follow political and ideological lines, and organic growth among people who support our message will only go so far.  So how can we reach our target audience?

We believe the best way to do this is through advertising, and advertising costs money.  We plan to use the funds raised to promote our message on social and other media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Youtube.

We also need to continue generating content that makes the details of our analysis accessible to a broader audience.  And we need to generate new content to keep up with developments, as they occur. 


How we'll spend the money

Advertising: we plan to purchase advertising and promotion on a number of social and other media platforms, including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube.  Depending on how much we raise, we may also try to purchase radio advertising.

New media: we've received great feedback on the content we've generated so far and we'd like to create more, both for existing arguments and in response to developments as they occur.

In order to achieve our goals, we are hiring local (British Columbian) web and social media talent.  We believe in paying these people a fair wage for their excellent work, and that's why we're asking for your support.


About our group

Dr. Ricardo O. Foschi, P.Eng, Professor Emeritus, UBC

Dr. Ricardo O. Foschi is Emeritus Professor of Civil Engineering at the University of British Columbia. He holds graduate degrees (Master and Ph.D) in Applied Mechanics from Stanford University, California. His areas of specialization are probabilistic methods in engineering, including reliability and performance-based design under reliability constraints, particularly in earthquake engineering. He has contributed to many projects in which probabilistic applications were central. Among them: ice loadings and iceberg impacts for the Hibernia and Terranova oil platforms; ice loadings and geotechnical implications for the Confederation Bridge in Prince Edward Island; collision with bridge piers for several bridges across the Fraser River in British Columbia; and combination of earthquake loadings and vessel collisions for movable bridges in Victoria, BC.

Dr. Foschi was also responsible for the reliability calibration of the Canadian CSA Code for wood construction, and has been a member of the ISO Committee for Reliability of Arctic Structures.

Dr. Foschi is a Fellow of the Canadian Society for Civil Engineering, and has received several awards, among them: the Marcus Wallenberg International Prize for contributions to reliability and mathematical models for wood, and the Canadian Society for Civil Engineering’s Gzowsky and Leipholz medals.


Peter S. Hatfield, P.Eng

Peter Hatfield completed his B.Sc. studies in Naval Architecture at the University of Durham, U.K. Presently retired and acting as a part time consultant, he has accumulated vast experience in design office management; design project management; concept and final design of commercial, government, fishing, passenger and special purpose vessels; arctic petroleum exploration vessels; production equipment design; studies and reports regarding marine vessel and equipment operations; stability reports; vessel surveys; legal consultation, expert witness in court cases involving marine projects and operations.

Early work by Peter Hatfield included assignments with John Brandlmayr Ltd., Naval Architects, Vancouver, B.C. (1958 – 1961) and Sparkman & Stephens Inc., Naval Architects, New York, N.Y., U.S.A. (1961-63). This work was followed, in 1963, by a short term assignment with the Food & Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations, on the design and construction of fishing vessels in Thailand.

From 1969 to 1973 Peter was Partner in Cove, Hatfield and Company Ltd., North Vancouver, B.C., as Naval architect responsible for design projects such as tugs, barges, fishing vessels, special purpose craft; general marine consulting.

As President of Peter S. Hatfield Ltd. (PHL), Naval Architects, Marine Engineers & Marine Consultants, Vancouver, BC., from 1973 to 2004, he has been responsible for general administration of all consulting activities both domestic and international, new business development, joint venture management, quality of Company work and client satisfaction, direct supervision and coordination of office projects and staff.

From August 2004 to July 2006 Peter also acted as Senior Consultant, BMT Fleet Technology Limited, following their acquisition of PHL in 2004.

Peter was awarded the Council of Marine Carriers Legacy Award in 2011 for services to the West Coast Towboat Industry.


Brian Gunn, P.Eng

Brian Gunn is a retired Professional Engineer. He graduated with a BASc (civil engineering) from UBC in 1962 and received his P.Eng in 1965.  Brian’s engineering work experience began in 1963 with construction supervision for Canadian Comstock of the CN Mt Jarvis Aerial Tram to service a trans-Canada microwave Network. From 1965 to 1985 Brian worked on small and large materials handling projects as a project manager for Swan Wooster Engineering, both in Canada and overseas. After Swan Wooster, Brian worked for 5 years with Westshore Terminals (WST) as their engineering and maintenance manager for the Roberts Bank coal handling facility in Tsawwassen, BC. He ended his full time engineering career working as WST’s project manager for the expansion phase 2b for 2.5 years as an independent consultant from 1990 – 1993.

In 1989 Brian started the Big Bar Guest Ranch in the Cariboo country of BC. During that period of time Brian became active in representing the members of the Cariboo, Chilcotin, Coast Tourism Association and the BC Guest Ranch Association on issues to do with tourism, particularly land use conflicts with other industries.

In 1998 Brian left the ranch and became the marketing manager and consultant on engineering matters for Strathcona Park Lodge and Outdoor Education Center located on Vancouver Island.

In 1999 Brian was instrumental in the formation of the BC the Wilderness Tourism Association (WTA), representing nature-based tourism operators on land and marine use concerns. Brian was elected president of WTA in 1999 and remained in that role until 2012.  He is now Past President and is still active in advocacy work.


Chris J. Peter, P.Eng

Chris’s area of expertise lies in energy efficient design for cold climates. He has been actively involved in building systems energy modelling since development of the early software programs in the 1980’s.

Upon graduation in Engineering from the University of Toronto in 1981, Chris was one of five energy conservation engineers carrying out energy retrofits to school buildings for the Government of Alberta. His territory covered the northern third of the Province and during this time he designed extensive building envelope, controls, heating system upgrades and electrical modifications for 30 schools. 

In 1985, Chris joined the Government of the N.W.T. as a mechanical engineer in Iqaluit/Frobisher Bay and was involved in a wide variety of capital and operation and maintenance projects including water storage tank and distribution systems, district heating systems, government office buildings and heating system service specifications for Arctic municipalities. 

In 1987, Chris became project engineer with Stantec Engineering in Yellowknife. He undertook heating system energy metering, recreational facility, airport site works, school and health care facility, and office building renovations and design of bulk fuel storage facilities and firehalls. 

In 1989, Chris became project engineer with Williams Engineering in Edmonton, and was responsible for the mechanical engineering design on a variety of schools, airports, office buildings, health care facilities and district heating systems, the majority of which required specialized systems due to their remote location. 

Since 1994, Chris has been principal of C.J.Peter Associates Engineering, a mechanical engineering firm in Prince George, B.C. specializing in design and modelling of energy efficient mechanical systems and facilities throughout northern B.C.

story:
We're humbled and grateful here at Idaho Rivers United for the outpouring of support we received during our Indiegogo campaign, which concluded September 25, 2014. More than 200 of you helped exceed our $25,000 goal and raised $27,600 to fight industrialization of the Lochsa and Clearwater rivers, and Wild and Scenic Rivers across America.

From the bottom of our free-flowing rivers, thank you!

If you're new to this issue, please read on to learn about big oil's attempts to turn two of America's original Wild and Scenic rivers into industrial thoroughfares. This work is ongoing, and you can still donate to Idaho Rivers United at idahorivers.org.

The Fighting Goliath story

The goal of this campaign is to protect the beautiful Lochsa and Clearwater rivers of north central Idaho from the oil industry and tar sands-bound “megaload” traffic on U.S. Highway 12. These two rivers were among the first protected by the federal Wild & Scenic Rivers Act in 1968. 

The outcome of this campaign will have profound impacts on the future of these watersheds, and on the management of Wild & Scenic Rivers across the U.S.

The Clearwater, Lochsa and the landscapes around them are threatened today by an oil industry fixated on transforming U.S. Highway 12 (a winding, two-lane road that runs along and through the river canyons) into a permanent ‘high and wide’ transportation route for space shuttle-sized, road-closing, recreation-stopping, scenery-destroying megaloads of mining equipment. The industry hopes to transport these loads from ports on the Snake River near Lewiston, Idaho, overland to the Canadian tar sands mines and other fossil fuel hotbeds east of the Rockies.

Among our nation’s natural treasures, the Lochsa and Clearwater rivers are real gems. They boast crystal clear waters, towering cedars, steep canyon walls and moss-covered rocks. In addition to their beauty, the rivers are significant nationally because:

  • They offer world-class destinations for whitewater boaters, anglers, hikers, bikers, campers, backpackers, skiers, wildlife watchers and hunters.
  • They provide critical habitat for federally protected salmon and wild steelhead.
  • They are home to important populations of native westslope cutthroat trout, bull trout, elk, bears, wolves, nesting harlequin ducks and songbirds.
  • They are rich in history — the river canyons provided travel corridors for the Nez Perce Indians for centuries, and for the Lewis and Clark expedition in 1805.
  • They lie at the heart of the Nez Perce homeland and include sacred tribal sites.

Megaloads threaten those values — and the health and integrity of America's entire Wild & Scenic River system. If we lose the Lochsa and Clearwater, which river is next? If we lose the Lochsa and Clearwater, what does Wild and Scenic mean for other protected rivers?

Together, we can convince the U.S. Forest Service to implement permanent protections for two of America’s original Wild & Scenic Rivers. With your help, we can stop big oil from converting these gems into an industrial shipping route for the tar sands mines.

Please watch our video, and please support this important campaign today!

IRU is Idaho's only river-specific conservation group

Idaho Rivers United is a result-driven, campaign-oriented, non-profit conservation group formed in 1990 to help citizens defend the rivers they love. Since that time we’ve stopped construction of over 18 unnecessary and destructive dams, led grassroots campaigns to protect and designate federal Wild & Scenic Rivers, and have been a driving force in the national campaign to save Columbia and Snake River salmon from extinction. 
Today, IRU has 3,500 members, 14 active volunteer directors, and a staff of four full-time and three half-time river activists. Our annual budget is small, but diverse, including some foundation funding, member and individual contributions, business support and income from events, such as chartered river trips. IRU’s mission is to protect and restore the rivers of Idaho. We achieve our goals using a mix of direct advocacy, education, grassroots organizing and citizen involvement, collaboration and, when necessary, litigation. Learn more at www.idahorivers.org.

About the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act of 1968

The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act was passed by Congress and signed into law by President Lyndon Johnson in October 1968. The intent of the Act was to protect rivers in their free-flowing state, and to prevent the degradation of natural, scenic, recreational, cultural, historic and other values identified at the time of designation. The Lochsa and Middle Fork of the Clearwater (along with their sister river, the Selway) were among the first eight designations under the Act.

Today, the National System protects 12,598 miles of 203 rivers in 38 states and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico; this is less than one-quarter of one percent of the nation's rivers. By comparison, more than 75,000 large dams across the country have modified at least 600,000 miles, or about 17%, of American rivers.

The U.S. Forest Service has the authority and the responsibility to protect the Lochsa and Clearwater Wild & Scenic Rivers. The agency’s refusal so far to ban megaloads from the protected river corridor has put the integrity of the entire Wild & Scenic Rivers System in jeopardy. 

Campaign Background

The oil industry and their contractors began their quest to turn the Clearwater-Lochsa Wild & Scenic River corridor into a permanent, “high and wide” transportation route for tar sands bound 'megaloads' in 2008. Originally, much of the super-sized equipment was to be manufactured in Asia, shipped to Snake River ports and then overland through our river corridors enroute to Alberta’s tar sands.

Engulfing both lanes of winding, rural U.S. Highway 12, megaloads stand up to three stories tall, 30-feet wide, are longer than a football field and weigh up to 1 million pounds. With hopes of moving hundreds of megaloads through the Cleawater-Lochsa river canyons, a steady stream of megaloads and their convoys would pose safety hazards for residents and travelers, block access for recreation, disrupt wildlife, and destroy the rivers aesthetic, spiritual and cultural values.

Megaloads have no place in America’s Wild & Scenic River corridors.

Idaho Rivers United has been fighting the ‘megaload’ battle since 2010. In 2012, our group and our allies, including the Nez Perce Tribe, filed a lawsuit to stop Canada’s Imperial Oil (an Exxon-Mobil subsidiary) from using the rivers for hundreds of loads. Favoring IRU’s position, the court placed megaload-regulating authority in the hands of the Forest Service. Sadly, in August 2013 another megaload — this one owned by General Electric and bound for the tar sands — traveled through the river corridors. Despite protests by the Nez Perce Tribe and IRU members, the Forest Service took no action to stop the loads.

IRU and the Tribe went back to federal court and obtained an injunction blocking megaload traffic until permanent rules and restrictions can be developed and put in place. In August 2014 our organization, the Tribe and the USFS began court-supervised mediation to attempt to resolve the issues.

That means our work to win permanent protections is just beginning.

Mediation with the Forest Service will require considerable manpower, grassroots organizing, media work, travel and direct advocacy. We must make sure the Forest Service writes acceptable, legal and protective transportation regulations for the Wild & Scenic corridor and Nez Perce homeland. That won't be easy. So far the agency has seemed reluctant to buck big oil.

What We Need and What You Get

Since 2010, this campaign has put significant stress on our small non-profit’s annual budget. Big oil and the U.S. Forest Service don’t face such financial constraints. That’s why we’re reaching out to you via Indiegogo. Short term we need $25,000 to keep our campaign running effectively. We’ll use your contribution help us:

  • Continue to build grassroots support for Wild & Scenic River protection — in the Clearwater-Lochsa region and across Idaho.
  • Tell this story nationally with an eye toward convincing the government to do the right thing for the Lochsa-Clearwater, and Wild & Scenic Rivers nationwide.
  • And, engage fully and effectively in court-supervised mediation with the Forest Service in an attempt to resolve our differences over the management of the Lochsa-Clearwater Wild & Scenic corridor.

As an incentive to secure your support, key business partners from the Lochsa-Clearwater region have offered several incredible perks for our donors. Check out the list at the side of this page!

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to making a financial contribution to our campaign, there are other ways that you can help:

  • Please write an email to Forest Service Chief Tom Tidwell (ttidwell@fs.fed.us) and tell him 1) it's the Forest Service's responsibility to protect America's first Wild & Scenic Rivers, 2) the Lochsa-Clearwater is too precious for big oil and 3) failing to act will threaten Wild & Scenic Rivers across the nation.
  • Also, share this campaign with your family and friends. We're working with our valued partners to engage river lovers around the nation, but a campaign like this is most effective when people like you spread the word. Please pass it along via email or via social media, and help us keep the Lochsa and Clearwater rivers megaload free for generations to come.

This issue has achieved national attention and has been featured by media outlets coast to coast:

Media converge includes this five-minute news report from from PBS affiliate This American Land:

Last, and far from least, thanks to our business partners who are supporting this work and helping to avert this threat to our Wild & Scenic Rivers:

values — and the health and integrity of America's entire Wild & Scenic
River system. If we lose the Lochsa and Clearwater, which river is next? If we
lose the Lochsa and Clearwater, what does Wild and Scenic mean for other
protected rivers?
Together, we can
convince the U.S. Forest Service to implement permanent protections for two of
America’s original Wild & Scenic Rivers. With your help, we can stop big oil from converting these gems into an industrial shipping route for the tar
sands mines.
Please watch our
video, and please support this important campaign today!
  IRU is Idaho's only river-specific conservation group 


Idaho
Rivers United is a result-driven, campaign-oriented, non-profit conservation
group formed in 1990 to help citizens defend the rivers they love. Since that
time we’ve stopped construction of over 18 unnecessary and destructive dams,
led grassroots campaigns to protect and designate federal Wild & Scenic
Rivers, and have been a driving force in the national campaign to save Columbia
and Snake River salmon from extinction. Today, IRU has 3,500 members, 14 active
volunteer directors, and a staff of four full-time and three half-time river
activists. Our annual budget is small, but diverse, including some foundation
funding, member and individual contributions, business support and income from
events, such as chartered river trips. IRU’s
mission is to protect and restore the rivers of Idaho. We achieve our
goals using a mix of direct advocacy, education, grassroots organizing and
citizen involvement, collaboration and, when necessary, litigation. Learn more
at www.idahorivers.org.
About the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act of 1968


The Wild and Scenic Rivers Act was passed by Congress and signed into law by President Lyndon Johnson in October 1968. The intent of the Act was to protect rivers in their free-flowing state, and to prevent the degradation of natural, scenic, recreational, cultural, historic and other values identified at the time of designation. The Lochsa and Middle Fork of the Clearwater (along with their
sister river, the Selway) were among the first eight designations under the
Act.
Today, the National System
protects 12,598 miles of 203 rivers in 38 states and the Commonwealth of Puerto
Rico; this is less than one-quarter of one percent of the nation's rivers. By
comparison, more than 75,000 large dams across the country have modified at
least 600,000 miles, or about 17%, of American rivers.
The U.S. Forest
Service has the authority and the responsibility to protect the Lochsa and
Clearwater Wild & Scenic Rivers. The agency’s refusal so far to ban
megaloads from the protected river corridor has put the integrity of the entire
Wild & Scenic Rivers System in jeopardy. 

Campaign Background



The oil industry and their contractors began
their quest to turn the Clearwater-Lochsa Wild & Scenic River corridor into
a permanent, “high and wide” transportation route for tar sands bound 'megaloads'
in 2008. Originally, much of the super-sized equipment was to be manufactured
in Asia, shipped to Snake River ports and then overland through our river
corridors enroute to Alberta’s tar sands.
Engulfing both lanes of winding, rural U.S.
Highway 12, megaloads stand up to three stories tall, 30-feet wide, are longer
than a football field and weigh up to 1 million pounds. With hopes of moving
hundreds of megaloads through the Cleawater-Lochsa river canyons, a steady
stream of megaloads and their convoys would pose safety hazards for residents
and travelers, block access for recreation, disrupt wildlife, and destroy the rivers
aesthetic, spiritual and cultural values.
Megaloads have no place in America’s Wild &
Scenic River corridors.

Idaho Rivers United has been fighting the
‘megaload’ battle since 2010. In 2012, our group and our allies, including the
Nez Perce Tribe, filed a lawsuit to stop Canada’s Imperial Oil (an Exxon-Mobil subsidiary)
from using the rivers for hundreds of loads. Favoring IRU’s position, the court
placed megaload-regulating authority in the hands of the Forest Service. Sadly,
in August 2013 another megaload — this one owned by General Electric and bound
for the tar sands — traveled through the river corridors. Despite protests by
the Nez Perce Tribe and IRU members, the Forest Service took no action to stop the
loads.
IRU and the Tribe went back to federal court and
obtained an injunction blocking megaload traffic until permanent rules and restrictions
can be developed and put in place. In August 2014 our organization, the Tribe
and the USFS began court-supervised mediation to attempt to resolve the issues.
That means our work to win permanent protections
is just beginning.
Mediation with the Forest Service will require
considerable manpower, grassroots organizing, media work, travel and direct
advocacy. We must make sure the Forest Service writes acceptable, legal and
protective transportation regulations for the Wild & Scenic corridor and
Nez Perce homeland. That won't be easy. So far the agency has seemed reluctant to buck big oil.
What We Need and What You Get

Since 2010, this
campaign has put significant stress on our small non-profit’s annual budget.
Big oil and the U.S. Forest Service don’t face such financial constraints. That’s why we’re reaching out to you via Indiegogo. Short term we need $25,000 to keep our campaign running effectively. We’ll use your contribution help us: 



Continue to build grassroots support for Wild & Scenic River
protection — in the Clearwater-Lochsa region and across Idaho.


Tell this story nationally with an eye toward convincing the government to
do the right thing for the Lochsa-Clearwater, and Wild & Scenic Rivers
nationwide.


And, engage fully and effectively in court-supervised mediation
with the Forest Service in an attempt to resolve our differences over the
management of the Lochsa-Clearwater Wild & Scenic corridor.


As an incentive to secure
your support, key business partners from the Lochsa-Clearwater region have
offered several incredible perks for our donors. Check out the list at the side
of this page!
Other Ways You Can Help
In addition to making a financial contribution to our campaign, there are other ways that you can help:

Please write an email to Forest Service Chief Tom Tidwell (ttidwell@fs.fed.us) and tell him 1) it's the Forest Service's responsibility to protect America's first Wild & Scenic Rivers, 2) the Lochsa-Clearwater is too precious for big oil and 3) failing to act will threaten Wild & Scenic Rivers across the nation.

Also, share this campaign with your family and friends. We're working with our valued partners to engage river lovers around the nation, but a campaign like this is most effective when people like you spread the word. Please pass it along via email or via social media, and help us keep the Lochsa and Clearwater rivers megaload free for generations to come.

This issue has achieved national attention and has been featured by media outlets coast to coast:

Media converge includes this five-minute news report from from PBS affiliate This American Land:

Last, and far from least, thanks to our business partners who are supporting this work and helping to avert this threat to our Wild & Scenic Rivers:

story:
A CALL TO ACTION

"Action without vision is only passing time, 
vision without action is merely day dreaming, 
but vision with action can change the world!" 
~ Nelson Mandela

   "Rewilding The Lost Wilderness: Green Heritage of the Forgotten Cape" is an epic literary masterpiece of South African cultural history, heritage and conservation! 

  • The Impact: to distribute books free of charge to schools and libraries in rural, previously disadvantaged communities.
  • The Cause: to conserve the history of wildlife and conservation in South Africa.
  • The Mission: to inspire and facilitate rewilding and restitution of wilderness throughout South Africa for the benefit of wildlife and previously disadvantaged communities. 

THE IMPACT 

   In keeping with the vision of Madiba, the Father of the South African nation, "Rewilding The Lost Wilderness: Green Heritage of the Forgotten Cape" was written to inspire change and action through the uniting force of conservation.

   Through the combined efforts of the "Rewilding The Lost Wilderness: Green Heritage of the Forgotten Cape" team, we aim to: 

  • Distribute books free of charge to rural community libraries and schools - thereby conserving the multi-cultural heritage of and for all South Africans;
  • Inspire unity and economic upliftment among previously disadvantaged communities through the expansion of "rewilding areas" and game reserves;
  • Inspire the creation of community operated game reserves - through free "Rewilding The Lost Wilderness" consultancy to previously disadvantaged communities;
  • Inspire the continued conservation of the globally threatened species, which sadly includes both the local black and white rhinoceros;
  • Serve as a guideline for the restitution of wilderness areas across South Africa, and;
  • Serve as an example for global rewilding initiatives. 

THE CAUSE

   "Rewilding The Lost Wilderness: Green Heritage of the Forgotten Cape" is a tale of the unknown Africa! A wilderness forgotten in the midst of colonization, urbanization, and exploitation! But a lost wilderness that has proven resilient and a forgotten wilderness with hope! 

   The North American prairie has its bison, the European tundra has its reindeer and the Central Asian steppe has its saiga antelope, but nowhere else on this globe is there a greater spectacle of wildlife and wilderness than in Africa! No other continent can boast with the immense diversity and expansive wilderness.

   Yet along the southernmost extremities of the continent lies a land with a much different reality. Here the ancient rhythm of Africa has been disturbed, changed and distorted! Endless herds of gazelle, wildebeest and half-striped zebra have been replaced with far-ranging mutton estates. Raucous parrots and their evergreen forests retreated into far off districts and inaccessible mountain slopes. Lagoons and river mouths where the hippopotamus and crocodile openly bathed in the morning sun gave way to harbours, towns and cities. Rolling coastal hills and mountain slopes where the leopard found his favorite haunt now stands adorned with some of the finest vineyards and olive groves in the southern hemisphere! Where vast grasslands with bontebok and blue antelope once ranged across the Overberg panorama, now only wheat and canola fields flourish. And even the mighty Clanwilliam cedar tree nearly went the way of the dodo, as its fragrant wood was sculpted into lavish furniture! This transformed part of southern Africa came to be known as the Cape! Today this region is defined as the three south-westernmost provinces of South Africa, and not half of its story has been told!

   After more than 350 years of European settlement much about the former wilderness has been forgotten, and for many the notion of lions, rhinos and elephants in Cape Town might come with a strong sense of disbelief. But the Dutch colonization was by no means the beginning of the story of man’s wandering in these southern districts, for the exploits of man in the Cape goes back many centuries! First came the Stone Age hunter-gatherers with power over the element of fire! On the heels of the San followed the Stone Age Khoikhoi pastoralists with their herds of sheep, goats and cattle. As the Khoikhoi spread across the entire face of the Cape, the Iron Age dawned with the arrival of the Bantu-speaking Nguni and later Tswana farmers. By 1488 European forays to these shores commenced as Portuguese seafarers set foot on South African soil! And after Dutch colonization in the year 1652 the Cape was never to be the same again!

   However, the real Africa is a land of innovation, optimism and restoration! After much environmental and socio-political unrest, as various cultures surpassed their predecessors and came to define their own borders within this multi-cultural blend, the Cape was left in a state of wildlife neutrality! Vast Karoo plains devoid of springbok, blesbok, black wildebeest and quagga; Fynbos laden mountains devoid of red hartebeest, eland and elephant; and water courses devoid of hippopotamus. But the modern African was not satisfied to have African bush devoid of African wildlife, and so we embark on the quest to ‘rewild’ this forgotten wilderness!

   "Rewilding The Lost Wilderness: Green Heritage of the Forgotten Cape" is the story of a quintessential African wilderness that has been lost and is being regained! It is a story of hope and restoration! A tale of hope for all the wilderness areas that has been lost, and an example for all wilderness areas that is still to be regained!

~ Marcel H. van der Merwe

"a South African author, conservation activist, and philanthropist."

THE MISSION 

      "I read Marcel van der Merwe’s book with great interest and empathy, his authors note really says it all and he is to be complimented on producing an outstanding contribution to conservation literature. Sixty two years of my life has now been spent in the battle for the conservation of wildlife and wilderness in South Africa, also in other countries such as the Philippine Islands where I assisted in the preservation of the tamaraw, a diminutive buffalo on the island of Mindoro.

   The Cape Province has always been of great interest to me although I have never lived there. I always remember my great friend, Colonel Sir Laurens van der Post CBE, giving speeches and talking about the history of the Cape and how the hippo came out into Table Bay to welcome the first settlers and how the black rhino existed on the top of Table Mountain. He had a way of touching the hearts of the audiences that he spoke to. The wild animals and the Bushmen were always part of his story. The wild landscapes of his early youth were deeply ingrained on his psyche. His ability to describe wild landscapes, wild animals and wild people, always left a deep impression. It is no wonder that his Royal Highness Prince Charles came to regard Laurens van der Post as a mentor.

   I believe Marcel van der Merwe’s book deserves the thanks not only of South Africans, but people in other countries who increasingly are becoming concerned about the plight of wild animals and wild country in South Africa. The current slaughter of white and black rhino, animals that I have been closely associated with and done my best to protect, is very much in the forefront of the great struggle to conserve our wildlife. The birth of wildlife sanctuaries such as Shamwari and Sanbona, created through the genius and hard work of Adrian Gardiner in the Eastern Cape have proved that wildlife conservation has been a tremendous boon, not only to the conservation of animals, but also to the tourist industry which I believe will eventually prove its critical importance to South Africa because it is sustainable, unlike the minerals which will eventually run out. Adrian Gardiner’s efforts have now been emulated in other parts of the Cape and are proving again not only important for wildlife, but also economics.

   The earliest game ranches in South Africa originated in the Cape with the saving of the bontebok and we can be grateful that Adrian Gardiner and others have carried on that tradition. It is my hope that Marcel van der Merwe’s book will inspire other landowners to recreate wild lands for the protection of all wildlife; animals, birds, vegetation and landscapes. His book is a mine of valuable information, a most important resource for present and future conservationists wanting to restore the wild lands of our country."

~ Dr. Ian Player

"(born March 15, 1927) a South African environmental educator, conservationist, sportsman and activist."

WHAT WE NEED  

   In order to make this South African heritage and conservation masterpiece a reality we need funds to cover the final production costs. The bulk of which includes community outreach orientated expenses, and some professional and artistic layout fees and costs regarding final printing.

   In order to achieve positive impact in the local, previously disadvantaged communities of South Africa we initially need around $50,000 to facilitate:

  • The free distribution of books to schools and libraries in rural and previously disadvantaged communities, especially in the Western Cape, Eastern Cape (birthplace of Nelson Mandela) and Northern Cape of South Africa.
  • The general logistics of community outreach (especially in rural parts of the Cape like the Transkei).
  • The provision of free consultancy to communities concerning the development of ecological friendly and economically sustainable community owned game reserves, and the logistics involved in such an operation.
"Only after the last tree has been cut down, 
only after the last river has been poisoned, 
only after the last fish has been caught. 
only then will you find - that money cannot be eaten" 

~ Chief Seattle

SUMMARY:

We're just two guys... who for all intents and purposes are just like everyone else. And like everyone else we're disillusioned with the extreme prosperity that exists on one side of the planet, while on the other side people live in deep degradation and poverty. So Aurica is our move at introducing the change we want to see.

Our efforts will see us introduce to market a range of health and wellness goods. From the sale of every product we'll donate a whopping £1 per item towards global initiatives which aim to relieve poverty, address inequality and help the environment (among them Cool Earth and it's tree planting campaign!)

We'll be selling coconut oil / argan oil / supplements / tea leaves / coffee / food bars along with a range of everyday health and wellness produce - so you can look forward to some really cool stuff from us.

With your help HERE we're looking to offer early donations to the charity we've confirmed we'll be supporting and the others that are in the pipeline. We'll also look to buy a good deal of farmed goods from local farmers to get operations in full flow.

We believe our products can make the world of difference- so if you have a spare £1 you can donate, please do, it's so important to us and the people we'll be helping. Thanks!

**If we raise our £20,000 target - then that money once it's helped us buy and sell our produce, will see over £15,000 given in charitable donations to the charities we're confirmed & lining up to work with**


THE FULL STORY (if you have 5 minutes):

The problem we face...

If we were to ask you... 'what do so many of the products on our supermarket shelves have in common'... it wouldn't be long before someone said 'their sales are filling the pockets of the wrong people!'

And they would be right to say that.

The every day product life cycle has become one that is driven by GREED and UNFAIRNESS - that's not only unsustainable but is also extremely damaging to the environment and the communities at the product source. 

...But for an everyday problem there is an every day solution. And that's the concept from which Aurica was born.


What is Aurica...

Aurica is the brain-child of me (Ioan) and my co-adventurer (Ian).

We're just two guys... who for all intents and purposes are just like everyone else. 

We share one thing in common with most people, and that's this feeling of  is disillusionment with corporations and society at large - and particularly how they operate (for the most part) when it comes to buying, manufacturing and selling of goods. A pattern of operation which in the short and the long term is having a catastrophic impact on the world that we live in and on the communities that inhabit it.

You see we're in a window right now - a window which on one side of the glass sees prosperity like never before, but on the other sees extreme poverty and depletion of resources. Think of it like a weighing scale, when you take from one side without giving back, well that's when equality starts to become an obsolete term, giving rise to the super rich and the super poor.

And whilst this haven of sorts exists in the short term for the super rich, the situation is one that will see them like everyone else fall away into ruin - so ask yourself... is it fair? Is it fair that people have so much while others go without? And is it fair that a few people should benefit in the short term while a countless many will perish because the people who dictate this pattern of society don't share the values of everyday people, like us and you?

Well...naturally this has become the starting point for Ian and myself, two guys who share a love for people and for the world we live in. Inspired by figureheads in a growing movement that takes social responsibility seriously, leaving any feeling of this is trendy or a quick gimmick at the door, this is where it's all beginning....


Our aims for Aurica...

What we're aiming for Aurica to become is a brand of earth-friendly products that are sourced from the most needy environments in sustainable and organic ways, giving the farmers a much fairer price on their produce - that's the first part. The next part will see us donate £1 from every item sold donated back to TO THE SOURCEOF THE PRODUCT FOR A RANGE OF SOCIAL & SUPPORT INITIATIVES -  from tree planting (with Cool Earth) / healthcare / community investment towards education and food / womens rights (with Otra Cosa Network in Peru) / clothing and equipment for work and leisure / financial donations towards local needs - and anything else that we can help fund to give the people at the source and their environments a better and most importantly, A FAIR LIFE

The products we're looking to release are - coconut oil / argan oil / supplements / tea leaves / coffee / food bars along with a range of further health and wellness produce - all sourced from regions which need a break from the big chains that are leaving them with nothing for their hard work.

I KNOW THESE SOUND LIKE EVERY DAY PRODUCTS - BUT THAT'S EXACTLY THE POINT. So many of our products come from people and communities that don't benefit from their sale.

We want to give people the chance to buy every day products, that have an extraordinary impact. With 'every day living, every day giving' as our brand motto and with our passion, desire and research we beleive Aurica has what it takes to really make a HUGE IMPACT, IMPROVING THE LIVES OF THOUSANDS, IF NOT MILLIONS, OF PEOPLE.

We've successfully established a number of the suppliers at the sources we want to help, and we've also managed to get a number of charities on board that we're looking to help. We're also lining up the outlets we want to see our product sold at, but there's more to be done...


Why we need YOU to help us...

We really need the help of indiegogo'ers in funding this project.

We want to make early donations to the confirmed organisations we're working with which include Cool Earth and Otra Cosa Network (Peru), with many more on the way! That's where a good proportion of any money raised will come in. Further funds will be utilised to help get our social enterprise off the ground, to get its products into environments where they can start to flourish flourish to begin the process of helping people and communities at the source.

If you're able to donate just a pound or a dollar - we would be so grateful!! 

We really cannot express enough our gratitude enough or our desire to see this project fulfilled and on its way towards helping the countless communities that need a fairer system of product sourcing and a fairer way of life!

Thanks for reading!

Ioan & Ian

We're also lining up the outlets we want to see our product sold at, but there's more to be done...

We really need the help of indiegogo'ers in funding this project.
We want to make early donations to the confirmed organisations we're working with which include Cool Earth and Otra Cosa Network (Peru), with many more on the way! That's where a good proportion of any money raised will come in. Further funds will be utilised to help get our social enterprise off the ground, to get its products into environments where they can start to flourish flourish to begin the process of helping people and communities at the source.
If you're able to donate just a pound or a dollar - we would be so grateful!! 
We really cannot express enough our gratitude enough or our desire to see this project fulfilled and on its way towards helping the countless communities that need a fairer system of product sourcing and a fairer way of life!
Thanks for reading!
Ioan & Ian

story:
What is MicroHydro?

Micro-hydroelectric systems generate electricity from flowing water without altering the landscape. Instead of building a dam, as with most large hydroelectric systems, microhydro systems simply reroute a portion of the river flow and pass it through a turbine to generate electricity before returning the water to the river. Microhydro is ideal for isolated communities and farms with difficult terrain, and it is a more economical and environmentally friendly way of generating electricity than most other options. For a more extensive explanation of how a microhydro system works, visit our website at www.hiteca-gt.com. (You might want to use Google Translate if you don't speak Spanish).
Guatemala has the perfect landscape for microhydro - the mountainous terrain provides areas of drastic elevation change, and streams and rivers flow generously, offering great natural potential to create energy. Microhydro is not an unknown technology in Guatemala, but we estimate that only 10% of the country's micro-hydro capacity is currently being realized. In addition, many of the existing systems are very old (some were installed in the 1950s), and advances in technology mean that their capacity could be greatly increased. Hiteca has the expertise to fill the large unmet need for high-quality personalized engineering to help communities develop the best micro-hydro systems for their needs.
 

Our Impact

Guatemala is a country where electricity is scarce, expensive and dirty. This has innumerable economic and social consequences, from high costs of production for the country's small farms and industries to reduced opportunities for education for the poor in remote parts of the country. Small scale renewable energy technologies, particularly micro-hydroelectric systems, have a great potential for changing this situation. A typical microhydro system can provide electricity to a community of 300 people that is too remote to connect to the national grid or help a coffee farmer reduce his energy costs during production by up to 80%.

We are already starting to bring this potential impact to reality. This year we have installed a new control and electrical protection system in a microhydro that serves 250 families, rehabilited a system in a community of 50 families and another in an organic coffee and cardamom farm, and have started the fabrication of a completely new system for a 40 family community in partnership with Engineers Without Borders. In total we are contributing to the generation of 80+ kW of clean electricity for over 300 families.


Who is Hiteca?

We are a startup social enterprise committed to providing renewable energy solutions to families and communities across Guatemala. Founded by husband and wife Steve Crowe and Waleska Aguilar and growing out of their extensive experience in the renewable energy field, Hiteca provides sorely needed clean and affordable energy technologies in a country where energy is normally both dirty and expensive.

Steve is a mechanical engineer who was trained in the United States and, drawn by the rich culture and beautiful landscape of Guatemala, came to the country to work over 8 years ago. During that time, Steve has worked with many organizations including the Appropriate Infrastracture Development Group (AIDG) and Engineers Without Borders developing and implementing renewable energy technologies. Waleska is a Guatemalan born business administrator, trained at a local university and well-versed in the challenges of running a business in Guatemala. Together they founded Hiteca in December 2012 and started working with a special focus on micro-hydroelectric systems.


How YOU can Help

Since we started Hiteca in December we have made a lot of progress, installing and repairing four microhydro systems and doing initial studies for several more. We are continuing to meet more people and do more studies to be able to bring more projects to reality. We are excited by this progress, but we need your help to continue to grow. To take on more projects we need to build a workshop and invest in some key tools and equipment. This will allow us to work more efficiently and provide a higher quality product - helping us to bring clean, affordable electricity to more people all around the country.

By helping us to do this we'll show our thanks by giving you a super-awesome Hiteca t-shirt, coffee coaster, notebook, or tote bag (that's right, you'll be the envy of all your friends. Except of course those that get their own Hiteca stuff). Or if you're really excited by our work and want to see what we do first hand, we'd love to show you around Guatemala and one of our projects! But if you can't donate right now, don't worry, we don't hate you. You can still spread the word about Hiteca and our campaign through Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn.

Shipping outside of the U.S. not included in the perks. See the gallery for images of the t-shirts and coasters!
story_txt:
What
is MicroHydro?
Micro-hydroelectric systems generate electricity from flowing water without altering the landscape. Instead of building a dam, as with most large hydroelectric systems, microhydro systems simply reroute a portion of the river flow and pass it through a turbine to generate electricity before returning the water to the river. Microhydro is ideal for isolated communities and farms with difficult terrain, and it is a more economical and environmentally friendly way of generating electricity than most other options. For a more extensive explanation of how a microhydro system works, visit our website at www.hiteca-gt.com. (You might want to use Google Translate if you don't speak Spanish).Guatemala has the perfect landscape for microhydro - the mountainous terrain provides areas of drastic elevation change, and streams and rivers flow generously, offering great natural potential to create energy. Microhydro is not an unknown technology in Guatemala, but we estimate that only 10% of the country's micro-hydro capacity is currently being realized. In addition, many of the existing systems are very old (some were installed in the 1950s), and advances in technology mean that their capacity could be greatly increased. Hiteca has the expertise to fill the large unmet need for high-quality personalized engineering to help communities develop the best micro-hydro systems for their needs. Our Impact
Guatemala is a country where electricity is scarce, expensive and dirty. This has innumerable economic and social consequences, from high costs of production for the country's small farms and industries to reduced opportunities for education for the poor in remote parts of the country. Small scale renewable energy technologies, particularly micro-hydroelectric systems, have a great potential for changing this situation. A typical microhydro system can provide electricity to a community of 300 people that is too remote to connect to the national grid or help a coffee farmer reduce his energy costs during production by up to 80%.We are already starting to bring this potential impact to reality. This year we have installed a new control and electrical protection system in a microhydro that serves 250 families, rehabilited a system in a community of 50 families and another in an organic coffee and cardamom farm, and have started the fabrication of a completely new system for a 40 family community in partnership with Engineers Without Borders. In total we are contributing to the generation of 80+ kW of clean electricity for over 300 families.

Who is Hiteca?
We are a startup social enterprise committed to providing renewable energy solutions to families and communities across Guatemala. Founded by husband and wife Steve Crowe and Waleska Aguilar and growing out of their extensive experience in the renewable energy field, Hiteca provides sorely needed clean and affordable energy technologies in a country where energy is normally both dirty and expensive.
Steve is a mechanical engineer who was trained in the United States and, drawn by the rich culture and beautiful landscape of Guatemala, came to the country to work over 8 years ago. During that time, Steve has worked with many organizations including the Appropriate Infrastracture Development Group (AIDG) and Engineers Without Borders developing and implementing renewable energy technologies. Waleska is a Guatemalan born business administrator, trained at a local university and well-versed in the challenges of running a business in Guatemala. Together they founded Hiteca in December 2012 and started working with a special focus on micro-hydroelectric systems. 
How YOU can Help
Since we started Hiteca in December we have made a lot of progress, installing and repairing four microhydro systems and doing initial studies for several more. We are continuing to meet more people and do more studies to be able to bring more projects to reality. We are excited by this progress, but we need your help to continue to grow. To take on more projects we need to build a workshop and invest in some key tools and equipment. This will allow us to work more efficiently and provide a higher quality product - helping us to bring clean, affordable electricity to more people all around the country.By helping us to do this we'll show our thanks by giving you a super-awesome Hiteca t-shirt, coffee coaster, notebook, or tote bag (that's right, you'll be the envy of all your friends. Except of course those that get their own Hiteca stuff). Or if you're really excited by our work and want to see what we do first hand, we'd love to show you around Guatemala and one of our projects! But if you can't donate right now, don't worry, we don't hate you. You can still spread the word about Hiteca and our campaign through Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn.

Shipping outside of the U.S. not included in the perks. See the gallery for images of the t-shirts and coasters!

story:
PET-REMOTE offers a new and easy way to communicate with your dog! 

Pet-Remote is a small vibrating device that works in combination with a free iPhone App. With the push of a single button, Pet-Remote vibrates or plays an acoustic signal, and your dog will know exactly what to do!


First of all you need a dog. But you can also try your luck with training a cat or any other pet. The rest is very simple!

Just download the free Pet-Remote iPhone App and attach the Pet-Remote device to your dog's collar. Now you and your dog are ready to start training and have fun!


You open the Pet-Remote App and push one of the command buttons. The small device on your dogs collar will vibrate and/or play an acoustic signal, depending on your settings. Your dog feels and/or hears the signal and reacts to it.

Don't forget - first teach your dog what you expect him to do when he gets a signal. You will be surprised how fast your dog will learn to respond correctly to the commands!



You can teach your dog standard commands or come up with new ones. The default setting offers the commands "sit", "down" and "come". You have the possibility to replace each one by choosing from a range of other commands.


Pet-Remote is no shock-collar - it definitely won't hurt your beloved dog! You can choose whether to use vibration and/or acoustic signals. 

The setting for the signal can be edited for each command. So you can decide e.g. to use just vibration for "sit" and "down" but both signals (vibration and sound) for the very important command "come". It's up to you!

The consistency of the signals helps your dog to understand and fulfill your expectations. Your dog will thank you for your clarity.


  • The Pet-Remote device only weighs 10 g and has a size of 1,7 in x 0,9 in. 
  • Its very energy efficient - the battery holds up to 1 year.
  • It uses Bluetooth Smart Technology to communicate.

story:
About Pollima

Pollima is a visionary consulting brand connecting designers, investors, and material manufacturers to boost the circular economy. Pollima partners with industry leaders utilizing textile waste, agricultural waste, bacteria, and other materials from the waste stream to push the fashion and interiors industries into a circular future.

The Pollima Material Revolution

On October 13th, Pollima will be hosting the Material Revolution exhibit that will bring awareness to innovative materials reimagined and grown from the waste stream and the designers that use them. We are working toward the future of design, consumption, and the circular economy. Our whole country looks to California for the healthiest and most sustainable standards and together we can make LA Fashion Week the sustainable fashion week.

Showcasing:

  • Agricultural-waste alternative leathers, textiles, board, and buttons
  • Kombucha leather and rolling papers
  • Recycled cannabis paper
  • Recycled textiles
  • Bacteria and algae dye 
  • 3 panel discussions with the innovators

Taste, Smell, See, Learn, and Do:

  • Interactive bacteria dyeing from Living Colour
  • Panel discussions with innovators of materials and supply chains
  • Rolling station with The Kombucha Paper
  • Food & material pairings (EX: coconut-waste leather & CocoTaps coconut water to drink!)

Special Guests

  • Rachelle Carson-Begely will be moderating one of our panels
  • Kestrel Jenkins, creator of Conscious Chatter, will be too!

Why?

According to the McKinsey & Company’s State of Fashion 2018 Report, less than 1% of material not used to produce clothing is recycled into new clothing. Aside from the $500 billion/year economic value loss, there are countless negative environmental and societal impacts. Together, we are all partners in the material revolution to raise the industry standards and re-imagine our waste streams. 

We have to ask : Where did this material come from? Where is this material going?

We Need Your Support

Some material manufacturers and designers put all their money into research and development - we thank them! Creating a new circular economy is a noble cause and we are grateful for their work. We don’t want them to feel limited in their ability to exhibit and share with conscious consumers and impact investors what they are doing day in and day out in the studio or lab.
That is why we at Pollima have been inclusive in our Material Revolution Exhibit .are not able to cover the costs of their exhibit. 

  •  With $1000 we can cover three exhibitors installation costs
    • Gallery space and hardware for installation

Even if you cannot attend the event, you can be making a major difference in supporting the makers who are building the future of consumption. 

For your contribution, we will send you a video of the panel discussions!

The Impact

  • We are expecting over 200 conscious consumer and media attendees. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please invite your LA network to the exhibit! bit.ly/2I4QbfQ
  • And ask 2 questions when purchasing a product: Where did this material come from? Where is this material going? If you find an answer, great first step! Then ask yourself if you like the answer. If you don't like the answer, vote with your dollar on products made from materials made from the waste stream. :)

story:
Hi, my name is Jaben Wood. I am a 17-year-old Life Scout from Kalispell, Montana. I have been a Scout since I was six years old. Now I am working on the highest level in scouting, my Eagle Scout Award. An Eagle Project must give back to a community so for my Boy Scout Eagle Project I set a goal of putting in 10 water systems in 10 villages in Uganda, Africa.

I went to Uganda with my family as a 12-year-old and fell in love with the people and the country. I was moved by the plight of so many of the kids. They were my age and had no access to clean drinking water. Later that year I made up my mind to go back to Uganda and take clean water to all those kids I had met. I started planning how to make my dream a reality. I went back to Uganda in 2011 and met with Ugandan Scouts and looked at many villages that did not have any water systems. I want to involve the local scouts in each area so that the villagers see local kids helping build better communities.

After looking at the cost of hiring a well driller, I realized that to be fiscally responsible and plan for a long-term project, I needed to look into buying a drill rig. I am trying to raise enough money to purchase one and have it shipped to Uganda. By having a drill rig, the project will be able to continue long after I have gotten my Eagle Scout Award. Your contribution will not only bring a long-term sustainable project to the Ugandan Scouting program. You will also help bring clean water and improved health for the villagers, and you will enable the children to stay in school and give back to their country.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to purchase a RockBuster R77-Mag well drilling rig.  The price for this is:

RockBuster R77-MAG:  $38,500

35 stick of standard duty drill rod:  $7,175

4” step bit:  $145

6” step bit:  $185

4” Chevron:  $150

6” Chevron: $425

4” Rock Roller Bit:  $440

6” Rock Roller Bit:  $1080

2-3/8” Sub:  $265

3-1/2” Sub:  $375

Total:  $48,740.00

 

You can see the R77-Mag here http://www.rockbuster.com/?page_id=125&sl=r77-mag

 

These prices do not include the cost of shipping or the expense to import the machinery into Uganda. 

Anything above my goal will go into funding more wells. I looked at hiring a drill company to do the work but the cost was astronomical, so I am coordinating with Ugandan Scouts on this project and the well rig will stay in Uganda. They will continue the work of scouts4water after my Eagle Project is done. Any excess funds will be held in trust for future maintenance costs. 

Each installed water system is designed to be a self-contained, submersible pump run from electricity, where available, or solar power to fill storage tanks. The villages can then have a reserve of water in case of drought.   

For helping with this project we have some great perks for our donors. 

$10 donation:   A thank-you letter from the village you helped support

$25 donation:   A photo of the village that you helped with its well

$100 donation: An enameled tin cup with the Scouts4Water logo on it

$1000 donation:  A plaque with your name on it that is on the water holding tank in the village that you helped support

 

All perks are cumulative.

 

If I am not able to achieve the full campaign amount of funding, I will explore the possibility of purchasing a less expensive drill rig.  The less expensive drill rig is lower in quality and horsepower and may limit the abilities and longevity of the Scouts4Water project. 

The Impact

At the age of 12, I had the opportunity to travel to Uganda with my Youth Group from Christ Church Episcopal. Africa to me is almost indescribable. The city of Kampala with its grungy streets, acrid smells, and high noise level was so different from my home in Montana. There was a strange combination of poverty and technology.—There was no electricity, no refrigeration, and spotty water pressure, but there were also internet cafes and cell phones. The countryside seemed as familiar as home but with banana trees replacing the pines. In the four-hour ride to Bulanga, I was excited to realize I was in Africa yet nervous about being accepted by the people we would be meeting.

Our destination was Hope Child Care Project (HCCP), an orphanage and boarding school for local children ages 4-16.  It provides an education, food, shelter, and most importantly, clean water for approximately 400 children and the surrounding villages. 

The village of Bulanga sits another half mile from the school.  It is a small village that borders the main road. As with most of Uganda, Bulanga is very rural.  The average home in Bulanga is about 100 square feet. It has one or two rooms, is built of mud and sticks, and has a grass thatched roof.  This home has no windows, a dirt floor, no indoor plumbing, no kitchen, and houses an average of five to eight people.  Cooking is done primarily over charcoal grills or open fires.  Water is hauled to the house on a daily basis. People commonly have a small patch of land that they farm to feed their family, and they try to have surplus food available to sell at the local market.  They grow coffee, bananas, pineapple, beans, ground nuts, and Irish potatoes. Many of the mothers also make baskets, woven mats, and paper jewelry to sell. 

Bulanga is in the middle of the Rakai District of Uganda and is documented to be the location where the AIDS epidemic began.   While there are many single mothers, there are often no parents in the home and older siblings raise younger ones. 

A man who stays in the village usually works as a laborer, making the equivalent of $50 a month if he is a hard worker. The teachers who live at HCCP are paid around $100 per month. This is in a nation where 69% of the population live on less than $1 U.S. per day.

I introduced you to Steven in the video. He is a 10-year-old schoolboy at HCCP.  Every morning he walks approximately 1-1/2 to 2 miles to school from his sister’s house, where he lives. The closest water supply to their house is a small creek next to a pineapple plantation. According to Loughborough University, the average distance that women in Africa walk to collect water is six kilometers or 3.7 miles.

Water is not as light as you might think. The total weight that Steven carries at least once a day is equal to 40 pounds of water.  The water he carries is for his sister, her three children, and himself. This water is used for cooking, cleaning, bathing, and drinking.

When I revisited Uganda in December 2010, I brought home a water sample at the creek to have it analyzed for choliform bacteria levels. The levels present in that sample were over 24,200 mpn (most probable number)/100ml; the current EPA standard is 235 mpn/100ml. Steven has over 100 times the acceptable amount of e.coli bacteria in his drinking water. Because of the high amounts of e.coli bacteria in the water, many children like Steven will never see adulthood. 

A couple of days after our arrival at HCCP I was able to go see one of the local watering holes. This is when it struck me that their life is so different from mine. I have access to a quality education; I live in a house that is 10 times larger than the average African hut; I have stacks of clothing, instead of one school uniform and one play uniform; I have three meals a day instead of one cold meal for the day; and I have television, a laptop of my own, an IPod, and my own cell phone—not that much different from most teenage American boys.

Most of all, I have clean water. In America we have the ability to turn a faucet and have clean, drinkable, running water. There, they have to make do with whatever water they can find. This includes streams, puddles, and stagnant ponds that are shared with multiple villages and their animals. People all across the world live without IPods, cell phones, television, surplus clothing, big houses, fancy cars, and excess food. BUT no one can live without water.

I have been a Boy Scout for 10 years and have achieved the Rank of Life Scout.  The only higher rank in Scouts is that of Eagle Scout.  There are many requirements to the Eagle Scout rank, including a service project that gives back to a community.  Because of what I saw and learned on that first trip I decided to make my Eagle Project installing wells in Africa. I started working on this project when I was 12 years old and have devoted the last five years of my life to finding the best way to help as many people as possible have access to clean water. To that end, I plan to return to Uganda in the summer of 2013 to oversee the installation of 10 water systems in 10 villages.

I have learned many things through scouts and life that have taught me to make a difference wherever I can and here is where I want to make the difference: I want to make a difference in the life of Steven and others like him. Will you please help me? 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, please help get the word out about this campaign through any media channels and social networks.

Please use the Indiegogo tools above, post the link to my website to your wall, and invite all of your lists to this group.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/water4water/

 

And also on my Webesite:

http://scouts4water.org/
