story: Bees
story_txt: Bees

story:
THE AIM HAS NOW BEEN REACHED BUT KEEP CONTRIBUTING AS I STILL NEED MONEY FOR THIS PROJECT! THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR WHAT WE HAVE ACCOMPLISHED SO FAR


L'OBJECTIF EST ATTEINT MAIS J'AI TOUJOURS BESOIN DE VOS CONTRIBUTIONS ALORS N'HESITEZ PAS...MERCI INFINIMENT!



*Traduction en Français ci-dessous…


Hello and thank you for visiting this page =)

The video you have just seen (or are going to watch just now) was my application to a fantastic project: Homeward Bound. It aims at elevating the role of women in leadership and in particular women scientists as we have a determinant role to play NOW for the future of our planet. I will explain the project better below but before let me tell you why this is very important.

The statistics are clear, although on average there are equal numbers of men and women entering higher education, the more you go up the ladder, the fewer women are remaining. 

There are several reasons for that including the difficulty to balance family life with a successful career:

  • The gender pay gap (still too big in Europe) along with historical/cultural habits influences who is the person spending more time taking care of the home, kids and elderly. 
  • The lack of women role-models in the highest responsibilities is striking in most disciplines: science, politics, medicine, law, entertainment, industry, finance... and refrain from inspiring girls, boys and their parents on the possibilities in front of them. 
  • The image of women in the media brings the body at the centre of everything rather than the mind (very well explained in a great documentary: Miss Representation). Therefore girls and women often lack the self-esteem, confidence, communication skills needed to reach the highest responsibilities. 
The issues of gender equality and climate change are intimately connected and could be tackled at the same time. Recent studies have shown that women are more affected by climate change and extreme weather events than men but also that women are more aware and responsive to climate change. Our planet and its biodiversity are being destroyed at an unprecedented rate, we need a new dynamic in both highest impact climate science and critical environmental political decisions. Women think and work differently and it is by considering this richness of skills, ideas and points of view altogether that a better efficiency in actions at the global scale can be reached.

So how do we do that? Homeward Bound is the world's first state-of-the-art leadership and strategic program for 78 Women in Science from around the globe (Australia, New-Zealand, USA, Canada, UK, Germany, France). It is not only the start of a 10 year outreach initiative to build a 1,000 strong global collaboration network of women in science. It is not only the first ever all-women scientific expedition to Antarctica departing Ushuaia, December 2nd  to 21st  2016. It is not only the chance for us, the first crew, to receive an excellent leadership, strategy and innovation training together and to build an on-site understanding of polar regions that are changing at an unprecedented rate. It is about helping more women of our generation to reach leadership roles by gaining the confidence and networking skills that are needed so that we can become role models for the next generation. 

A documentary crew, will follow us before, during and after the expedition, this is the trailer they have made. Homeward Bound benefits from the support of globally recognised women and men of influence, including Dr Jane Goodall, Primatologist and environmental activist, Franny Armstrong, one of the world’s 100 most influential women, Sylvia Earle, famous marine ecologist and celebrated activist filmed by James Cameron in Mission Blue, Dr Susan David, Co-Founder and Director of the Institute of Coaching, Harvard A-lister, Clare Bowditch – award winning singer and activist, Dr Robert Kaplan and Dave Norton – developed strategy mapping, balanced score card.

I applied to this initiative because I am at a critical time in my career, I just became a mum so I am very aware and militant for the challenges women are facing, I am passionate and made so many sacrifices that there is no way I am letting it go now. But the future is blurry because of lack of research funding and intense competition for permanent positions. I wanted to be part of it because it is innovative and pushes our comfort zone, it is already so inspiring to interact with the team on our Facebook page. I think creating a network like this is really going to help each of us achieve higher goals and creat a snowball effect.

I am so lucky to be a part of such an exceptional and inspiring project. The cost for me to attend is £10,000 or €14,000, which covers half of the costs of the cruise, the staff, the training and the film crew. The other half is arranged by Homeward Bound. Could you help me go forward in the common interests of Women, Men and our Planet???

Please use the links in blue if you want to have more information, they link to very good YouTube videos or short and targeted news articles. If clicking on it does not work, try right click and open in a new window. Homeward Bound is the brainchild of renowned Australian leadership expert Fabian Dattner, and the product of a magic collaboration with Dr Jess Melbourne‐Thomas from the Antarctic Climate and Ecosystems Cooperative Research Centre.


                                  


Bonjour et merci de visiter cette page =)

La vidéo que vous venez de voir (ou que vous allez regarder maintenant) a été préparée pour postuler à un projet fantastique: Homeward Bound. Il a pour but d’élever le rôle des femmes en position de leader, en particulier les femmes dans la science, car nous avons un rôle déterminant à jouer MAINTENANT pour le futur de notre planète. Je donnerai plus de détails sur le projet ci-dessous, mais d'abord laissez moi vous expliquer pourquoi cela est très important. 

Les statistiques sont claires, bien qu'en moyenne le nombre d'hommes et de femmes qui entament des études supérieures soit équivalent, au plus on monte les échelons, moins il y a de femmes.

Il y a plusieurs raisons pour cela dont la difficulté d’équilibrer vie de famille et carrière professionnelle, mais aussi:

  • L'inégalité salariale entre les sexes (toujours trop répandue en Europe) ainsi que certaines habitudes historiques/culturelles influencent le choix de la personne qui s’occupe de la maison, des enfants et des personnes âgées. 
  • Le manque de femmes servant d’exemple est frappant dans les responsabilités les plus élevées de la plupart des disciplines:  science, politique, médecine, justice, divertissement, industrie, finance... et limite l'inspiration des filles, garçons et leurs parents sur les possibilités qui s'offrent à eux. 
  • L'image des femmes dans les médias  positionne le corps plutôt que l'esprit au centre de tout  (très bien expliqué dans le documentaire : Miss Representation). C'est pour cela que les filles et les femmes manquent souvent de confiance, d'estime d'elles mêmes et de compétences en communication leur permettant d'atteindre les postes à haute responsabilité. 

Les problèmes d’égalité des sexes et de changement climatique sont intimement liés et pourraient être réglés en même temps. Des études récentes ont montré que les femmes sont plus affectées par le changement climatique et les événements climatiques extrêmes que les hommes, mais également que les femmes sont plus au fait et réactives vis a vis du changement climatique. Notre planète et sa biodiversité sont détruites à une vitesse sans précédent, nous avons besoin d'une nouvelle dynamique à la fois dans les études climatiques à fort impact et les décisions politiques environnementales critiques. Les femmes pensent et travaillent différemment et c'est en considérant cette richesse de compétences, d’idées et de points de vue ensembles qu'une meilleure efficacité dans les actions à grande échelle pourra être atteinte. 

Comment arriver à cela ? Homeward Bound est le premier programme au monde de leadership et stratégie pour 78 femmes dans la science venant des quatre coins du globe (Australie, Nouvelle-Zélande, Canada, Royaume Uni, Allemagne, France). Ce n'est pas seulement le début d'une initiative de 10 ans pour construire un réseau global de collaboration fort de 1000 femmes dans la science ; ce n'est pas seulement la première expédition scientifique exclusivement féminine de l'histoire à partir pour l’Antarctique depuis Ushuaïa entre le 2 et 21 Décembre 2016 ; ce n'est pas seulement la chance pour nous, la première équipe, de recevoir une excellente formation sur le leadership, les stratégies et l'innovation ensemble et construire un savoir in-situ des régions polaires qui sont en plein changement et à une vitesse sans précédent ; c'est aussi pour aider plus de femmes de notre génération a atteindre des rôles de leader en gagnant la confiance et le réseau qui sont nécessaires afin de devenir des exemples pour les générations futures.

Une équipe de documentaire nous suivra avant, pendant et après l’expédition. Voici the trailer qu'ils ont réalisé. Homeward Bound bénéficie du support d'hommes et de femmes d'influence mondialement reconnus comme Dr Jane Goodall, primatologue et activiste environnementale, Franny Armstrong, l'une des 100 femmes les plus influentes du monde, Sylvia Earle, écologiste marine reconnue et célèbre activiste filmée par James Cameron dans "Mission Blue", Dr Susan David, Cofondatrice et Directrice de l’institut de Coaching, Harvard A-lister, Clare Bowditch – chanteuse récompensée et activiste, et les stratégistes Dr Robert Kaplan et Dave Norton.

J'ai postulé à cette initiative car je suis a un moment critique de ma carrière : je viens juste de devenir mère et je suis très sensible aux challenges auxquels les femmes font face et je milite pour cette cause. Je suis passionnée par mon travail et j'ai fait tellement de sacrifices pour en arriver là, qu'il n'y a pas moyen que je m’arrête ici et maintenant. Mais le futur est encore flou à cause du manque de financement de la recherche et d'une compétition intense pour les postes permanents. Je voulais faire partie de cette initiative parce que c'est innovant et que cela repousse nos limites, c'est déjà tellement motivant d'interagir avec l’équipe sur notre page Facebook... Je pense que créer un réseau comme cela aidera vraiment chacune d'entre nous à atteindre des objectifs plus hauts et créera un effet boule-de-neige.

J'ai beaucoup de chance de faire partie d'un projet aussi exceptionnel et motivant. Le coût pour ma participation est de 14 000€ (10 000£), ce qui couvre la moitié des frais du voyage, le staff, la formation et le documentaire. L'autre moitié est financée par Homeward Bound. 

Pouvez vous m'aider a continuer cette aventure dans l’intérêt commun des femmes, des hommes et de notre planète ???

Veuillez utiliser les liens en bleu (en anglais désolée) si vous voulez avoir plus d'informations, ils renvoient vers de très bonnes vidéos Youtube ou des articles courts et ciblés. Si le lien ne fonctionne pas, essayez un clic droit > ouvrir une nouvelle page. Homeward Bound est l’idée de l'experte en leadership reconnue Fabian Dattner, et le produit de la collaboration avec Dr Jess Melbourne‐Thomas du Antarctic Climate and Ecosystems Cooperative Research Centre.


Photo credits: 

 Tyabin Vladislav, Beautiful eyes and frozen eyelashes

Sean Yoro, Women painted on iceberg
story_txt:
THE AIM HAS NOW BEEN REACHED BUT KEEP CONTRIBUTING AS I STILL NEED MONEY FOR THIS PROJECT! THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR WHAT WE HAVE ACCOMPLISHED SO FARL'OBJECTIF EST ATTEINT MAIS J'AI TOUJOURS BESOIN DE VOS CONTRIBUTIONS ALORS N'HESITEZ PAS...MERCI INFINIMENT!*Traduction en Français ci-dessous…
Hello and thank you for
visiting this page =)
The video you have just seen
(or are going to watch just now) was my application to a fantastic project: Homeward Bound. It aims at elevating the role of women in leadership and in
particular women scientists as we have a determinant role to play NOW for the
future of our planet. I will explain the project better below but before let me
tell you why this is very important.
The statistics are clear,
although on average there are equal numbers of men and women entering higher
education, the more you go up the ladder, the fewer women are remaining. There are several reasons for that including the difficulty to
balance family life with a successful career:
The gender pay gap (still too big in Europe) along with historical/cultural habits influences who is the person spending more time taking care of the
home, kids and elderly. 

The lack of
women role-models in the
highest responsibilities is striking in most disciplines: science, politics,
medicine, law, entertainment, industry, finance... and refrain from inspiring
girls, boys and their parents on the possibilities in front of them. 

The image of women in
the media brings the body at the centre of everything
rather than the mind (very well explained in a great documentary: Miss Representation). Therefore girls and women often lack the self-esteem, confidence, communication skills needed to
reach the highest responsibilities. 
The issues of gender equality and climate change are intimately connected and could be tackled at the same time. Recent studies have shown that women are more affected by climate change and
extreme weather events than men but also that women are more aware and responsive to climate change. Our planet and its biodiversity are being destroyed at an unprecedented rate, we need a new dynamic in both highest impact climate science and
critical environmental political decisions. Women think and work differently and it is by considering this richness of skills, ideas and points of view
altogether that a better efficiency in actions at the global scale can be
reached.

So how do we do that? Homeward
Bound is the world's first state-of-the-art leadership and
strategic program for 78 Women in Science from around the globe (Australia,
New-Zealand, USA, Canada, UK, Germany, France). It is not only the start
of a 10 year outreach initiative to build a 1,000 strong global collaboration
network of women in science. It is not only the first ever all-women scientific expedition to Antarctica departing Ushuaia, December 2nd  to 21st  2016. It is not only the chance for us, the first crew, to receive an excellent leadership, strategy and innovation training together and
to build an on-site understanding of polar regions that are changing at an unprecedented
rate. It is about helping more women of our
generation to reach leadership roles by gaining the confidence and networking
skills that are needed so that we can become role models for the next
generation. 




A documentary crew, will follow us before, during and after the
expedition, this is the trailer they have made. Homeward Bound benefits from
the support of globally recognised women and men of influence, including Dr Jane Goodall,
Primatologist and environmental activist, Franny Armstrong, one of the
world’s 100 most influential women, Sylvia Earle, famous marine ecologist
and celebrated activist filmed by James Cameron in Mission Blue, Dr Susan David, Co-Founder and Director of the Institute of Coaching, Harvard A-lister, Clare Bowditch – award winning singer and activist, Dr Robert Kaplan and Dave Norton – developed strategy mapping, balanced score card.
I applied to this initiative because I am at a critical time in my career, I just became a mum so I am very aware and militant for the challenges women are facing, I am passionate and made so many sacrifices that there is no way I am letting it go now. But the future is blurry because of lack of research funding and intense competition for permanent positions. I wanted to be part of it because it is innovative and pushes our comfort zone, it is already so inspiring to interact with the team on our Facebook page. I think creating a network like this is really going to help each of us achieve higher goals and creat a snowball effect.
I am so lucky to be
a part of such an exceptional and inspiring project. The cost for me to attend is £10,000 or €14,000, which covers half of the costs of the cruise, the staff, the training and the film crew. The other half is arranged by Homeward Bound. Could you help me go forward in the common interests of Women, Men and our Planet???

Please use the links in blue if you want to have more information, they link to very good YouTube videos or short and targeted news articles. If clicking on it does not work, try right click and open in a new window. Homeward Bound is the brainchild of renowned Australian leadership expert Fabian Dattner, and the product of a magic collaboration with Dr Jess Melbourne‐Thomas from the Antarctic Climate and Ecosystems Cooperative Research Centre.
                                  


Bonjour et merci de visiter cette page =)
La vidéo que vous venez de voir (ou que vous allez regarder maintenant) a été préparée pour postuler à un projet fantastique: Homeward Bound. Il a pour but d’élever le rôle des femmes en position de leader, en particulier les femmes dans la science, car nous avons un rôle déterminant à jouer MAINTENANT pour le futur de notre planète. L'inégalité salariale entre les sexes (toujours trop répandue en Europe) ainsi que certaines habitudes historiques/culturelles influencent le choix de la personne qui s’occupe de la maison, des enfants et des personnes âgées.

story:
Tim thinks communities of color shouldn’t be left out of the new green economy.

Guadalupe believes workers, not big corporations, should profit from their labor.

Steven wants to keep the money he earns circulating in the community he’s lived in all his life.

These are just some of the reasons African American and Latino workers came together to form the unique bilingual, multicultural co-op called CERO. They’ve invested two years of sweat equity into building a worker-owned business. In its first year CERO will reduce customer trash sent to landfills and incinerators by 50% and return more than 1000 tons of organic food waste to the food chain as rich composted soil.

Will you help CERO get up and running?

We need trucks and equipment to get our source separation recovery systems operational. This campaign will show investors and lenders that we have serious support. The proceeds will seed our direct public offering so that community folks, even those who don't have a whole lot to invest, can have a stake in our success too. We've already got customers lined up. With your help we can get the trucks and equipment we need to do the job.

Exciting Perks

  • Cool stuff made of recycled materials

  • Your name on one of our recycling & composting trucks

  • Cenar con CERO (Supper with CERO) dinner parties in great local restaurants

It's a Community Thing!

We are super appreciative for your donation. Now won't you help your friends into the CERO Circle by connecting them with the campaign?

story:
Living in the Dzanga sangha protected area, is hard, there is a constant threat of political turmoil as the rest of the country burns. Poaching at this time can easily slip out of control, and we believe that our presence here was vital in order to maintain a presence and an independent voice to the reality of what is going on here.

THE HISTORY 24 MARCH 2013 UNTIL PRESENT DAY.

Sangha lodge in the Central African Republic has remained active throughout the conflict and the troubles.

On March 24 the rebel alliance of Seleka managed to overthrow the government in Bangui and effectively took control of the whole country. We at Sangha lodge held on believing that we would not be in any danger personally from these rebels, while the staff from the WWF evacuated to Bomassa in Rep. Congo. However later that night our staff pleaded with us to leave, and we did. We were not really in fear of our own safty, but rather in fear of their safety. They would feel obligated to protect us and this would put their lives in danger.

We had and adventure heading down river at night to Congo and onwards to our home in South Africa. Meanwhile the staff at WWF headed home for the home countries and while some based themselves in Yaoundé. In early May  while conservation staff stayed in exile a massacre of elephants occurred at Dzanga bai, this is well documented, and while conservation staff from WWF stayed away frustrating us who have real passion for this area, a private security consultant Nir Kalron, from Maisha consulting came to Dzanga to start negotiating with the rebels in control.

We, that is Tamar and I in the meantime were at this stage very frustrated in South Africa as we now had no money to return. At this time we realised that our presence was vital to the morale of the local population who felt that the outside world had abandoned them.  While looting and thieving was going on by Seleka and local elements of the population, Sangha lodge itself was deteriorating too. Cables, electrical fittings, plumbing fittings and pipes, as well as all our alcohol and food stores were stolen by locals. Our staff remained loyal and did their best to protect the lodge but the onslaught was too intense at times.

At this time we received a gift of money from a very generous benefactor, the Lindberg family, and this inspired us to return immediately. Following news of our plans to return others helped and we also extended our own credit from our bank in South Africa. We believed that the crisis would end as soon as the WWF returned, and they kept saying they would be coming back next month, well next month lead into another next month and 8 months down the line the latest news is they will be returning next month [February]. I must say though that Maisha consulting has been hired by the WWF at this time so we are not entirely alone, there are Tamar and myself at the lodge, a security consultant at the WWF office, and Louis Sarno.

In the meantime we have remained here at the lodge and have contributed where we can to ongoing efforts with conservation and community. We have had many meetings about the future and the reason to continue with conservation and our community tourism plans with locals and have won the hearts and minds of most we believe.

We have assisted Maisha Consulting in building an installation at Dzanga bai so that the bai can be monitored 24/7 with security cameras. We have aided Drive against malaria to return and continue their work in the fight against malaria. And we continue to distribute Free of charge medicines wherever we are qualified to…simple diagnoses like malaria and some infections.

Our most exciting day however was our direct involvement with catching an elephant poacher, the first elephant poacher to be arrested in the APDS in the 5 years since our arrival. Ironically this arrest was with the help of Seleka the rebels.

The future for us remains uncertain; 12 months without earnings have drained our resources and left us on the verge of bankruptcy, only the generosity of clients, friends and family that has kept us alive until now. We are optimistic that the worst of the troubles are over and that Central Africa and especially this isolated corner of Central Africa will return to a form of normality that we had in the past. Our big issue now is to raise bridging finance to see us though the coming hard times, and we are pleading with all our loyal agents to help us survive this period.

The basic costs of keeping the lodge and the staff alive as well as continue with some of our developments with the local communities and maintain the lodge is in the region of 2 million CFA per month. That is approximately 3000 euros.  By the end of February we will be at the turning point and have to decide what direction to go in, but we are pleading for any form of assistance you can give us to help us through.

story:
Can Miami help Haiti become Urban Paradise?

With your support, the answer is YES!
Miami has a unique set of resources that could be used to help the Haitian people transform their lives, their communities, and their nation.

Sam Van Leer, President and Founder of Urban Paradise Guild (UPG) wants to help replicate the success of UPG in Haiti.

Sam wants to bring a whole lot of Seeds to establish new Nurseries and Gardens! 

About UPG

Urban Paradise Guild (UPG) was founded in 2008 with the goal of creating sustainable habitat in Miami. We do so by working with land throughout the county and finding volunteers who are passionate about native plants, edible gardens and the future of their city.

UPG's Location Adoptions involve the open-ended commitment to resolve the problems that the environment and the people experience through public engagement, knowledge, innovation, hard work, and steady pressure. 

These are the locations where UPG currently operates.

  • Oleta River State Park (Adoption + Nursery) 
  • Arch Creek East Preserve 
  • Amelia Earhart County Park (Garden Center & Adoption)
  • Lemon City (Garden Center & Region)
  • Vizcaya Museum and Gardens (Adoption + Nursery)
  • Matheson Hammock (Adoption) 

Photos of UPG at Work! 

If you don't already know UPG, we invite you to view our photos.

There are more than 3,000 posted on Facebook showing us at work.  https://www.facebook.com/urbanparadiseguild

Additionally, UPG has been providing Seeds for use in Haiti since October 2008, with kilos of Seeds from eatable Natives and Cacao for economic development. 

Replicating the UPG Model in Haiti

We can not do this without you!

We would like to foster this opportunity, and provide Sam the chance to bring seeds and materials to help jumpstart gardens in Haiti. 

    The Impacts

    We believe the best way to learn the realities on the ground in Haiti is to work with the workers, learning from Haitians about its resources and needs. We would like Sam to spend at least 5 days in Haiti. 

    Sam says about the trip:

    By the conclusion of the trip, I hope to be wiser about Haiti. I will have planted many seeds, and helped people feed and reforest their country in a small way. If my ideas are found useful there, then I will have planted those seeds as well. Perhaps through new friendships, we will be able to build stronger programs in Miami that will help Haiti.

    Risks, Challenges... and Greater Impacts!

    UPG's role in Haiti is not to fund or manage projects.  We don't even have funding for all our work in Miami yet. When Sam leaves Haiti at the end of this short trip, these projects will thrive only if there are Haitians managing and working on them.
    That doesn't mean we are turning our back on them!
    We hope that this trip will also raise awareness about what UPG can do in Miami for Haiti. We will be able to highlight the needs UPG can fill.

    We will seek the resources needed to grow UPG so that we can:
    * Create a Seed Bank and Heirloom Vegetable Seed Crops to provide seeds in both Miami & Haiti
    * Build new models of Education and Volunteerism that may be replicated in Haiti
    * Create educational materials - Video & Print - tailored for the needs of Haiti
    * Train a new generation of Haitian-American youth to serve as Leaders in Haiti
    * Maintain in contact with our counterparts in Haiti and guide them on strategy so that they continue to replicate the UPG model successfully, and connect them with future resources

    Funds

    The funds raised from this campaign would be used to cover travel and cargo expenses for the week in Haiti.  If you help us exceed our funding goal, any remaining funds will be used to help create the Seed Bank.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please spread the word. Share with those who CARE!

    You know people who care... churches and community organizations, permaculture groups and human rights organizations. Help us find the organizations and people who are able to help fund this effort to share UPG's model of engaging local Volunteers for sustainable planting in Haiti. 

    Wish Lists:

    For Haiti: UPG needs Heirloom Vegetable Seeds that are capable of surviving Haiti's tropical conditions (high temperature, high humidity).

    For Miami: You have STUFF, and we can put it to work! http://www.urban-paradise.org/wishlist
story_txt:
Can Miami help Haiti become Urban Paradise? 
With your support, the answer is YES! Miami has a unique set of resources that could be used to help the Haitian people transform their lives, their communities, and their nation. Sam Van Leer, President and Founder of Urban Paradise Guild (UPG) wants to help replicate the success of UPG in Haiti.Sam wants to bring a whole lot of Seeds to establish new Nurseries and Gardens!  About UPG
 Urban Paradise Guild (UPG) was founded in 2008 with the goal
 of creating sustainable habitat in Miami. We do so by working with land
 throughout the county and finding volunteers who are passionate about native plants, edible gardens and the future of their city. UPG's Location Adoptions involve the open-ended commitment to resolve the problems that the environment and the people experience through public engagement, knowledge, innovation, hard work, and steady pressure. 
These are the locations where UPG currently operates.



Oleta River State Park (Adoption + Nursery) 


Arch Creek East Preserve 


Amelia Earhart County Park (Garden Center & Adoption)


Lemon City (Garden Center & Region)


Vizcaya Museum and Gardens (Adoption + Nursery)


Matheson Hammock (Adoption) 


Photos of UPG at Work! 
If you don't already know UPG, we invite you to view our photos. 
There are more than 3,000 posted on Facebook showing us at work.  https://www.facebook.com/urbanparadiseguild
Additionally, UPG has been providing Seeds for use in Haiti since October 2008, with kilos of Seeds from eatable Natives and Cacao for economic development.    Replicating the UPG Model in Haiti 


We can not do this without you! 
 We would like to foster this opportunity, and provide Sam the chance to bring seeds and materials to help jumpstart gardens in Haiti. 


 The Impacts

We believe the best way to learn the realities on the ground in Haiti is to work with the workers, learning from Haitians about its resources and needs. We would like Sam to spend at least 5 days in Haiti. 
Sam says about the trip: 
By the conclusion of the trip, I hope to be wiser about Haiti. I will have planted many seeds, and helped people feed and reforest their country in a small way. If my ideas are found useful there, then I will have planted those seeds as well. Perhaps through new friendships, we will be able to build stronger programs in Miami that will help Haiti.

with our counterparts in Haiti and guide them on strategy so that they 
continue to replicate the UPG model successfully, and connect them with future resources

Funds
The funds raised from this campaign would be used to cover travel and cargo expenses for the week in Haiti.  If you help us exceed our funding goal, any remaining funds will be used to help create the Seed Bank. 


Other Ways You Can Help
 Please spread the word. Share with those who CARE! 
You know people who care... churches and community organizations, permaculture groups and human rights organizations. Help us find the organizations and people who are able to help fund this effort to share UPG's model of engaging local Volunteers for sustainable planting in Haiti.

story:
It is simple I love plants and as there is none in my office so I just want to plant one. Well maybe buy it or plant the seed – haven’t really decided yet but really need something green. 

Lots of Cash?

I know $500 sounds bit crazy for a plant but this is the minimum amount that can be fundraised on Indiegogo. So for really what I need is $10.

With this I will either go to the market and buy a plant or get a pot, some soil, and fruit with seed and plant it.

The Impact

Working in post natural disaster environment and sharing office and house with around 60 people my life is pretty stressful at the moment. So having to take care of a creature that doesn’t ask for money, support, where toilet paper is… but is grateful for water, listens and pays attention as well as produces O2 will really improve my life and my work.

On the other hand it will have positive impact on the whole community living in this house and sharing the office space.

story:
• A Good Dog! helps a child with autism connect with the world
  • A Good Dog! creates a public environment of acceptance and non-judgement
  • A Good Dog! brings autism families back together with their local communities
  • The world will be a better place with more Good Dogs in it.
  • More puppies = More Good Dogs = Change the world. Simple canine calculus.

    Orbiting Autism

    In 2002, our son, Elliot was diagnosed with autism. Since that time, we've tried just about every prescribed remedy to help alleviate his symptoms. Our breakthrough came when we learned the power of personal connection through acceptance -- you know, that thing that dogs do naturally and unconditionally.  As lifelong dog lovers, we decided to get Elliot an autism service companion.  When his dog, Orbit, came home it changed our lives. Not only did Orbit help mediate Elliot's disability, but when together as a team in public Elliot and Orbit positively changed the environment wherever we went. Both of these things are really big deals for a family living with autism -- game changers. So big that we were inspired to start a non-profit organization to help other families like ours.
     

    Good Dog! Autism Companions was born in 2011. We have provided service dogs for 16 families and because of their success stories we have a wait list that's getting longer and longer. The high demand for our companion dog program has called for a new model of support. The goal of this campaign is to help launch this new model by getting a new crew of puppies in training so we can start to provide more trained service dogs to more families in need with shorter wait time. Currently, it takes about 18 months to 2 years -- That's just too long. So please join us by contributing and becoming part of our pack. Together we can make this world a more loving and welcoming place for everyone.

    What We Need - More Puppies in our Pack

    Our goal is to get funding for 10 new furry recruits to enter our Puppy Program - $50,000. Our per puppy costs include breeders fees, medical, training, food and supplies, transportation, program management and insurance. It adds up fast.

    All funds raised in this campaign will go toward our service dog training and placement programs regardless of whether our goal is reached, stretched, or not...so you can be sure your contribution intent will be honored by us. 

    Wags! Recognizing Your Generosity. Thank You!

    Our amazing Part of the Pack Perks - AKA our "high value human treats" will make you wag, for sure. They could even make you beg for more...we hope they do! 

    Let's Celebrate #GivingTuesday Together

    We have a day for giving thanks -- Thanksgiving. We have two days for getting great deals -- Black Friday and Cyber Monday. Now, we have #GivingTuesday, a global day dedicated to celebrate the spirit of generosity and charitable giving. On Tuesday, December 2, 2014, charities, families, businesses, community centers, foundations, and students around the world will come together for one common purpose: to celebrate generosity and to give back.

    By contributing to the Good Dog! #GivingTuesday #UNselfie Perk, we will help you show the world how you support children & families living with autism and their canine companions! Just email us your #UNselfie and we will share it with all of our Twitter, Face Book and Instagram followers. We will also include your #UNselfie on our Wall of Thanks website page. It's like your big, hearty, enthusiastic, digital, party BARK during this special day of the year.
     

    Our Founders' Story


    We believe that all children and families living with autism deserve to be accepted and connected in our world .. . and Good Dogs can facilitate this for them. We truly live our mission and love sharing it with the world.

    Our Autism Community's Challenges

    The most recent statistics for the incidence of autism published by the Center for Disease Control (CDC) in 2014 show that 1 in 68 children born in the US is now affected. That is an increase of 30% in just two years. Clearly, this has become an unstoppable epidemic that needs to be addressed from many angles. Because there is still no known cause or cure for autism, and each child affected presents symptoms differently, trying to function in our world can be a very frustrating experience for the child.

    These are actual comments made by total strangers toward autism families out in public with their child with autism and no Good Dog!by their side:
    Kid: “Mom, what’s wrong with that kid?” Kid’s Mom: “Nothing a little discipline won’t fix.”  I    “Your child needs an exorcism.”  I   "If I ever acted like that in a store, my mother would have beat me.”
    There are too many living with autism having to deal with this today. We are encouraged when judgment and condemnation forthcoming from strangers
    is transformed into acceptance and connection when a Good Dog! enters
    the scene.

    Our Solutions

    Our goal is to bring the benefits of the human/canine relationship to children and families living with autism so they can experience a higher quality of life. We
    facilitate this by honoring the uniqueness of each person, dog and community we serve to insure the long-lasting bonds we create together are infused with
    integrity, positivity and love. Today, we have 16 Good Dogs in service and 13 families approved and waiting for their new companions. 

    A companion dog provides a bridge for a child with autism to connect with the world. Studies have shown that autism service dogs in the home reduce stress hormone levels in children with autism. Parents are reporting many other benefits of these faithful, hard-working companions as well.

    Giving is Good, Dawg - Our Need for Funding Help

    Good Dog! Autism Companions is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that relies on charitable giving to support our cause. We ask all families who get approved for a Good Dog! to fund raise half the costs of their program in their local spheres. This has created an amazing outpouring of support for our Good Dog! families. It's reconnecting them with their communities in a very special way -- we could not be happier that we have ignited this spirit of giving in so many places.

    This model has served us well as a start-up, but now due to our minimum fund raising requirements needed in order to acquire a puppy on a family's behalf, they are having to wait too long to get their fully trained service dog. High demand for our services called for a new model. By starting a reserve team of puppies in training, we can begin to reduce lead times and expand our program to accommodate even more families in need. That's why we need your help.

    WOOF!! Other Ways You Can Help

    • Help us make some noise about our campaign to get the word out
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • Forward to a corporate sponsor contact who might align with our cause

    FAQs

    Autism can be a confusing and convoluted condition to understand. We know this firsthand. We hope we explained it for you above so that you could understand some more about what children and families living with autism are going through. In addition, we hope we provided you with an understanding for how an autism service dog can help. Below, we've included some frequently asked questions just in case you want to know more:

    1. How do you train your dogs?

    We use the Bergin University of Canine Studies methodology that uses only positive reinforcement. We start socialization of our puppies early on, then teach basic training, then advanced training. During the last few months we add in any specific skills that our dogs must learn to meet the needs of their unique child companion.

    2. What can a service dog do for kids with autism?

    Studies have shown that autism service dogs in the home reduce stress hormone levels in children with autism. Parents are reporting many other benefits of these faithful, hard-working companions as well. Here are more of the life-enhancing experiences that can be attributed to owning a companion dog: calming, social, communication, companionship, independence, and quality of life. For more detailed information, please refer to "Our Solutions" section above. 

    3. How is an autism service dog different from other service dogs?

    Most people are familiar with the concept of the service dog through their experience seeing those with physical disabilities where a working dog can provide help with mobility and/or vision. An autism service dog is utilized to mediate the disability by acting as a social bridge, providing sensory input, aiding in redirecting and focusing, as well as offering unconditional love with constant companionship. Autism Service dogs have also been referred to as SsigDogs, which stands for Social and Sensory Signaling Dogs.

    4. How much does an autism service dog cost?

    There is a cost associated for a service dog provider to perform all functions necessary to finish a fully trained dog for a specific person in need. Depending on the size of the organization and complexity of the services they are providing, these costs can vary widely. Industry range is from $10,000 up to $50,000 per dog.

    Some larger non-profit organizations raise all money necessary and can provide dogs almost cost-free. Most organizations ask recipients to help fund raise either part or all of the costs involved to provide their service. At Good Dog! we share the fund raising responsibilities with our families. Our families are required to raise 13,000 and our organization raises the other 13,000, so together we cover the cost of each dog. We offer our families fund raising coaching and tools to help them meet their goal and have been very encouraged by the support the families receive from their communities! 

    5. Why does it cost so much?

    Autism service dogs need to be specifically and carefully bred, trained, and matched  to be most effective with their team partners. Families receiving service dogs should also be specifically and carefully trained and matched with their dogs :) To be successful an organization should employ expert multidisciplinary teams in both the canine and autism arenas.   

    6. How much do families have to pay for a dog?

     See # 4 above

    7. How do I get a Good Dog?

    Sign up for a free chat. We consult on everything in an unbiased open dialog. After we both decide that a Good Dog! program would be of benefit, we get the ball rolling. Schedule a Free Chat here: gooddogautismcompanions.schedulista.com

    8. Why do you give the dogs nicknames?

    We must state first that we reserve final naming of all Good Dogs for the child receiving their companion. We believe that when the child and family name their dog it aids in the bonding process. But, since our matching process occurs well into a puppies training period, meaning we do not know who will be best matched with whom quite yet, we have to call the little fur balls something. And besides, it's just plain fun coming up with their nicknames!

story:
Help restore Hat Creek to its original glory. California Trout’s 3-year restoration project on Hat Creek is now in its second year and great progress has been made but we need your help to raise $25,000 to fully fund the project, match a grant received from Orvis, and ensure that Hat Creek is a vibrant ecosystem and fishery for generations to come.

Background

Reports from the early 1900s suggest that Hat Creek was once California’s premier spring-creek fly fishing experience. By the 1960s, however, the fishery collapsed due to invasive, non-game fish and heavy angling pressure. In 1968, CalTrout founders and CA DFW led a major effort to restore wild trout populations. These efforts were remarkably successful, and in 1972, Hat Creek was designated as the state’s first Wild Trout Management Area -- a major paradigm shift away from hatchery supported fisheries. But in the early 1990s, conditions began to deteriorate again due to heavily degraded streambanks, unrestricted cattle grazing, and a collapse of native aquatic vegetation.

In 2012, CalTrout secured the largest restoration grant in the organization’s 40-year history. This funding is helping to support a substantial, three-year project that began in the summer of 2013.

Project Goals 

• Restore wild trout populations to over 5,000 fish per mile with at least 30% of trout greater than 12 inches.

• Re-vegetate 6.3 acres of riparian area with assemblages of native plants, shrubs, and trees (5,000 plants).

• Restore 1.5 miles of in-stream habitat conditions with cover and shelter for wild trout.

 

The Work to Be Done  

In Year 1 of the project, CalTrout was focused on finalizing plans. Specifically, the Hat Creek Riparian Restoration Plan and the Hat Creek Geomorphic Assessment and In-Stream Habitat Plan. Thesetwo reports identify the key issues affecting the ecological health ofthe Wild Trout Area (WTA) and lay out detailed plans for restoration.

On-the-ground restoration work began in April 2014 and the work will carry through to the fall of 2015. The project consists of five major conservation, recreation, and cultural resource protection strategies:

  1. In-stream habitat restoration
    Restore 1.5 miles of in-stream habitat using large tree structures anchored on the banks and placed strategically in the stream channel
  2. Riparian and streambank restoration
    Re-vegetate the riparian corridor—over 6 acres or 1.5 miles of river—and stabilize stream banks with over 5,000 native plants, shrubs, trees, and grasses
  3. Recreation improvements
    Maintain and improve 1.5 miles of recreational river trail, re-locate existing parking area to protect streambanks, restore historic Carbon Bridge with a pedestrian bridge and establish an interpretive kiosk
  4. Pit River Tribal work force training and employment
    Engage the Pit River Tribe in the stewardship and restoration of their ancestral lands on Hat Creek with 20 seasonal restoration jobs, weekly conservation training opportunities (stream-bank restoration), and meaningful education opportunities about Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) of the Illmawi people.
  5. Hat Creek Youth Initiative (HCYI)
    Develop the next generation of conservationists and natural resource professionals by engaging 30 underserved youth and Pit River Tribal Youth in restoring 3 miles of the iconic Hat Creek Wild Trout Area.

Check out our Hat Creek Restoration Project website and blog to get more information. 

Our Awesome Partners 

  

Here's Where You Come In

While a good majority of the project funds have been secured, CalTrout is relying on donations from individuals like you to raise $25,000 and get us to the finish line.

The donations raised through Indiegogo will help to fund:

  • Those 5,000 plantings we talked about above
  • Building the Carbon Bridge and interpretive kiosk
  • Educating and training the Pit River Tribal youth to be the next generation of conservationists and natural resource professionals 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word. Share on Facebook, blogs, tweet #HatCreek. Make some noise and help us reach our goal!

CalTrout founders and CA DFW led a major
effort to restore wild trout populations. These efforts were remarkably successful, and in 1972, Hat Creek was designated as the state’s first Wild Trout Management Area
-- a major paradigm shift away from hatchery supported fisheries. But in the
early 1990s, conditions began to deteriorate again due to heavily degraded streambanks,
unrestricted cattle grazing, and a collapse of native aquatic vegetation. 
In 2012, CalTrout secured the largest restoration grant in the organization’s
40-year history. This funding is helping to support a substantial,
three-year project that began in the summer of 2013.
Project Goals • Restore wild trout
populations to over 5,000 fish per mile with at least 30% of trout greater than
12 inches.

• Re-vegetate 6.3 acres
of riparian area with assemblages of native plants, shrubs, and trees (5,000
plants).
• Restore 1.5 miles of
in-stream habitat conditions with cover and shelter for wild trout. The Work to Be Done  In Year 1 of the
project, CalTrout was focused on finalizing plans. Specifically, the Hat Creek Riparian Restoration Plan and
the Hat Creek Geomorphic Assessment and
In-Stream Habitat Plan. Thesetwo
reports identify the key issues affecting the ecological health ofthe Wild Trout Area (WTA) and lay out
detailed plans for restoration.
On-the-ground restoration work began in April 2014 and the work will carry through to the fall of
2015. The project consists of five major conservation, recreation, and cultural resource protection strategies: 

In-stream habitat restorationRestore 1.5 miles of in-stream habitat using large tree structures anchored on the banks and placed strategically in the stream channel


Riparian and streambank restorationRe-vegetate the riparian corridor—over 6 acres or 1.5 miles of river—and stabilize stream banks with over 5,000 native plants, shrubs, trees, and grasses

Recreation improvementsMaintain and improve 1.5 miles of recreational river trail, re-locate existing parking area to protect streambanks, restore historic Carbon Bridge with a pedestrian bridge and establish an interpretive kiosk


Pit River Tribal work force training and employmentEngage the Pit River Tribe in the stewardship and restoration of their ancestral lands on Hat Creek with 20 seasonal restoration jobs, weekly conservation training opportunities (stream-bank restoration), and meaningful education opportunities about Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) of the Illmawi people.


Hat Creek Youth Initiative (HCYI)Develop the next generation of conservationists and natural resource professionals by engaging 30 underserved youth and Pit River Tribal Youth in restoring 3 miles of the iconic Hat Creek Wild Trout Area.

Check out our Hat Creek Restoration Project website and blog to get more information. Our Awesome Partners 
   
Here's Where You Come InWhile a good majority of the project funds have been secured, CalTrout is relying on donations from individuals like you to raise $25,000 and get us to the finish line.The donations raised through Indiegogo will help to fund:
Those 5,000 plantings we talked about above
Building the Carbon Bridge and interpretive kiosk
Educating and training the Pit River Tribal youth to be the next generation of conservationists and natural resource professionals 
Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us spread the word. Share on Facebook, blogs, tweet #HatCreek. Make some noise and help us reach our goal!

story:
Tandem Festival

20 - 22nd June 2014 @ Hill End, Oxford


So what’s the deal?

Pan-european, intimate and inspiring, Tandem is a brand new festival, starting this year at Hill End, Oxford. Tandem Festival will showcase a diverse range of musicians and performers, alongside workshops, documentaries and talks promoting community projects and eco-living, all whilst making as little environmental impact as we can. Set in Hill End's stunning 63 acres site, the festival will bring together music lovers of all ages to listen, learn, and dance together.  

At Tandem Festival, listening is key. Our acoustic performance spaces, from barns to yurts, will bring you closer to the music, enabling the rediscovery of sound without large amplification. Our performers are coming from across Europe, with acts including Sophie ter Schure, Jack & The Arrows, and Little Shoes Big Voice. 

Exploring the possibilities of European mobility, we're inviting our performers and our audience to join in the celebration by bike if they can! To facilitate this, we're organising bike convoys from around the UK and Europe - keep an eye on our Facebook page closer to the time if you'd like to join us, or even lead a convoy yourself!

  Environmentally, the festival will serve as a medium to inform and teach about key environmental issues such as food waste, recycling, climate change, and energy production and consumption. Speakers and documentaries will focus on these topics throughout the festival, whilst workshops will facilitate learning in a fun, hands-on environment!  


Where will your money go? What are our ideals?

The more we raise, the better the festival! Here are just a few of our aims and ideals:

  • We are looking to commission a local artist to create a bike rack for Hill End
  • We want to help push the campaign for a bike path to Hill End
  • We want to ensure all bands are reimbursed fairly
  • We want to build compost loos for Hill End from upcycled timber
  • We want to ensure we leave Hill End's land in the tranquil and healthy state that we found it
  • We want to gather together knowledgeable and inspirational speakers on sustainability
  • We want to get all festival food from local producers

Importantly, Tandem is a not-for-profit venture, we will plough any profit back into the Hill End site and into ensuring Tandem's future.


The Impact?

Tandem Festival wants to work together with the Hill End site and festival goers to create a lasting legacy. Our range of workshops mean you won't just leave with incredible memories, but also a whole range of useful skills and knowledge - from mending and up cycling clothes, through fixing bikes, to understanding more about sustainable living and about the importance of living ecologically.  

The festival isn't just a one-off party, we are creating an event that will keep running for years to come, and we want to enable more and more people to enjoy the environment through Hill End's amazing work. 


Pre-Festival Events

The festival will be running from the 20th to 22nd June 2014 but if you can’t wait till then, why not come along to one of the pre-festival events and get stuck in!   

  • Community group gathering [Sunday 16th February 2014, 4-6pm @ Turl St Kitchen, Oxford]
  •  Fundraising cycling adventure between Paris and Oxford [March 2014]; 
  • Cosy warm-up gig [March 27th 2014 @ Hill End];
  •  Help to prepare, plant and harvest a festival vegetable bed at Cultivate's farm [March to June 2014]; 
  •  Help build the compost toilets at the festival and learn all about how they work [May to June 2014].


Who Are We?

Niko is coordinating, fundraising, promoting, programming and more for Tandem Festival. He is a sound engineer, musician and keen cyclist. He first thought of organising a festival upon his return from 5 month of cycling round Europe recording artists (Record-and- Ride). Now, after two years of working freelance and coordinating one-off original events, with his new sound and events production company (Upcycled Sounds) and a fantastic team the festival idea is coming to fruition!

Nina is helping to organise, promote, fundraise, network to make the first ever TandemFestival happen! She worked for 2 years in film production and currently works in sales, marketing, recruitment and business development with the farming co-op Cultivate Oxford and in management at the natural health centre Eau de Vie. Herbs are already being grown at Tandem Festival beds at Cultivate to make sure the festival’s food is tasty and local!

Dot is helping with fundraising, promotion, some of the eco-friendliness and many other organisational bits and bobs for Tandem festival! She also coordinates Abundance Oxford, a community group working on local food, food redistribution and food wastage... and plans are on the simmer for Abundance to facilitate a pop-up Disco Soup tent at Tandem!

Kat is helping out with fundraising and getting the word out about Tandem festival! In her spare time Kat is a PhD student in Evolutionary Biology, and helps coordinate primary school outreach for the Oxford Zoology department.

Alex is a general chippy, builder, mover and shaker! He’s a serial festival-goer and has also worked at SGP and Wilderness – he’s done everything from building stages to managing traders, site traffic, info tents and knows all that important on-the-ground festival know-how. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Let your friends, family and random strangers know about us via Facebook, Twitter, or good old word of mouth. Every bit of publicity counts!

Want to volunteer? Got a good idea for a workshop? Just want to say hi? Drop us an email at admin@tandemfestival.com

story:
I am Charlotte Anthony.  I have created 7 food forests and 650 gardens for community

I am Charlotte Anthony.  I have created 7 food forests and 650 gardens for community members in Eugene, Oregon over only a 5 year period.  While traveling in India farmers I met told me about severe water problems.  They have to either do dry land farming or dig new bore wells every 2 years.  The rainfall is continuing to decrease.   In some areas dry land farming is no longer working.  To alleviate the water crisis the Indian government is paying farmers for the labor, the manure and for the seedlings to entice them to plant trees.  The farmers do not feel that they can afford to plant trees because they take a long time to yield.  I believe to be really sustainable our practices need to pay the farmers a living wage so they can grow food.  To this end I have developed practices of interplanting crops with the trees which will yield money in the first year and will, along with the fruits of the trees, produce a significantly increased income for the farmers once the trees start bearing.  The farmers I am talking to in our target area love the idea.   They want to see it to believe it.

We are helping farmers who do not have water to grow food.  Many of the farmers in India have learned that they can grow hybrid vegetables, hybrid trees, with chemicals and export these for what they consider reasonable sums of money.  With desertification they no longer have the water resources to do this.  The methods the farmers have been told will give them more yield take 3-4 times the amount of water.  We are showing them how to get slightly less yields on the main crop by using permaculture and natural farming methods, but get more money overall by doing intercropping.  Another part of our program is to create awareness and  demonstrate the benefits of reservoirs, swales, key lines, to restore ground water and rainfall.  There are many steps to this process so see our web site if you want to know more.

Our goal is to have 100 farmers participating in our program before the monsoon starts in June, 2014.  We are offering them seeds which they pay it forward when their own seeds come in.  We are offering to buy their crops for a premium above what they can get from the local markets because they are organic.  We have found a report by an NGO stating that 6 x 6 meter ponds have worked for restoring ground water in 2 acre plots.  It seems that there is a history of these methods working in the past, so the farmers seem eager to start these water conservation practices.  

1)   To do this we need to outreach to the local farmers who have water problems. We need to work with governmental agencies,  NGO’s and local community organizations to find out who these farmers are.

2)   We will set up a marketing arm which will contact potential organic suppliers, meaning the farmers who are too poor to use chemical fertilizers, and see if they need our help to increase their economic base.

3)  We have found several animated videos regarding ground water recharge which we will show to the farmers. 

4)  We also will hire artists to make posters for our campaign.

a.   One set of posters would show what trees they can plant which will recharge the groundwater and yield with dry land farming and cultivation needs.

b.  Another set of posters for the economic benefits of growing each particular tree.

c.  A third set of poster for the additional economic benefits of intecropping with that tree and diversity from planting with other trees.

d.  A fourth set of posters for how to increase water levels. 

The monies we need are:

Labor for creating 60 posters………………………….. . . . . . .1,000                              

Materials for 60 posters…………………………………………..  500

Salaries for coworkers…………………       …………… ……..4,500

Setting up a tree nursery including rent for 3 months. . . . . . .4,000

Total expenses……………………………  ………              …10,000

           http/www.handsonpermaculture1.org

In India there have already thousands of suicides due to farmers losing their land. Without our work, there will be many millions of starving people as well as more farmer suicides.  This desertification is worldwide, involving more than 90% of the earth's surface.   One advantage to working in India is that the farmers here are desperate and once they see the model will work not only for the water, but will give them a living wage, they will incorporate it immediately.  Our organization which is only months away from forming an NGO has many local people involved who will carry on the work and spread it throughout India and we hope the world.  We are working with ways that are inexpensive to install, increasing the likelihood of them going viral.  So contributing to this project you will significantly impact desertification as well as contribute to the sovereignty of Indian farmers, the Indian population in general and support a model of that will work for watering a world that is desperate for it.

Isn’t it amazing that trees which are in themselves one of the most beautiful offerings of nature are also integral to the water cycle.  What a magnificent example of stacking functions to tree the deserts and at the same time bring back the water to the earth now experiencing desertification.  You helping this project is the beginning.

If you forward this indiegogo offering to your friends and acquaintances you will know that you have contributed to the awareness of the relationship between desertification and starvation, and the awareness of a solution, one farmer at a time...
