Deep Thanks and Gratitude!

story:
Hi everyone!! - Ciao a tutti!!

(in fondo trovi la spiega in italiano!!)

T-shirts!!

Why are we here?!

This campaign is a little gift to a great person.
I never thought that one day I would meet one of my heroes, and so I'd love to give this moment an even greater meaning. On October 15, Serj Tankian will be playing in Milan, Italy. I've bought a special ticket that should grant me access to the backstage and a little chat with Serj. Thinking about what I could do or say to him, in order not to seem dull, this idea came up:

  • I scream in a System of a down/Serj Tankian tribute band called Toxiciteam.
  • Sometimes I help a Swiss humanitarian organization called Espérance Acti.
  • If there's one thing I learned from Serj Tankian, is to love and help other people.

So we (the team and me) connected the dots and here we are. We'd love to give Serj's name to a well in South Vietnam, in order to give water to, at least, 45 people who need it.

What are YOU doing here?!

Espérance Acti needs 300 CHF (nearly $320 or €250) in order to project, build and manage a well. With every single dollar you give, you're participating in a simple but lifechanging and lifesaving project, in Serj's name.
If we reach the goal, a new well will be built, and I will smile to Serj Tankian while presenting him the result of this campaign. We're sure it would be a little surprise to him (and I've always thought that surprises are the true spring of pure joy) and that he would appreciate your effort in this.
Each and every extra dollar (apart from those covering Indiegogo fees, shipping and production costs) will go into other Espérance Acti projects, like building schools or bridges (8000 CHF for a little bridge, something more for a school, how far do you think we could go?!).

What do you get?!

If you're here, you already have our gratitude, but we'd love to be sure you get what you deserve, for helping us trying to make this world a better place. Here on the right you can see a list of gifts that will state that you took part in this little but great project. And here's what happens when the campaign ends:

  • All fundings will go to Espérance Acti, in order to build a well (or two, or more!!).
  • We'll ship you or contact you in order to personally give you your gifts.
  • You'll show off your philanthropy with stickers, caps and t-shirts. When people will see you and ask you "what's that?!", you'll have a great story to tell and much love will be given to you :).

We know that showing off what you do with your hearth is not the right thing, but we think that this would just be a way to get people involved and aware of how much you can change the world with so little effort.
We know that the perks are high, but here's how we calculated the levels:
gadget production cost + shipping + 10 dollars to Espérance Acti

You don't have money?!

We know this is not a great moment, for a fundraising campaign, and the way Indiegogo works is why we're almost at ease asking you money (we'd never do that). You can make the difference just spreading the word on the internet and in real life:

  • Talk to people about this campaign.
  • Share this page online with the tools Indiegogo gives you!
  • Share the warm sensation of quenching somebody else's thirst, with a dollar or little more!!
  • Smile, and when you'll be asked "why that?!", you'll have a great story to tell and much love will be given to you :)!!!

Thanks, thanks and thanks again!!!!!

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Perché siamo qui?!

Questa campagna è un piccolo regalo a una grande persona.
Non avrei mai creduto che un giorno avrei potuto conoscere di persona uno dei miei eroi, così vorrei dare a questo momento un significato ancora maggiore. Il 15 ottobre, Serj Tankian suonerà a Milano. Ho acquistato un biglietto speciale che dovrebbe permettermi di andare nel backstage a chiacchierare con Serj. Pensando a cosa avrei potuto dire o fare, perché quell'incontro non risultasse banale, m'è venuta un'idea:

  • Urlo in un tributo ai System of a down e a Serj Tankian che si chiama Toxiciteam.
  • A volte aiuto un'associazione umanitaria svizzera, chiamata Espérance Acti.
  • Se c'è una cosa che Serj Tankian m'ha insegnato, è di amare e aiutare gli altri.

Perciò è bastato unire i puntini. Vorremmo (il Team e io) che un pozzo in  Vietnam del sud portasse il nome di Serj, così da dare acqua ad almeno 45 persone che ne hanno realmente bisogno.

Che ci fai TU qui?!

Espérance Acti ha bisogno di 300 CHF (circa €250) per progettare, costruire e gestire un pozzo. Con ogni singolo euro, partecipi a un semplice ma splendido progetto che salva delle vite... in nome di Serj.
Se si raggiunge il traguardo, verrà costruito un nuovo pozzo e io potrò sorridere a Serj Tankian mostrandogli il risultato della campagna. Siamo certi che sarà una piccola sorpresa per lui (e ho sempre pensato che le sorprese siano la fonte prima della gioia più pura) e che apprezzerà i vostri sforzi.
Ogni euro extra (tolti i costi di gestione di Indiegogo, di produzione dei gadget e spedizione) andrà in altri progetti di Espérance Acti, quali la costruzione di scuole o ponti (bastano 8000 franchi per un piccolo ponte, qualcosina in più per una scuola, fin dove potremmo arrivare?!).

Che ci guadagni?!

Se sei qui, hai già tutta la nostra gratitudine, ma vorremmo essere sicuri che tu riceva in cambio ciò che meriti, per averci aiutati a rendere migliore questo mondo. Qui a destra troverai una lista di gadget che confermeranno la tua partecipazione a questo piccolo grande progetto. Ed ecco cosa accadrà a fine campagna:

  • Tutti i fondi andranno a Espérance Acti, per la costruzione di un pozzo (o due, o ancora di più!!).
  • Ti spediremo il premio che hai scelto, o ti contatteremo per dartelo di persona.
  • Potrai andare in giro mostrando il tuo impegno filantropico con adesivi, cappellini e magliette. Quando la gente ti vedrà e ti chiederà "che è?!", avrai una bella storia da raccontare e ti verrà elargito un sacco d'amore :).

Sappiamo che sbandierare ciò che si fa col cuore non è la cosa giusta da fare, ma crediamo che in questo caso sarebbe solo un modo per rendere partecipi e coscenti le persone di quanto poco basti per fare un'enorme differenza e cambiare questo mondo.
So che le offerte sono alte, ma ecco come abbiamo calcolato i prezzi:
costo di produzione del gadget + spedizione + 10 dollari a Espérance Acti

Nun teng terrise - Gh'ho mia dané - Nun c'ho spicci - Quai schei?!

Sappiamo che non è un gran momento per una raccolta fondi, ma Indiegogo ci rende il chiederti soldi, un po' più sopportabile (non lo faremmo mai). Puoi fare la differenza, semplicemente passando parola online o nella vita reale:

  • Parla a chiunque di questa campagna.
  • Condividi online questa pagina con gli strumenti messi a disposizione da Indiegogo!
  • Condividi l'avvolgente sensazione di dissetare chi ne ha realmente bisogno, con un euro o poco più!!
  • Sorridi e, quando ti verrà chiesto "che c'è?!", avrai una bella storia da raccontare e ti verrà elargito un sacco d'amore :)!!!

Grazie, grazie e grazie ancora!!!!!

story:
Short Summary

The Lookout Mountain Conservancy was founded in 1991 as a way to help protect the natural beauty on Chattanooga's iconic mountain.  Our mission is to protect Lookout Mountain's scenic, historic, and ecological resources through conservation, advocacy, recreation and education, for current and future generations.  Lookout Mountain spans Tennessee, Georgia, and Alabama with its 93 miles.  This 1 mile-long connector trail is the missing piece that will create 140 miles of continuous trail.  

This conservancy is dedicated to community engagement, we like to get the people out to the land!  Five years ago, a partnership was formed with The Howard School.  The freshman come out to the land for experiential learning opportunities, and all students are welcome to apply to the Howard Intern and Leadership Program.  The LMC is able to hire young men and women from The Howard School to maintain the trails and the land of the Conservation.  Doing so allows these students to gain a job (something that is very hard to do as a 14 or 15 year old), learn job skills, and have greater financial stability.  The staff of the LMC are dedicated to offering support year round to the students, encouraging them to stay in school, connecting them with internship opportunities and resources, and giving a listening ear when needed.

This trail will be built over the two weeks of their winter break.  This will not only provide them with a full time job over winter break, but will help keep them busy, and help them learn new skills as they will be joining a professional trail builder. 

What We Need & What You Get

EVERY DOLLAR WILL BE MATCHED up to $9000!!! Help us reach our goal!

The funds for this campaign will pay for the contracted professional trail builder, the supplies, and will help towards paying the students.  

  • $16,000 - Professional Trail builder with use of Excavator 
  • $1,700 - Will be spent towards the paychecks of the Howard Interns for the project 
  • $300 - Will be spent towards tools

To help show our appreciation for your support we would like to offer some perks for your contributions:

  • $10 - Lookout Mountain Conservancy sticker
  • $25 - LMC T-shirt and sticker
  • $50 - LMC Hat or Visor, and previous perks
  • $100 - LMC Sweatshirt, and previous perks
  • $250 - LMC fleece or vest, and previous perks
  • $500 - Trekking pole/stick, and previous perks
  • $750 - 4 Tickets to the annual Shrimp Boil Fundraiser, and previous perks
  • $1000 - 4 hours of yardwork, provided by 4 interns and 1 staff (within 25 miles of Chattanooga), and previous perks

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to help in other ways beside making a financial donation, please help us spread the word!  If you're in the Chattanooga area, consider volunteering your time to help with the trail!  Contact Ashley: email: ashley@lookoutmountainconservancy.org  phone:423-424-3882

story:
Greetings ~ We are a 22 year husband and wife team, inspired with the vision to create and share the hospitality of a loving and nurturing natural retreat sanctuary... for the purpose of re-awakening, educating, restoring, living, celebrating and bonding Humanity's harmonious relationship to the Natural world. 

'New Eden Sanctuary' Inc. is an established environmentally conscious non-profit Arizona corp. [501(c)(3) pending], in support of this vision and purpose. We intend, with your help, to purchase the location, now for sale, which we have chosen AND WHICH HAS CHOSEN US for 'New Eden Sanctuary's purpose. Please click the link below and let us introduce you now, to this amazing, historic, Arizona ranch.....  http://sodaspringsranchaz.com/sodasprings_booklet.pdf 

  Exterior of lodge and one of 2 ponds


We require your help, to raise $7,000,000 for purchase.  ($6,500,000 for the main parcel, $250,000 for purchase of road easement; required by contract, plus approx. $3,250,000 for initial 2 years start-up, operating and development costs.)


The intended 'Home' for 'New Eden Sanctuary' please click the link below...

http://sodaspringsranchaz.com/sodasprings_booklet.pdf is an oasis of 134 generously watered acres set amid lush irrigated pastures, a year round warm mineral spring, ponds and wetlands, with over 3/4 mi. of creek side frontage. The land is rich loam "rested" soil, with warm Arizona sun, perfect for our abundant organic fruit orchards and food gardens, which will be served to guests of the lodge, sold to local markets and shared with local food banks. The area itself, is a very sacred and spiritual place, with ancient history of indigenous, native cultures, some claiming it as their "Place of Emergence" from the enormous, nearby ancient, natural Well, named in more recent history as "Montezuma's Well". The intended land for 'New Eden Sanctuary' borders right next to National Forest Service and Montezuma's Well and is blessed with the waters of one of the seven sacred "off-spring" coming from this 'Great Mother Well' ("Niewa" in Hopi). The "ranch's" history enters in the late 1800's, it's founder's naming the quaint local town known as Rim Rock, which is a short 15 minute drive to the nearby scenic "mecca" of Sedona. All of this, accessed just off the I -17 freeway, an easy 90 minutes from metropolitan Phoenix. 

  Interior of 10 room, 5000 sq. ft. lodge 


This dear place has been privately owned for decades. We delight in sharing and serving the community and the earth, offering 'New Eden Sanctuary' as a place of land preservation and nature conservancy, a place of healing and peaceful respite, a sweet and hallowed place to assemble, offering supportive hospitality for summits, retreats, events, classes, celebrations and communion. Our friendly and knowledgeable 'New Eden Sanctuary' "team" will serve to provide a welcoming, environmentally conscious, sustainable, renewable ecology demonstration and education model, while exploring the frontier of "zero point free energy" ecology. We will serve as Location Hosts for Unification of Cultures and Community, inviting the sharing of Truths, Wisdom and Creativity. We are passionate, in particular, to invite and encourage "hands-on" eco-education and historical site lore for children, creating ancillary "field trip" support for schools and offering equestrian therapy and kid's camp opportunities for groups. 

YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS WILL HELP MAKE 'NEW EDEN SANCTUARY' TANGIBLE AND AVAILABLE TO BE SHARED WITH HUMANITY ~ CREATING AND INSPIRING A WORLD OF REVERENT AND RESPECTFUL CONSCIOUS EARTH STEWARDSHIP FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS TO COME! THANK YOU FOR CONTRIBUTING WHAT YOU CAN NOW! 

***If, for some reason, we don't reach our goal THIS TIME, we guarantee your contributions will go toward the fruition of our 501(c)(3)non-profit standing; (contributions may be retroactive accordingly).... grant writing services, fund raising events, and all remaining funds will be saved and accrued for "homesite" purchase. 

re: "PERKS".....  ALL OF YOU ARE CHERISHED BY US AS "FAMILY" AND WE WILL MAKE ARRANGEMENTS TO THANK YOU AND WELCOME YOU PERSONALLY ~ NO MATTER WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION $$ AMOUNT :o) 

PLEASE, IF YOU HAVEN'T ALREADY, TREAT YOURSELF AND SEE THE WEBSITE LINK http://sodaspringsranchaz.com/sodasprings_booklet.pdf 

PLEASE CONTRIBUTE WHATEVER FUNDS YOU ARE INSPIRED TO GIVE, AND PLEASE USE THE "INDIEGOGO SHARE TOOLS" AND SHARE THIS INFORMATION IN EVERY WAY YOU CAN! THANK YOU and MANY BLESSINGS!

WE EAGERLY LOOK FORWARD TO SEEING YOU IN 'NEW EDEN SANCTUARY'

With warm regards,

Jeremy & Julie Miller on behalf of 'New Eden Sanctuary' inc.
story_txt: Greetings ~ We are a 22 year husband and wife team, inspired with the vision to create and share the hospitality of a loving and nurturing natural retreat sanctuary... for the purpose of re-awakening, educating, restoring, living, celebrating and bonding Humanity's harmonious relationship to the Natural world. 'New Eden Sanctuary' Inc. is an established environmentally conscious non-profit Arizona corp. [501(c)(3) pending], in support of this vision and purpose. We intend, with your help, to purchase the location, now for sale, which we have chosen AND WHICH HAS CHOSEN US for 'New Eden Sanctuary's purpose. Please click the link below and let us introduce you now, to this amazing, historic, Arizona ranch.....  http://sodaspringsranchaz.com/sodasprings_booklet.pdf   Exterior of lodge and one of 2 pondsWe require your help, to raise $7,000,000 for purchase.  ($6,500,000 for the main parcel, $250,000 for purchase of road easement; required by contract, plus approx. $3,250,000 for initial 2 years start-up, operating and development costs.)The intended 'Home' for 'New Eden Sanctuary' please click the link below...http://sodaspringsranchaz.com/sodasprings_booklet.pdf is an oasis of 134 generously watered acres set amid lush irrigated pastures, a year round warm mineral spring, ponds and wetlands, with over 3/4 mi. of creek side frontage. The land is rich loam "rested" soil, with warm Arizona sun, perfect for our abundant organic fruit orchards and food gardens, which will be served to guests of the lodge, sold to local markets and shared with local food banks. story:
Help Northern Plains Make Big Oil Toe the Line in Montana!

Northern Plains Resource Council is a grassroots conservation and family agriculture group that organizes Montana citizens to protect our water quality, family farms and ranches, and unique quality of life. 

The Northern Plains Oil and Gas Task Force is a group of Montanans from across the state working to ensure Montana's long term health by putting community interests above oil and gas profits and empowering communities to not get run roughshod by oil and gas companies.

Northern Plains is laying the groundwork for our grassroots efforts to influence the Montana legislature to require oil and gas development happens in ways that protect our water and communities.

Statewide legislation will protect landowners in and near the Beartooth Mountains, Glacier National Park and the Bakken, where widespread development is already occurring.

Extreme Energy Development:  With each passing year, oil and gas development is becoming more extreme in efforts to maximize profits at all costs. This fast paced development leaves everyday Montanans and their communities to pay the price by polluting water, contaminating soil, and fracturing communities. Montana residents and landowners are being put at risk so oil and gas companies can increase profits. 

With your support we can win protections in the 2015 Montana Legislature and make sure oil and gas development doesn’t harm Montana!

This is a David and Goliath situation and Goliath is only getting bigger.

What Is Needed:

Decision makers need to hear from more than just the oil companies. In order for MONTANA CITIZENS (YOU!) TO HAVE A VOICE AT THE LEGISLATURE we need to do and pay for several things!

  1. Hauling citizens to the capitol:  We need to rent buses or vans to bring landowners and other Montanans from rural parts of the state to Helena to participate in Lobby Days.  Montanans in the Bakken who are facing the most serious impacts from oil and gas development can live more than eight hours away from Helena. Carpooling gives people the opportunity to lobby who may otherwise be unable. —$1,250 
  2. Organize a public actionat the Capitol during the Legislative session to show legislators that Montanans from across the state support protections for landowners in oil and gas producing regions.—$3,000
  3. Present our Oil and Gas Roadshow about  land and water protections to communities across the state to build support for laws that ensure oil and gas companies do it right and protect Montana's land, water, air, and communities. —$1,500. 
  4. Create and run radio ads in oil producing counties to spread the word about landowner protections that are possible through the legislature.—$2,500
  5. Arm members of the public with information - we need to get the truth out about threats and solutions to citizens across the state. —$5,000
  6. Get out action alerts to landowners and citizens encouraging them to contact their legislative representatives in support of landowner protections. Generating calls, emails, letters and visits will keep the pressure on the legislature so that they don’t cave in to big oil.  —$3,000
  7. A picture is worth a thousand words - take aerial footage of oil and gas development and waste disposal sites to show to legislators so they can’t hide from the truth. Seeing what is happening will help legislators have a better understanding of the scope and impact of oil and gas development in Montana and the need for landowner protections. We have a member willing to do this at an extremely discounted rate! —$500

Total: $16,750 

What Your Gift Will Do:

You can help protect Montana and make the oil and gas industry pay its fair share to prevent and/or minimize the “train wreck” rampant, uncontrolled oil and gas development can wreak.   

With your help, we can make sure that oil and gas companies in Montana toe the line and do it right. 


    Other Ways You Can Help

    Become a member of Northern Plains Today!

    Northern Plains is made up of dues-paying members. Our members vote for our leaders, or can run for leadership positions themselves. It is our member leaders who govern the organization, and who represent it publicly before the news media and in testimony before public bodies.

    Northern Plains has a long track record of success on a wide variety of issues that impact family agriculture, land, water, air, and communities. 

    Join us today and make a difference on the decisions that affect your life!

story:
What We Need & What You Get

We were fortunate enough to receive a Recreational Trails Grant for $19,500 but now we need to raise $12,500 to match it. Every dollar donated will directly benefit conservation and improvement.  If we happen to beat our goal for the Clam River restoration work, we'll use the additional funds to improve the 10,000 acres of publicly accessible BNRC land. When you donate you'll receive some great perks from the BNRC and Outdoor Life magazine, including a shout out in an upcoming issue! 

Nature lovers, hunters, anglers, photographers, scientists, historians – there’s something here for everyone on this great property.  Please make a gift – you’ll help us put feet on the Clam!


Who We Are 

Founded in 1967, the Berkshire Natural Resources Council is a non-profit land conservation organization working throughout the Berkshires in Massachusetts to protect threatened lands. The Council has always worked to protect any landscape, (big or small) that provides sensational views, clean water, fresh air or recreational opportunities.

Our current project of improving Clam River in Sandisfield, Massachusetts has been in the works since 2011. BNRC and its volunteers recently conserved and opened two linear miles of land along the beautiful river and its accompanying wild valley. We're launching plans to build a 2.5 mile trail from one end of our property to the other that will visit massive boulder fields, mature forests, 150-year old cellar holes and millworks, and a cold, cascading river. But we need your help to increase access and the visitors experience! 


Your Footprint

Every year people from all over the country visit the picturesque Berkshires  to enjoy scenic views while they hike, ski, hunt, fish, mountain bike, or snowshoe.  Your donation will directly benefit the people who come from far and wide, as much as it does he people who come from just up the road. 
Sandisfield, Mass, where Clam River is located, is one of the smaller towns in the Berkshires. Despite hosting tanneries, mills, a logging operation and even Merino Sheep farms the area's landscape has remained relatively untouched.  It's a ideal spot for nature lovers to enjoy, but we need your contribution to do so. 

Other Ways You Can Help

While we need your help, we'd also love your support! Want to plan an outdoorsy trip to the Berkshires? Want to get involved? Visit our website to learn more about our work and us: http://www.bnrc.net/.  You can also follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/BerkshireNaturalResourcesCouncil

story:
Locations such as Cairns, Orange, Burnie, Victoria, Adelaide and Darwin in Australia are set to become major mining centres as Global Aquatica has solved major road blocks to mining in those areas, opening them up to extensive resource development and employment.

Global Aquatica has developed technology that is proven to remove the acid mine drainage pollution caused by mines and is campaigning through this crowdfunding site for funds to build scaling plants. These areas have abundant valuable mineral resources, however, they cannot be mined due to the contamination of the rainfall.

Unfortunately, all the minerals in these areas exist in sulphide rock that turns the rain into sulphuric acid called acid mine drainage. The acid dissolves the metals in the rock into the water resulting in toxic water that cannot be released to the environment. The mines quickly become inundated with lakes of sulphuric acid they cannot get rid of and are abandoned. Currently, the treatment costs are prohibitive, preventing mining from proceeding.

Global Aquatica is the only company in the world that can totally remove acid mine drainage pollution.

Using our ground breaking, patent technology, Global Aquatica converts the contaminants into valuable resources for use by the global electronics and high technology industries. Essentially, we are mining the acid mine drainage. The sulphuric acid is converted into high quality water which can be used by agriculture or the mines for low cost processing. The mining costs are slashed, the environment is protected, abundant high quality water is available and mining brings high, long term employment to these local areas.

We intend 'mining' the acid mine drainage from the existing and abandoned mines in the areas of Cairns, Mt Isa, Orange, Central Victoria, Western Tasmania, Adelaide and Darwin, creating new long term mining centres. It will also significantly reduce operating costs at the existing mines and open up 50% more mineral wealth to Australia and globally, previously inaccessible.

Global Aquatica intends commencing operations in the mines and also starting construction of local extractive metallurgy plants and regional engineering offices in each area within 2 years. As Global Aquatica's policy is to purchase locally, we will be starting with the communities where we receive the most support.

Global Aquatica’s engineers have already proven the technology and it has been extensively used on sites around the world. The next step is to assess the process by treating each type of pollution at each abandoned mine. Global Aquatica intend placing scaling plants on each site, after which the mines have indicated they will purchase a full size plant. Global Aquatica will then commence operations in each area, resulting in a mining boom in each area that will result in significant long term employment growth.

Three of Global Aquatica’s engineers formed the company to ensure the technology is available after their coal mine industry parent company closed. Global Aquatica has launched this crowd funding campaign to empower the local communities to improve their economies by funding the construction of the scaling plants. Once these have assessed the technology on each site, the mining companies will fund full size plants, kicking regional resource development in that area into high gear. Donations are needed to fund the construction of the plants.

To help the engineers at Global Aquatica create jobs in your area, donate at our crowdfunding site now.
The Global Aquatica team.

After our coal industry parent company went out of business, the engineering team formed Global Aquatica to carry on the good work.

The team consists of very experienced engineers and technicians.

Samuel Costin is the Managing Director of Global Aquatica and he brings over 30 years water engineering experience to the company. He has founded several successful water engineering enterprises and has extensive experience in the design and engineering of the Global Aquatica technology.

Eric Longamn is the Project Manager of Global Aquatica. He is a civil engineer with over 28 years experience in water engineering and water enterprise management with extensive experience in wastewater treatment engineering.

Harry Windsor is a 30 year experienced and qualified mechanical engineering technician. He has extensive experience in the building, operation and servicing of mechanical and process equipment.

 

How will the funds be used

We will start by building small scaling plants and installing and operating them. We will start with the Queensland site on the video, then on other sites around Australia. As we prefer to use local suppliers, We will be starting with the communities that show us the greatest support during this campaign.

If you just can’t support healing the planet, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask people you know to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Check out the Indiegogo share tools to make this easier.

Stretching the project.

The more support we receive the faster we can get started on creating employment in Cairns, Mt Isa, Orange, Central Victoria, Melbourne, Western Tasmania, Adelaide and Darwin.

Perks and rewards

We can’t express how happy we are to get your support. As we are the only people in the world who can do this, and we can't do it without this crowdfunding support, the pollution doesn’t get cleaned up without your support. We also have a great range of perks that are relevant to the ongoing ‘healing our planet’ project and the part you play in it as a contributor. Check out the Perks on the right hand side and the images of the perks in the gallery.

We are really excited about the limited offer for the great looking, fitted T shirts Hoodies and prints with very tasteful artwork by the renown artist John Sabraw  That guy is really talented. Check out his artwork at Http://www.johnsabraw.com.

None of these perks will be available after the campaign ends, so grab them while you can.

Thanks for supporting Global Aquatica. Together we will Heal our Planet and bring employment to regional areas of Australia.

Thanks for supporting Global Aquatica. Together we will Heal our Planet and bring employment to regional areas of Australia.

story:
The Colores del Priorat Project

My name is Sara Dochow. I have an MFA in painting from Portland State University, Portland, OR. This project involves working with flora from the Montsant and Priorat regions of Catalunya, in Spain. It is the anti-Monsanto campaign, focusing on sustainable, environmentally conscious practice, while cataloging results and gathering local lore. Contributions would help fund research and development, specifically a written account of the project.

What I Need & What You Get

I am one year in to this project. Contributions would go towards an official catalog/research journal to be developed as a book, developing and experimenting with flora to create the Priorat Paintbox, gathering local lore regarding flora as dyestuff. I am looking to fund a years worth of research and development, materials costs, enlisting local youth in the discovery process, with an agent already on line to work with me into generating a text. If I don't reach my full goal, I will use whatever funds this idea generates to continue the project. Please see my perks below for a wide range of contribution options.

The Impact

We are living in a world where the chemical dominates. My question is, how do we use the resources available without negative impact to our environment? I am working with winemakers who use biodynamic and organic practices, extracting unique colors from each vineyard, as well as harvesting flora throughout the area. The enotourism in the Priorat would be enhanced by another view of what this region offers. Unique colors, unique to the Montsant. This project is a model for regional explorations. If you are a champion for the environment, support the arts and crafstmanship, and love color, join me in this project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Help this project by getting the word out, sharing with your friends.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Rachel Liston and I'm currently a freshman attending the University of Texas at Austin. This summer I'm going to New Zealand through ISV to work on an environmental conservation project.

  • Volunteers who have served on environmental management projects have planted tens of thousands of fruit trees and vegetable gardens, conducted forest clean-ups and informed communities of their local environmental issues and how to protect their surroundings.

What We Need & What You Get

  • I need $3,395 to pay for the entire trip.
  • This trip will get me to first of all expand my horizons and fulfill my dreams of traveling and second of all help to keep New Zealand beautiful.

The Impact

  • My project is valuable as it will help to save the earth in this polluted time.
  • My trip leaves on July 23 and I come back on August 20, giving me a full four weeks to help keep the beauty of New Zealand alive.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't contribute, please help get the word out about International Student Volunteers! You can like the Facebook page or visit the website and tell your friends.

story:
Hey everyone.
It's Jacob Abraham and I'm 15. I'm running a 10k race and need to raise
money for The Ezra Abraham To Life Foundation (named after my brother who died from cancer) and I  and was wondering if you would please sponsor me.

PS thats a picture of my brother Eddie holding me when I was a baby

 

The Foundation is responsible for building 3  Living Rooms so far for cancer teens. The 3 locations are 1) the Hospital for Special Surgery 2) Monmouth Hospital 3) Jersey Shore  (see website)

www.tolifefoundation.org

  

“The Ezra Abraham’s To Life Living Room is a wonderful example of how one family linking their name to ours can make a true difference in the lives of patients every day. We know that our patients are receiving an extra level of care because of the To Life Foundation’s support of The Children’s Hospital at Monmouth Medical Center, and we are very grateful for this amazing space and gift.”
-Daphne Halpern, Vice President, Monmouth Medical Center Foundation

 

 

The Ezra Abraham To Life Foundation provides quality-of-life support to youths with cancer or other life-threatening illnesses during their medical treatments. Recognizing the importance of family in the lives of patients, the Foundation also provides families and loved ones with appropriate resources and emotional support.

story:
THE DREAM:

We think it's time to rethink development in Palestinian refugee communities, and that means green, sustainable, and grassroots solutions.

Refutrees has developed 3 innovative projects, and our dream is to raise $30,000 for the development of each of them as the first step towards a sustainable and green future for displaced communities.

THE SEEDS: Our Story

Refutrees was born after years of research conducted by founder Lamya Hussain in Palestinian refugee camps across the West Bank and Lebanon. Through her work, Lamya was able to identify the failure of current development and aid programs to end donor-reliance. Further, Lamya’s research identified the gaps in building local livelihoods for Palestinian refugees in the long-term.

In an effort to address these issues of unemployment, lack of land and food sovereignty, and deteriorating community health, Refutrees was created in order to integrate green innovation with the development of projects fundamentally based on the needs of local communities in collaboration with local resources. With a small dedicated team made up of Lamya, Pauline, Theo, Shatha, and Bridie (read more about us below!), a wealth of research, and endless amount of hope, Refutrees is now ready to grow its seeds!

THE SPROUTS: Our Plan

We have 3 interconnected, extensively researched pilot projects (detailed below): the Rooftop Garden Project, the Agro-Knowledge Exchange, and Eco-Art Palestine.

Each project responds to the needs of Palestinian refugees by developing local capacities in the long-term by incorporating community aspirations and principles. Our ideas are eco-friendly, sustainable and replicable, and rooted in helping Palestinian communities achieve their socio-economic and human rights.

THE WATER AND SUN: Your Help

Our pilot projects each require $10,000 from start to finish, for a total of $30,000. Our budget is made up of:

  • Cost of materials
  • Consultancy charges,
  • Travel, administrative and legal costs.

Any left over funds, if any, will be used to produce locally made merchandise such as t-shirts and tote bags, as a means of continuing our fundraising efforts after this campaign is over.

We have planned our funding campaign in such a way that allows our three  projects to help each other through a growing network and wellspring of resources. This allows us also to move forward even if we (heaven forbid!) don’t reach our $30,000 goal – all the money raised will go directly to starting up the projects as well as help us explore other fundraising avenues.

THE FRUITS: What YOU Get

We want you to feel all the love that's going into these projects. To thank you for your support, we have an amazing set of thank you gifts -- "perks" for your generosity!  Here are some of the highlights from our friends!

  • Our friend Dr. Naif Mutawa has donated 200 limited edition issues of "The 99" comic book series. Check out his TedTalk here: http://bit.ly/bneH5B
  • A recipe guide for a 3-course Palestinian meal, from the kitchen of Refutrees' Mama Hania!
  • One of two signed prints by Josh MacPhee of JustSeeds Artists' Cooperative! Have a look HERE and HERE   OR a copy of the JustSeeds Political Art Book "Signal" preview HERE
  • One of two ORIGINAL ARTWORKS by esteemed artist Muiz: 1) 'Gaza Zaytoun' see HERE or 2) 'Palestine', see HERE
    Each piece is 12x16 in, mounted plyboard. Both prints were featured in Muiz's London exhibition, Nuclear Nuqta, which opened the 2012 Nour Festival of Arts at Leighton House Museum in Kensington - covered by the Huffington Post, BBC, and The National, among others

And MANY MORE! Read them all on the side PERKS panel on this page.

THE ROOTS: The Background

Displaced for over four decades, Palestinian refugees remain in a state of ‘temporary’ with limited access to resources, restricted mobility, and uncountable barriers to livelihood. While Palestinians have continued to find innovative ways to maintain their communities and spirit, the daily struggles around health, environment and livelihood have been key motivations in establishing Refutrees. Living conditions are poor and include: poor diet and nutrition, access to clean drinking water, sanitation and sewage, garbage disposal and poor overall environment, security and safe spaces for children, and so on. Existing local capabilities continue to be exhausted, and Palestinians remain skeptical of the donor programs that have thus far failed to resolve the roots of their current circumstances. Nonetheless, Palestinians remain resilient and continue to identify with innovative solutions towards the gaps in development in their communities -- amongst which are green solutions with a sustainable future. 

In creating projects that are reflective of the needs of the community in a manner that is creative, eco-friendly and premised on the dissemination of knowledge and resource building, Refutrees is hoping to work collobaratively with local communities to create grassroots change.

The Pilot Projects:

 

1. The Rooftop Garden Project

PROBLEM = Donor reliance, deteriorating health, and lack of food sovereignty. Palestinian refugees, as the longest standing refugee community in the world, continue to be reliant on international humanitarian assistance programs in such a way that restricts their independent development.

SOLUTION = Rooftop gardens that provide Palestinians the capacity to grown their own organic food in dense and restrictive spaces. The rooftop garden addresses the lowering health status of Palestinian refugees by getting to the root of the problem: access to good food. More importantly, it is both sustainable and reflective of Palestinian socio-economic and political rights. Furthermore, it is an investment into the continually deteriorating environment of the camps given poor infrastructure, lack of permits for repairs, and vulnerability to systematic violence.

Most of the refugees we will work with were previously landowners and farmers, which gives the project an even more important dimension. In aiming to adapt to their current context while also reviving farming concepts in the urban context, Refutrees will engage second and third generation refugees with the roof-top garden project by providing training and assistance.

2. Agro-Knowledge Exchange

PROBLEM = Even under highly restrictive circumstances, Palestinian communities are truly innovative and creative. However, lack of resources and other structural barriers to education and enterprise stand in the way of the long term development of community innovation and capacity building.

SOLUTION = Refutrees is rooted in the principles of resource-sharing and the exchange of knowledge, and all our projects are developed with the intention of being replicable and sustainable. The Agro-Knowledge Exchange program is one such way to do this, as it aims to connect Palestinian refugees with scholarship opportunities abroad to explore agricultural, environmental and social enterprise studies and programs. In collaboration with Palestinian communities, Refutrees will carefully select enthusiastic individuals that are community leaders and innovative thinkers that will ensure the continuity of projects such as the rooftop gardens.

We are working with potential universities that might be interested in sponsoring Palestinian refugees in short and long-term scholarship programs. Given the unique context of Palestinian refugees it is important to invest in the training and development of such capacities to improve current and future living conditions.

3. Eco-Art Palestine

PROBLEM = Palestinian children, particularly refugees, are the most vulnerable to systematic violence and arbitrary detention under their circumstances. Lack of  safe playing spaces means that Palestinian children are consistently denied of not only special protection, but their basic right to play, in accordance with Convention on the Rights of the Child.

SOLUTION = An eco-art playground made of recycled materials. In partnership with Ugandan eco-artist Ruganzu Bruno Tusingwire, he project addresses the issue of limited access for children to play. In designing a playground that is eco-friendly and utilizes recycled material, Refutrees is consistent in its approach to intertwine art-creativity-environmental awareness. This space will be unique, replicable for future projects, and will have a real impact on the community. Also, in a truly sustainable fashion, we will work with local artists and hold workshops to build capacity for future projects.

Tusinwire's project will be based on his design of a community amusement park made of recycled materials in Uganda, which won him the 2012 TEDxSummit Award.

 

Meet the Dream Team:

Founder and CEO: Lamya Hussain

Lamya is currently a PhD Candidate at SOAS with the Department of Development Studies. She holds a Masters in Environmental Studies and a Graduate Diploma in Refugee Studies. Lamya is currently developing original research that explores agriculture across the West Bank in working with Palestinian farmers. Previously, Lamya has dedicated several years researching Palestinian refugee communities across Lebanon and the West Bank. Her efforts have awarded her twice the Harold Mahabir Award for International Development.

Communications and Outreach: Shatha Al-Husseini

Shatha is a recent graduate of the University of Toronto, majoring in Political Science and Middle Eastern Studies. Her research interests include Palestinian diasporic culture, Middle Eastern art, and Transnational Social Movements. She is passionate about working in the intersectional spaces of community, art, and grassroots innovation . 

Social Media Coordinator: Theo Scheiner

Theo is currently an undergrad student at the SOAS, reading in Politics and Development Studies. His academic interests include development and humanitarian practices in East Africa. He is also interested in cultural identities and diaspora movements in Britain. A passionate social media activist,  Theo has taken a special interest in Refutrees as he puts it in his words:

“because I like working with small scale initiatives as they tend to be dynamic and have to rely on consensus and participatory approaches to grow.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t donate? No problem, we just need your love!

  1. Tweet about us @Refutrees and share our Facebook page with your networks!
  2. Know peeps that we should connect with? Potential donors or grants we should consider? Send us an email: refutrees@gmail.com
  3. Are you a writer? blogger? Get in touch. We are passionate about our ideas, we will happily work with you on an interview, blog-post, or article. We’re social. We’re green.

Your contribution will not only create a real impact in the communities we work with, but will infuse our projects with the spirit of support, optimism, and community!

 

FEATURED INTERVIEWS

PSFK "The Role of Green Projects in Displaced Communities"

MUFTAH: “Refutrees: A Better Way to do Development in Palestinian Refugee Camps with Pauline le Rolland"

GREEN PROPHET: "Refutrees Scratches Eco and Social Itches with Refugee Projects"

story:
Food crops and water supplies ruined following Cyclone Pam's devastating visit!  Kiribati children drinking contaminated water!

We Need Your Help:

  • Water is URGENTLY NEEDED in the outer islands of Kiribati, where many islands were awash with sea water from Cyclone Pam's king tides, devastating their drinking wells for the next 15 years.

  • Shipping is costly due to the remoteness of the Kiribati islands. We are looking to raise $7,000 AUD, to ship medical supplies and bulk water. 
  • Please, next time you are out having a drink with friends, donate the value of one round of drinks, so Kiribati children can drink safe clean water.    

What You Get:

  • We will send you an Island Hero certificate recognizing your support plus a link to a virtual holiday in the stunning Kiribati islands. 
  • Or for more substantial donations you can choose a perk of a Lifestraw personal water filter or a solar light. 
  • You may feel a warm glow inside knowing you have made a significant difference to the lives of these children.

                      

Cyclone Pam's fierce winds whipped up high waves that battered the tiny Pacific islands of Kiribati, flooding and damaging the Betio Hospital, the crucial inter island causeway, thousands of homes and the all important protective sea walls!

Salty sea water flooded 50% of the island land area, devastating many water wells and essential food crops like breadfruit, bab-bai (like taro) and coconut trees.

Half of this nations population are displaced and living with extreme shortages of safe clean water with severely limited food options. 


The Island Rescue Projects' volunteers do not earn wages. Our overheads or operating fees are minimal. We take your donation right to where it is needed. 

# Make a donation to help us reach $7,000 When we reach our target I will post a bizarre video clip where I drink dirty horse poop water!  

          

                                              

           1 out of every 20 babies do not survive early childhood in Kiribati. 
            

Our Impact:

Our project has been successfully instrumental in saving the lives of young babies, as well as helping children and adults with health issues.

  • Last November we donated 2 rain water tanks to Teaoraereke Village after their wells were ruined with sea water flooding over 100 homes.
  • In December of last year we participated in screening young babies and children for incidences of malnutrition on Tarawa
  • In January we donated 3 rain water tanks to villages on Marakei Island and supplied various medicines for everyday illnesses. There are no pharmacies on the islands. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please SHARE our link with all your friends and contacts asking them to support our campaign by getting the word out there and helping the I-Kiribati people to be heard.            
  • “Things are tough in Kiribati after Cyclone Pam's king tide flooding. They are desperate for clean water! They need our help. Please check out this video and Shout Kiribati a drink!  http://igg.me/p/shout-kiribati/x/68935 “                                          
  • Please take a look at our products in our website store.                                                 All profits go to The Island Rescue Project's activities in Kiribati. www.theislandrescueproject.org                                 


Where in the World are the Kiribati Islands?

 

                   


             

Tim, Crystal, Courtney, Liz and Carol Armstrong on our most recent visit

Sharing water treatment filters and medicines with the local village leaders.

A Kiribati woman scrambles to gather belongings during the ocean flooding of Teaoraereke Village on Tarawa. One of about 100 homes affected.

Sharing every day medicines we take for granted. It was like giving diamonds to the mothers of Marakei Island.                              

                   


Teaching women of Betio how to make Black African soap from local ingredients 

Medical supplies for the hospitals. Diabetes, asthma and gastro are key issues.

     islands. 
Or
     for more substantial donations you can choose a perk of a Lifestraw
     personal water filter or a solar light. 
You
     may feel a warm glow inside knowing you have made a significant difference
     to the lives of these children.

                      
Cyclone Pam's fierce winds whipped up high waves that battered the tiny Pacific islands of Kiribati, flooding and damaging the Betio Hospital, the crucial inter island causeway, thousands of homes and the all important protective sea walls!
Salty sea water flooded 50% of the island land area, devastating many water wells and essential food crops like breadfruit, bab-bai (like taro) and coconut trees.
Half of this nations population are displaced and living with extreme shortages of safe clean water with severely limited food options. 




The Island Rescue Projects' volunteers do not earn wages. Our overheads or operating fees are minimal. We take your donation right to where it is needed. 
# Make a donation to help us reach $7,000 When we reach our target I will post a bizarre video clip where I drink dirty horse poop water!  


          

                                              
           1 out of every 20 babies do not survive early childhood in Kiribati. 

            
Our Impact:

Our project has been successfully instrumental in saving the lives of young babies, as well as helping children and adults with health issues.

Last November we donated 2 rain water tanks to Teaoraereke Village after their wells were ruined with sea water flooding over 100 homes.
In December of last year we participated in screening young babies and children for incidences of malnutrition on Tarawa
In January we donated 3 rain water tanks to villages on Marakei Island and supplied various medicines for everyday illnesses. There are no pharmacies on the islands. 



Other Ways You Can Help


Please SHARE our link with all your friends and contacts asking them to support our campaign by getting the word out there and helping the I-Kiribati people to be heard.            

“Things are tough in Kiribati after Cyclone Pam's king tide flooding. They are desperate for clean water! They need our help. Please check out this video and Shout Kiribati a drink!  http://igg.me/p/shout-kiribati/x/68935 “                                          


Please take a look at our products in our website store.                                                 All profits go to The Island Rescue Project's activities in Kiribati. www.theislandrescueproject.org                                 



Where in the World are the Kiribati Islands?

 

                   




             

Tim, Crystal, Courtney, Liz and Carol Armstrong on our most recent visit




Sharing water treatment filters and medicines with the local village leaders.

 

A Kiribati woman scrambles to gather belongings during the ocean flooding of Teaoraereke Village on Tarawa. One of about 100 homes affected.


Sharing every day medicines we take for granted. It was like giving diamonds to the mothers of Marakei Island.                              

                    Teaching women of Betio how to make Black African soap from local ingredients Medical supplies for the hospitals. Diabetes, asthma and gastro are key issues.

story:
Every child deserves a clean, green, and safe place to play.

Grant Park, once a center of crime and blight, is now a center for community gatherings in a growing and changing neighborhood. Complete with a brand new playground, this park is set to become a great asset to all residents--young and old. As part of the 2015 Neighborhood Enhancement Program, the Over-the-Rhine (OTR) Community Council, City of Cincinnati, Keep Cincinnati Beautiful (KCB), the Cincinnati Recreation Commission, Brewery District CURC, and Playworld Midstates began a massive transformation of OTR's Grant Park located on East McMicken Avenue. The land has been cleared, a new and exciting play structure has been installed, and landscaping has begun. But there is still work to be done!

Keep Cincinnati Beautiful is seeking funds to complete the landscaping necessary to turn Grant Park into a truly "green" oasis for the OTR community. 


We need $5,000 to finish the job.

Your contribution will allow us to purchase and install the final 5 trees for Grant Park's greenspace area. These mature trees will provide shade, fresh air and an extra dose of beauty to encourage family time and playtime in this great space! These large-caliper trees will not only give the park an instant tree canopy feel, they will make the whole community healthier and more comfortable. 


Why does it matter?

"Greening" Grant Park means more than just providing something pretty to look at. Planting trees in a residential area improves air quality, reduces the physical stress of heat, increases property values, increases mental health and wellness among residents, and exposes urban youth to nature. Your contribution will have a lasting impact on the residents of Over-the-Rhine for generations to come and to the mission of Keep Cincinnati Beautiful. 


A Strong Reputation

Keep Cincinnati Beautiful is an award-winning affiliate of Keep America Beautiful. Our mission is to educate and encourage individuals to take greater responsibility for improving their community environment. 


KCB has been improving the Cincinnati landscape for over 30 years, and we're still going strong. We strive to provide programs that are based on changing behavior and cultivating community pride, and we rely on public and private partnerships to fuel our mission and programs. We focus on providing sustainable results through grassroots initiatives and work to improve not only the environment in which we live, but the quality of our lives as well.


Thank You to our Contributing Sponsors:


     Mr & Mrs Erik Lutz
     Mr & Mrs Edward Hatfield
     The Devine Group


Other Ways You Can Help


Even if you can't donate today, there are other ways to help:
  • Tell your friends! Spread the word about this campaign. Share it on Facebook and Twitter.
  • This project is only one example of how KCB is transforming neighborhoods around Cincinnati. Visit our website (www.keepcincinnatibeautiful.org) or connect with us on Facebook or Twitter to find out more!

Thank you for your support!

story:
We at  Avalanche Power Technology Limited have invented a new type of fuel cells based on Avalanche Proton Fusion. We will produce Cheap & Clean energy at any location covering any power class replacing traditional energy production in the developed economies by our carbon free technology AND supporting the spread of our technology in poor countries as it is crucial for all of us to introduce zero carbon energy technology in emerging regions too!

Experiments prove that our technology works. We are the company that has a physical theory in place that backs our approach.In order to convince further customers, investors and development organizations we aim to build a new prototype. An integrated approach of research & development including the special aspects for developing countries will consume additional 2 million Euros.

Thank you for your support and please spread our idea in your personal and/or professional network!

story:
Bandcochon (means You Pig! in kreol)  is the first social network in the world dedicated to fight against illegal wastes dumping. We started it in november 7th, 2011 for preserving our beloved island : La Réunion.

It’s both a participatory social web site to locate the “junk” and an indispensable tool offered to administrations in charge of wastes collecting which benefit of a geo-located database to track down junks on their territories.

Band Cochon is a original creation by 2 anonymous citizens (politicless and not business oriented) based on a web framework at the web technology egde.

In december 2012, Band Cochon had the pleasure to announce its little brother birth in Martinique Arété Sa ! (means Stop It!)

If we appeal to you it’s because we invest on our own savings in bandcochon.re and the first release almost ruin us.

Today, we wish to have enough money to do more and so to give all possible time to develop Band Cochon.

We also wish to allow to emerging countries who may not have the financial means of Western countries a fair use of Band Cochon.

We never wanted to create an association or crying for gourvernemental money because we want to keep our freedom and keep our movement away from politic.

Thanks to your participation and once the web site improvement and the mobile app created, we wish to allow to emerging countries who may not have the financial means of Western countries a fair use of Band Cochon.

We offer you to take knowledge of our project in detail by continuing the web site visite.

We thank you to take a little bit of your time to read us and for your interest.

 
You can find more information on the Band Cochon crowdfunding website. (both English and French)
You can see our work on www.bandcochon.re (in French but our user can read and write English).

story: I am a student at santa barbara city college and i am currently taking permaculture and for projects in sustainability we agreed it was the right choice to make a permaculture garden next to the culinary dept where we can provide natural and organic fruits, vegetables, and herbs. it will be a very educational location with its innovations with technology and keeping the simplicity intact. the goal is $10,000 which will build the garden and sustain it till we can offer events to help fund to keep the garden up and running. The garden will also include a stage to facilitate a class lecture and for our entertainment a musical performance will also take place on this stage. We have gotten the privilege to schedule a live musical performance by local bands to celebrate the opening to our public educational permaculture garden. This garden will benefit everyone in our school and will be open to visitors from all over, so they can experience the efforts of hard working dedicated students. Along with live performances their will be live silk screening on tshirts sale to help support the permaculture gardens future finances. So we are asking for your support to build this dream for a better tomorrow. A better life with healthier options and knowing that every one of us has the power to grow what we put in our bodies. To give the students of Santa Barbara city college the chance to taste the flavors of naturally grown fruits, vegetables, and herbs grown steps away. Give new skills that are essential for the students in the culinary dept. they are taught the necessary steps of catering to plants as you pick through our garden. Our goal is 10 thousand dollars and that will build our public permaculture garden and culinary green house.that money would also go to build our lecture and music stage so we can begin providing music to hundreds of the locals and students of Santa Barbara. We are offering custom made tshirts from a local company offering to help support the cause for a better tomorrow. We are also offering the opportunity to adopt a plant bed and have a section of the garden named after you or a company you would like to represent. We thank you for taking a moment to look at a family you can be a part of and a garden you can pick from if we reach our goal. Well have the clearance from the board and president of Santa Barbara city college to build the garden. We also have the site located for the garden and is ready to be built. The moment we hit 1 thousand dollars we will start Bokashi buckets and collect as much food waste from the cafeteria to help create the freshest soil for the permaculture garden as we build. We have the shovels in hand but our next step needs your support. Help us create a hands-on-garden any of our sponsors and guests can visit.

story:
The project story: 

In March, Laura and I will be volunteering alongside Jose DeCoux and his team for four to six weeks in a Rainforest Information Centre (RIC) conservation project. We will be deep inside the 17000 acre Los Cedros Conservation Reserve. This reserve is situated high in the Andean cloud forests of Ecuador and is largely unspoiled wilderness full of rare, endangered and as yet, unclassified species. 

Statement from Jose DeCoux

The Los Cedros reserve project was started at the end of the 1980´s when the first properties were purchased from farmer/colonists by a coalition of small environmental organizations.  A few years later an Ecuadorian NGO was cobbled together to cover the expanding administrative needs of several dispersed projects, including important initiatives with support from Australia and the Rainforest Information Center where Los Cedros became a founding member.

The Los Cedros project was able to expand its objectives to include the 6400 hectares (17000 acres) it has today with RIC having leveraged direct support from the Australian government and FOE Sweden.  A management plan was implemented and Los Cedros was declared a Bosque Protector under protection of the Ministry of Environment. Today the reserve administration is engaged in a process to include the local communites in that management process under a program financed by the United Nations and the Ministry of Environment.

One of our long term objectives has been to forment the investigation of the life cycles in this area of importance for the conservation of world biodiversity.  Here in the reserve the first field study was conducted of the Brown Headed Spider Monkey that brought to the attention of Primatologist´s the Criticaly Endangered CITES status it received.  Hardly any investigator enters the forest here without discovering something new.

We wish to contiune monitoring the presence of the Andean Bear, our tame Mountain Lion, Ocelots, Jaguarundis, Peccaries, Brocket Dear and myiad smaller species of Bird and Beast that walk our trail system. If we are able to station camera traps on strategic cross roads this monitoring will activate an ongoing conservation program that volunteers can maintain.

For more detailed information please visit:

http://reelmotive.org/shooting-jaguars-in-ecuador/

Please Note:  

This is a project of the Rainforest Information Centre and Australian donations over A$20 are tax deductible.

US$ donations of $100 or more can be tax deductible but NOT by donating on indiegogo. Anyone who wants to take advantage of this should email johnseed1@ozemail.com.au to find out how to proceed.



Los Cedros Reserve staff, university researchers and volunteers have conducted wildlife surveys in the past to great effect. Unfortunately, the high humidity has taken its toll on the reserve's own wildlife cameras and new cameras are urgently needed to ensure regular survey work occurs. Wildlife surveys provide much needed data on animal populations, ecosystem health and help forest guardians measure conservation outcomes. 

New wildlife cameras will also ensure systematic wildlife surveys recommence in the area, specifically focusing on the areas top predator, the Jaguar. 



Gathering scientific and visual evidence of the regions biodiversity will assist Jose (below) and his team's efforts to protect Los Cedros from ever-encroaching poachers, miners and illegal loggers.

.

How the funds will be used:

100% of all funds raised will go directly to purchasing new infra-red and white flash wildlife cameras and essential accessories like rechargeable batteries and SD Cards for the Los Cedros Reserve and associated field researchers. 


The Reserve is governed by the Fundación Los Cedros, composed of local community leaders, representatives from environmental groups, and Los Cedros staff. The Reserve staff also work closely with the internationally regarded Centro de Investigacion de los Bosques Tropicales (CIBT) or Center for Tropical Forest Research.

Some of my past work:

I have used motion-sensing IR wildlife camera's inside scheduled logging areas of East Gippsland, supporting the great work of Environment East Gippsland and GECO in surveying for endangered Long footed Potoroos.



I have a proven track record in using GIS and other spatial mapping technologies for rainforest conservation here in Victoria, as a research analyst and campaigner for the Victorian Rainforest Network. Please visit the Victorian Rainforest Network website for more info on some of our successful rainforest protection campaigns.



Risks and Challenges:

The main risks are weather related, as the very high humidity can damage electronic circuits. Encroaching poachers and squatters could also pose a theft risk.

To mitigate against these risks, we will purchase new cameras that have a waterproof rating of at least IP 54 ensuring they can withstand the elements. Additionally, we plan to trial using dessicant sachets inside each unit to absorb moisture leakage over time.

To minimise theft risk, we will purchase the latest cameras which contain 940NM LED lR technology, making their IR beams invisible to human and animal eyes at night. The cameras are also camouflaged to ensure they are difficult to detect during the day.

Please Note:  

This is a project of the Rainforest Information Centre and Australian donations over A$20 are tax deductible.

US$ donations of $100 or more can be tax deductible but NOT by donating on indiegogo. Anyone who wants to take advantage of this should email johnseed1@ozemail.com.au to find out how to proceed.

Thank you for taking the time to read this.

For the Earth, 

Laura & David

story:
We are an association of nine students in engineering school. Our school is specialized in renewable energies.

We are helping poor Mexican in isolated communities by providing them free energy equipment: solar oven and solar dryer (to cook and preserve their food for free). Indeed firewood and gas are expensive; these installations allow them to make considerable savings and offer them better life conditions. Moreover they reduce enormously their emission of carbon dioxide.

So by helping us you are helping people in need and giving earth a leg-up.

Besides when we are in Mexico we teach Mexicans how to build the solar machines so that they can fix or build others on their own. We also let them instruction books.



How will your money be spent?

The Budget of the project is around 15 000€, the main of it is due to the equipment  which is quiet expensive. It is expensive because of the quantity of machines that we want to build in order to have an impact on many communities. As all these installations are given to them, we have to finance the whole equipment needed for the construction of the machines. So an amount of 1000€ would be already a great help; it could help us for example to buy wood, glass or screws. 

And if we do not reach this goal of 15 000€, money collected will be used next year by the next team of Mexisol.


Expansion of the project

The last two summers, members of the association went to Mexico, in the state of Hidalgo, to install these machines. So we hope this year gathering enough money to carry on and develop our project! Indeed Mexicans are really satisfied of what we have done there. And the fact that our project is useful for them is really a motivation for us to continue the momentum.

We stay in touch with the Mexicans thanks to a monthly skype with the president of the association Nana Ximhai, which is committed to the environment. We have got a partnership with this association which allows us to have the viewpoints on the everyday life in these Mexican communities. So that we focus on what really matters for them.

And this year we are giving the project another dimension; we are developing two others installations: solar showers and dry toilets. Mexicans submit us these demands in order to save energy and water.

We also have a new partnership with Mexico City University. This summer five students will help us and take part in the project. They will especially translate the instruction books into local dialect.


Other ways you can help

Please share this with people around you. It would also be great if you could get us in touch with a firm which might be interested with this project. Indeed firms can benefit from a partnership with our association.

Thank you for your help and your attention!

year gathering enough money to carry on and develop our project! Indeed
Mexicans are really satisfied of what we have done there. And the fact that our
project is useful for them is really a motivation for us to continue the
momentum.
We stay in touch with the Mexicans thanks to a monthly
skype with the president of the association Nana Ximhai, which is committed to
the environment. We have got a partnership with this association which allows
us to have the viewpoints on the everyday life in these Mexican communities. So
that we focus on what really matters for them.
And this year we are giving the project another
dimension; we are developing two others installations: solar showers and dry
toilets. Mexicans submit us these demands in order to save energy and water.
We also have a new partnership with Mexico City
University. This summer five students will help us and take part in the
project. They will especially translate the instruction books into local
dialect.
Other ways you can help
Please share this with people around you. It would
also be great if you could get us in touch with a firm which might be
interested with this project. Indeed firms can benefit from a partnership with
our association.
Thank you for your help and your attention!

story:
OUR STORY:

My husband and I are humbly seeking donations to help us build an off-the-grid cabin in Kentucky and rebuild our farm.  

In August we were forced off the farm where we'd been living - the farm primarily featured in the above video - and found ourselves without money and without a place to go. We poured hundreds of hours and thousands of dollars into starting a garden we now have to completely walk away from, and chalk up to a loss; a loss of nearly everything we had. Thanks to a generous offer from our mentors and fellow farmers at Bugtussle Farm, however, we now have a plot of land in Southern Kentucky - back on the farm where we interned and fell in love with farming and with each other. But as wonderful as our new land is, it is not farmable yet and needs a tremendous amount of work and most glaringly... it does not have a house. We need to get back on our feet, and now with the land to do so, all we lack is the shelter! 

All of our savings were invested in that farm and garden - all of our wedding money and everything we earned growing vegetables this year. Your donations will give us a literal roof over our heads, but ultimately help to replant the healthy farmstead we lost.

We follow only organic and biodynamic practices in our gardens. We do not use chemicals or commercial fertilizers of any kind, nor antibiotics or synthetic medicine to treat our animals. We do not grow anything genetically modified and take great pride in saving heirloom seeds and promoting diversity. Through even a small donation, by giving us a chance to rebuild, you are effectively helping to get Rough Draft Farmstead back to doing what it does best: farm healthfully.  

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET:

We don't endeavor to build anything  extravagant––the design we have in mind is roughly 750 square feet, solar-powered and wood-heated. By our estimation (with the help of some friends more experienced in building cabins), we believe the structure itself will cost between $5,500 and $6,500....but being amateurs, that's probably a low estimate.

We plan on doing this pretty much by ourselves. Not only will this save us money, but it will give us the experience of building our own home, designed for our lives and built to have as little impact on the land as possible. In return for your donations, we plan on fervently documenting the entire building process on our blog. We personally love following along with stories of those building off-the-grid cabins, and can only hope that our journey will inspire and educate others in the same way. We only wish to build a place for us to live so we may restart the farm we lost and once again provide healthy food to a small community - your donations help make that possible  

 

Anyone interested in helping out in a more tangible way is welcome to pitch in! We need all the help we can get! We plan on hosting a few work parties....and you can surely expect a homegrown meal and maybe even some homemade wine in return!

Any extra money from this campaign would go toward things like:

  • Wiring the cabin for solar electricity, preparing for when we can one day afford the panels and inverter.
  • A water system - either a pump for the old well existing on the property or a way to utilize a nearby natural spring.
  • A wood stove for heat/cooking.
  • Simply getting us back on our feet - we invested and lost everything in our first farm! Extra funds could buy things like seeds, tools for clearing the land, and money for restoring an old barn on the property.

 

THE IMPACT:

By helping us to build our cabin, you are supporting a small family and a small farm. You are directly supporting farming practices that give back to the soil rather than deplete it. You are, in effect, planting a sustainable farm. 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

We understand that not everyone can contribute financially...but that does not mean that you can't help! You can help simply by sharing our story and this campaign with as many people as possible! Get the word out! Use the tools provided by Indiegogo, and send people to our blog!  

Even the littlest amount of money, even one link to our story, even the quickest prayer or the kindest thought means so much to us.

- Hannah and Jesse.
