story:
WE HAVE REACHED OUR GOAL! The ceremony has been fully funded and has begun in Muara Tae with the hosting families doing internal and external preparations.  
You can read about the first days of the ceremony here.


You can still befriend the tribe.
 Please join us as we follow the story of the ceremony as it emerges and learn from the Dayak Benuaq people their method of shaking off despair and re-committing as a people to the ancient mandate all humans have to nourish life on earth. 


Here's how to join in:

  • Read updates on the blog and sign up for the newsletter at flamingseed.com

  • Visit our Facebook page

  • Become an ambassador for the tribe by bringing the story to your community. You can create an inquiry circle or related ritual, weekly meditation, or other event to parallel the tribe's ceremony, and we will support you to do that. Visit the resources page for ideas, and join ourambassador's circle on Facebook to share ideas and reflections with others around the world.

  • The tribe can still use funds for all kinds of needs related to protecting their forest, so if you would like to donate, please contact Jane Brunette.


________________________________________________


Could an ancient tribal ceremony stop bulldozers
from destroying this Borneo rainforest? 


The Dayak Benuaq people of Muara Tae are losing their forest to palm oil. Western-style negotiations have failed to stop the clearcutting. With bulldozers poised to take what little remains of their ancestral forest, tribal elders say their best hope is to hold a ceremony that since ancient times has been used to resolve difficult disputes and highly charged situations with great power. Because all people of the earth need the rainforest for their oxygen, tribal leaders invite you to support this ancient vow ceremony (called Sumpah Adat) to protect their forest — for everyone's sake. 

For the Dayak Benuaq, humans have a sacred contract to nurture and sustain life — it is why we were put on the earth. Their assignment as a tribe is to care for this particular rainforest. To stay in touch with this role and united in their efforts, they have always relied on ceremony. This is how they connect with each other and with the larger cosmic forces as they tune into something bigger and more fulfilling than their personal security and comfort.
 

Unlike Western methods of negotiation, their ceremonial method of conflict resolution taps into the heart and the big picture, where all involved examine their part in the conflict, reconnect to their true values and recommit to their original purpose as humans: to keep the earth in balance. The 64-day ceremony will address tensions with four neighboring villages over disputed land by creating an opportunity to inquire deeply, celebrate and feast together. The tribe will also invite company and government officials to join in this process, though tribal elders say their cooperation is not necessary for the ceremony to correct things. 

Your participation will add power to the ceremony by extending it across the globe and may help avert violence and direct confrontation between the companies and the local people. We believe that the power of our intentions working together, with a willingness to engage the company and government officials who we will encourage to attend, can change some minds and hearts on both sides of the globe so that the remaining forest can be preserved.
Skeptical? Read this


For those inspired to witness and learn from the Dayak Benuaq's process or create your own version of the ceremony with your family, friends or colleagues, please visit our Guardians of the Forest page on Facebook where we will report on what is unfolding in Muara Tae, and invite an exchange of ideas, stories and reflections. You will have the opportunity to ask questions and send messages that we will relay to the shamans, tribal elders and leaders, and we will be posting photos, videos and updates as the tribe's ceremony progresses so you can be intimately involved from a distance. Please join us in this deep exploration as we build a bridge between cultures and paradigms — for the sake of our forests and all the beings dependent on them.  

The ceremony is scheduled to begin in mid May. It will continue for 64 days provided there is sufficient financial support to allow that. We're grateful to Forest Watch, an Indonesian NGO, for generously agreeing to front the money to the tribe as we raise the funds so that the ceremony preparations can happen concurrent with this effort.


Our $15,000 goal will allow the Dayak-Benuaq tribe to:

  • Issue open invitations to all residents of five villages as well as local government officials and companies — more than 1000 people. 
  • Engage in a 64-day, time-tested way to reconnect with their deeper intuitive wisdom and purpose as a community.
  • Address current conflicts and divisions within the tribe regarding how to respond to the destruction of their home forest.
  • Re-unite with their shared mandate to care for the rainforest and keep the earth in balance.
  • Dialogue with representatives of government and palm oil companies who are willing to engage with them.
  • Invite the rest of us around the world to bear witness to this process and use it as inspiration as we explore our own responsibility and purpose in relationship to what is happening to the forests of the world.
  • Cover the expenses of our Indonesian bridge builder who will facilitate the dialogue between us and the tribe.

    Specifically, our Indiegogo dollars will enable the tribe to:
  • Cover preparation costs (including labor for creating ritual objects): $1,330
  • Acquire food (rice etc.) to supplement the villagers' donations and feed all the ceremony attendees: $105 per day 
  • Pay the traditional dues and ritual offerings to the ten shamans who will facilitate the process: $8.50 per shaman per day
  • Give offerings to honor the ancestors (flowers, leaves, baskets): $8 per day

    The daily cost of the ceremony is $198.     Our Indiegogo contributions will determine how many people can participate and how long the ceremony can last. The elders say that 64 days is what it takes, and the second half of the ceremony is essential.


WHAT IF WE ARE OVERFUNDED? That would be fantastic! It would take $750,000 to protect the remaining forest by establishing a land trust. Short of that, any funds raised beyond the $15,000 goal will be given to the leaders of the alliance of families sponsoring the event to help the local people with whatever is most needed in their effort on behalf of the forest. 

Asuy — an elder among the Dayak Benuaq — told us that it is a great boost to the spirits of the tribe to feel the eyes of the world on them, to know that we appreciate the difficult work they are doing on behalf of all of us, and that we respect and support their traditional ways.


The above short video was made by Mina Setra, a Dayak whose tribe in West Kalimantan lost their ancestral forest to palm oil in only 10 years. It powerfully conveys the emotional side of what it's like for the people to watch their home forest disappear due to outside forces. See our second update for Mina's story. 



What happened to Muara Tae?


A strained immune system —It has been said that the rainforests are the lungs of the earth, and since ancient times, the Dayak Benuaq people have acted like a healthy immune system, nurturing and protecting the forest against imbalance and disease for the sake of all life on earth — including ours. Now, with palm oil plantations encroaching on their land, bulldozing the forest without the tribe's permission and turning it into a hot, dry wasteland, it is as though our collective lungs have developed tuberculosis.

Seedlings and bulldozers — The encroachment began with illegal logging, when the hardwood trees the tribe had tended over centuries were cut and sold by private interests. As the tribe nurtures the seedlings of these now endangered trees to replant in degraded forest areas, palm oil companies push into these same forests with their bulldozers and the land goes into dispute. The decisions made by officials over disputed land have resulted in the loss of large portions of Muara Tae forest without the consent of the tribe, and compensation offered after bulldozing is absurdly small. While NGOs continue to work hard through all of this to help, without sufficient attention from rest of the world, the Muara Tae forest continues to vanish with alarming speed. 

Smart phones and gold — As if this weren't enough, with our new smartphones and laptops in need of precious metals, a mining company suspects there is gold under Muara Tae village and wants to literally dig their homes out from under them to get to it, with the promise of dangerous mining jobs in return. It's clear that for the people of Muara Tae, sitting on a gold mine isn't a cause for celebration.

A steady sense of purpose — Muara Tae's strong connection to their tradition has helped them maintain a deep conviction that their purpose on earth is to act as the guardians of this forest. For this reason, while neighboring villages have sold their ancestral lands to private interests under pressure — including some that traditionally belongs to Muara Tae — no one in Muara Tae has backed down from their sacred contract to protect the forest. At least not yet.

They can't do it alone — Because it is so difficult, time consuming and stressful to continue to fight such powerful forces, some members of the village are tempted to give in, sell their land for the pittance offered and move on in despair. Once one family does this, the conviction of the village is sure to erode and the job of forest guardians like Asuy will become even more difficult. With our support, this ceremony can reconnect the local people with one another and with their ancient mandate to protect and care for the forest, knowing that they are doing it not just for themselves, but for the good of all the people of the earth. It can also help heal the rifts between villages over disputed lands and unite them in their common interests so that as they grapple with the disappearance of their forest, the community will stay intact.


“The most remarkable feature of this historical moment on earth is not that we are on the way to destroying the world — we’ve actually been on the way for quite a while. It is that we are beginning to wake up, as from a millennia-long sleep, to a whole new relationship to our world, to ourselves and each other.”
     —Joanna Macy


What does the ceremony involve?

Taking the long view — In the initial stages of the ceremony, participants ground in the long view that includes ancestors and descendants — the generations that came before and will come after us. Through experiential ritual, they are helped to reconnect to the traditional mandate for all humans on the earth: to maintain balance. In this context, all involved make honest reports to the ancestors of their part in the conflict and destruction.

Renewing vows to protect the earth — After everyone has restored connection to their highest values, together they take a vow to protect the health of the forest and the people who live there. Traditionally, the vow is made with great reverence and life-or-death seriousness, for the ancestors are deeply offended by half-heartedness, and once the vow is made, they expect it to be kept. For this reason, people are asked to think deeply about this and only attend the ceremony if they are truly sincere in their desire to restore balance. Since spirit knows no boundaries, this goes for those in the industrial world as well who are participating at a distance.

Partnering with a greater power — If any of the invited parties decide not to participate, the ceremony goes on without them, and the ancestors and cosmic forces are called on to bring life back into balance and alignment in ways that might supercede human understanding and timelines. (In the language of AA, this is surrendering to a greater power.) Traditionally it is said that following such a ceremony, the larger forces take care of events for the ultimate good of all.


“To continue to be in good conversation over our enormous and terrifying problems is to be calling out to each other in the night. If we attend with imagination and devotion to our conversations, we will find what we need; and someone among us will act — it does not matter whom — and we will survive.” 
—-Barry Lopez


Where we come in

The people of Muara Tae are cash poor and have not been able to afford such an extensive ceremony, which requires 64 days of hosting and feeding great numbers of people. Because the ceremony is meant to benefit the whole world, and the unpaid work of these people of maintaining and defending the forest since ancient times has been for the benefit of all of us, Asuy and the people of the forest invite us not just to donate, but to participate with them in our own communities. 

Asuy said that while the ancestors gave the assignment to humans of maintaining balance, they entrust the people of the earth at a given time to devise the means by which to do this — the ceremonies and methods needed for that time. And so for those of us who have lost touch with our own indigenous roots and no longer have those practices from which to draw inspiration, the tribe offers theirs. The fate of the forests cannot be decided in a lawyer's office. We are called on to get creative and devise new rituals and methods to remind each other of our sacred purpose and to maintain awareness of the impact of our use of resources, which is not as obvious as it is in a traditional community such as Asuy’s. 

Our hope is that people in the industrial world will be inspired to use internet technology to join with this remote tribe in global, creative, ceremonial space — buoying the spirits of these guardians of the forest for the difficult work they are doing for us on the front lines, and drawing on their inspiring conviction in order to reignite our own dedication to our vital role as humans in restoring and maintaining balance for the good of the whole.



“If we knew for certain that the fate of oceans and trees, tigers and bees, and the future of the human family, depended on our willingness to turn our attention inward, tune into our bodies, and develop our capacity to feel through the layers of numbness and closure that trap our vital energy, freeze our receptivity, and disconnect us from life within and around us, would we make it a priority?”
     —Tesa Silvestre


How would you like to participate?

If you connect with the heart of this campaign, we invite you to listen inside to what most draws you. Where is your passion and interest? Here are some suggestions to get you started:

• Join our ambassadors' circle.  To share ideas and meet others who are involved on all different levels, please join our campaign Borneo-gogo ambassadors' group on Facebook. At the most basic level, we need help getting the word out, so it would be a great help if you would forward the link to this page with a personal note to friends and colleagues who might be interested, and post it to social media. This effort began out of friendship and feeling, so it is best spread in the same way.

• Inspired to do a little more? Consider writing to company managers and government officials respectfully requesting that they participate in the ceremony and reflect deeply on their own values and involvement. For a sample letter, click here. 

• Drawn to inquire in a fresh way? You can fully join in the spirit of what the indigenous people are trying to do by creating a related ritual, ceremony or inquiry with your group, church, friends or colleagues. For ideas to get you started, click here. 

• Feeling particularly moved? Why not contribute a song, poem, drawing or short video of yourself expressing from your heart why you want to help protect the forest? Or write a personal note of encouragement to the forest guardians of Muara Tae. Simply put in the comments here, and we will share. For inspiration read the story of how this campaign began with a feeling.

• Have the urge to get practical? Consider learning more about the challenges facing the indigenous people of the rainforest and doing what you can to support them. The videos and organizations listed at the foot of this page will get you started.

• Want to bring this closer to home? Consider learning about the challenges faced by indigenous people in your area. They are all on the front lines, trying to protect the earth from environmental degradation for the benefit of us all and could really use the support of their neighbors.

• Moved to deepen your connection to the earth? Asuy suggests that you get to know your local forest intimately so you can see the richness there — the plants that grow and their uses, the animals that use it as their home. We naturally protect and serve what we know and love.

“I was in a split state of incredulity where the arrogance of my smallness was saying, ‘you can do nothing’ and another part of me was saying, ‘This is killing me. I’m living a lie. I’m colluding in a system that is destroying this planet. I can’t keep doing this.’ I woke up in that moment. What I realized is that my insecurities, my inadequacies, my smallness were nothing compared to what was going on and I had a choice to live a life that was completely meaningful. And what I needed was to give myself permission to feel the truth of what was going on and if I could feel that truth, I would move into action and I would move into right action.”
—Clare Dakin

The people behind this effort:

Jane Brunette teaches and writes about meditation, spirituality and creating a soulful life in challenging times. She travels widely, living simply in cultures where this is still possible so that she can have time for deep reflection as she explores the intersection between spirituality, human culture and the natural world. Author of the poetry book Grasshopper Guru, her essays can be found on The Huffington Post and on her blog at flamingseed.com. She would like to thank Tesa Silvestre for planting the seed of this effort by gifting her plane ticket to Borneo so that she could meet the people of Muara Tae, and Clare Dakin of Tree Sisters for the inspiration to act on behalf of the trees and their guardians.

Ruwi - Ambrosius Ruwindrijarto - has worked on behalf of indigenous peoples for many years as an advocate as well as through business development and entrepreneurship. He cofounded Telapak, an environmental NGO based in Bogor, and is a fellow of Samdhana, an organization for social and environmental renewal. Ruwi is also a member of Forest Watch Indonesia  who strives for transparency and good governance of Indonesia's forestry. In 2010, he received the Skoll Award for Social Entrepreneurship and in 2012, the Ramon Magsaysay Award, which is considered Asia's Nobel Prize. He is committed to telling the stories of those whose voices are not being heard.

Acting On Behalf of:

Pesuli Lati Tana Adat Takaaq  (Caring for Indigenous Lands and Forests) is a group of families in Muara Tae dedicated to being guardians of the forest and totaling approximately 160 people. Core member families include: Asuy, Singko, Sedan, Entang, Etun, Doh, Masrani, Christian, Rawm, Ketak, Jerman, Saiman, Nyiloh, Impus, Deis, Kilo, Nok, Nawi, Endo, Matih, Juru, Saeful, Lanin, Sriansah, Dahlan, Sekam, Nggong, Mus.

WE WOULD ALSO LIKE TO HONOR the efforts of the following organizations who have been doing all they can to help the people of Muara Tae: 
The Indigenous Peoples Alliance of the Archipelago (AMAN)
Forest Watch Indonesia
Environmental Investigation Agency
Sawit Watch
Rainforest Action Network


THESE VIDEOS give more background on the people of Muara Tae
and their efforts to save their forest:
Our Forest Our Life
Muara Tae Diaries
Iceberg at Muara Tae
Empowering Muara Tae
Quest for Indonesian Palm Oil Threatens Native Communities

What would love do?

Give offerings to honor the ancestors (flowers, leaves, baskets): $8 per dayThe daily cost of the ceremony is $198. Our Indiegogo contributions will determine how many people can participate and how long the ceremony can last. The elders say that 64 days is what it takes, and the second half of the ceremony is essential.
WHAT IF WE ARE OVERFUNDED? That would be fantastic! It would take $750,000 to protect the remaining forest by establishing a land trust. Short of that, any funds raised beyond the $15,000 goal will be given to the leaders of the alliance of families sponsoring the event to help the local people with whatever is most needed in their effort on behalf of the forest. Asuy — an elder among the Dayak Benuaq — told us that it is a great boost to the spirits of the tribe to feel the eyes of the world on them, to know that we appreciate the difficult work they are doing on behalf of all of us, and that we respect and support their traditional ways. The above short video was made by Mina Setra, a Dayak whose tribe in West Kalimantan lost their ancestral forest to palm oil in only 10 years. It powerfully conveys the emotional side of what it's like for the people to watch their home forest disappear due to outside forces. See our second update for Mina's story. What happened to Muara Tae?A strained immune system —It has been said that the rainforests are the lungs of the earth, and since ancient times, the Dayak Benuaq people have acted like a healthy immune system, nurturing and protecting the forest against imbalance and disease for the sake of all life on earth — including ours. Now, with palm oil plantations encroaching on their land, bulldozing the forest without the tribe's permission and turning it into a hot, dry wasteland, it is as though our collective lungs have developed tuberculosis.Seedlings and bulldozers — The encroachment began with illegal logging, when the hardwood trees the tribe had tended over centuries were cut and sold by private interests. As the tribe nurtures the seedlings of these now endangered trees to replant in degraded forest areas, palm oil companies push into these same forests with their bulldozers and the land goes into dispute. The decisions made by officials over disputed land have resulted in the loss of large portions of Muara Tae forest without the consent of the tribe, and compensation offered after bulldozing is absurdly small. While NGOs continue to work hard through all of this to help, without sufficient attention from rest of the world, the Muara Tae forest continues to vanish with alarming speed. Smart phones and gold — As if this weren't enough, with our new smartphones and laptops in need of precious metals, a mining company suspects there is gold under Muara Tae village and wants to literally dig their homes out from under them to get to it, with the promise of dangerous mining jobs in return. It's clear that for the people of Muara Tae, sitting on a gold mine isn't a cause for celebration.A steady sense of purpose — Muara Tae's strong connection to their tradition has helped them maintain a deep conviction that their purpose on earth is to act as the guardians of this forest. For this reason, while neighboring villages have sold their ancestral lands to private interests under pressure — including some that traditionally belongs to Muara Tae — no one in Muara Tae has backed down from their sacred contract to protect the forest. At least not yet.They can't do it alone — Because it is so difficult, time consuming and stressful to continue to fight such powerful forces, some members of the village are tempted to give in, sell their land for the pittance offered and move on in despair. Once one family does this, the conviction of the village is sure to erode and the job of forest guardians like Asuy will become even more difficult. With our support, this ceremony can reconnect the local people with one another and with their ancient mandate to protect and care for the forest, knowing that they are doing it not just for themselves, but for the good of all the people of the earth. It can also help heal the rifts between villages over disputed lands and unite them in their common interests so that as they grapple with the disappearance of their forest, the community will stay intact.
“The most remarkable feature of this historical moment on earth is not that we are on the way to destroying the world — we’ve actually been on the way for quite a while. It is that we are beginning to wake up, as from a millennia-long sleep, to a whole new relationship to our world, to ourselves and each other.”      —Joanna Macy
What does the ceremony involve?Taking the long view — In the initial stages of the ceremony, participants ground in the long view that includes ancestors and descendants — the generations that came before and will come after us. Through experiential ritual, they are helped to reconnect to the traditional mandate for all humans on the earth: to maintain balance. In this context, all involved make honest reports to the ancestors of their part in the conflict and destruction.Renewing vows to protect the earth — After everyone has restored connection to their highest values, together they take a vow to protect the health of the forest and the people who live there. Traditionally, the vow is made with great reverence and life-or-death seriousness, for the ancestors are deeply offended by half-heartedness, and once the vow is made, they expect it to be kept. For this reason, people are asked to think deeply about this and only attend the ceremony if they are truly sincere in their desire to restore balance. Since spirit knows no boundaries, this goes for those in the industrial world as well who are participating at a distance.Partnering with a greater power — If any of the invited parties decide not to participate, the ceremony goes on without them, and the ancestors and cosmic forces are called on to bring life back into balance and alignment in ways that might supercede human understanding and timelines. (In the language of AA, this is surrendering to a greater power.) Traditionally it is said that following such a ceremony, the larger forces take care of events for the ultimate good of all. 

“To continue to be in good conversation over our enormous and terrifying problems is to be calling out to each other in the night. If we attend with imagination and devotion to our conversations, we will find what we need; and someone among us will act — it does not matter whom — and we will survive.” —-Barry Lopez


Where we come inThe people of Muara Tae are cash poor and have not been able to afford such an extensive ceremony, which requires 64 days of hosting and feeding great numbers of people. Because the ceremony is meant to benefit the whole world, and the unpaid work of these people of maintaining and defending the forest since ancient times has been for the benefit of all of us, Asuy and the people of the forest invite us not just to donate, but to participate with them in our own communities. Asuy said that while the ancestors gave the assignment to humans of maintaining balance, they entrust the people of the earth at a given time to devise the means by which to do this — the ceremonies and methods needed for that time. And so for those of us who have lost touch with our own indigenous roots and no longer have those practices from which to draw inspiration, the tribe offers theirs. The fate of the forests cannot be decided in a lawyer's office. We are called on to get creative and devise new rituals and methods to remind each other of our sacred purpose and to maintain awareness of the impact of our use of resources, which is not as obvious as it is in a traditional community such as Asuy’s. Our hope is that people in the industrial world will be inspired to use internet technology to join with this remote tribe in global, creative, ceremonial space — buoying the spirits of these guardians of the forest for the difficult work they are doing for us on the front lines, and drawing on their inspiring conviction in order to reignite our own dedication to our vital role as humans in restoring and maintaining balance for the good of the whole.
“If we knew for certain that the fate of oceans and trees, tigers 
and bees, and the future of the human family, depended on our 
willingness to turn our attention inward, tune into our bodies, and 
develop our capacity to feel through the layers of numbness and closure 
that trap our vital energy, freeze our receptivity, and disconnect us 
from life within and around us, would we make it a priority?”      —Tesa Silvestre


How would you like to participate?If you connect with the heart of this campaign, we invite you to listen inside to what most draws you. Where is your passion and interest? Here are some suggestions to get you started:• Join our ambassadors' circle.  To share ideas and meet others who are involved on all different levels, please join our campaign Borneo-gogo ambassadors' group on Facebook. At the most basic level, we need help getting the word out, so it would be a great help if you would forward the link to this page with a personal note to friends and colleagues who might be interested, and post it to social media. This effort began out of friendship and feeling, so it is best spread in the same way.• Inspired to do a little more? Consider writing to company managers and government officials respectfully requesting that they participate in the ceremony and reflect deeply on their own values and involvement. For a sample letter, click here. • Drawn to inquire in a fresh way? You can fully join in the spirit of what the indigenous people are trying to do by creating a related ritual, ceremony or inquiry with your group, church, friends or colleagues. For ideas to get you started, click here. • Feeling particularly moved? Why not contribute a song, poem, drawing or short video of yourself expressing from your heart why you want to help protect the forest? Or write a personal note of encouragement to the forest guardians of Muara Tae. Simply put in the comments here, and we will share. For inspiration read the story of how this campaign began with a feeling.• Have the urge to get practical? Consider learning more about the challenges facing the indigenous people of the rainforest and doing what you can to support them. The videos and organizations listed at the foot of this page will get you started.• Want to bring this closer to home? Consider learning about the challenges faced by indigenous people in your area. They are all on the front lines, trying to protect the earth from environmental degradation for the benefit of us all and could really use the support of their neighbors.• Moved to deepen your connection to the earth? Asuy suggests that you get to know your local forest intimately so you can see the richness there — the plants that grow and their uses, the animals that use it as their home. We naturally protect and serve what we know and love.“I was in a split state of incredulity where the arrogance of my smallness was saying, ‘you can do nothing’ and another part of me was saying, ‘This is killing me. I’m living a lie. I’m colluding in a system that is destroying this planet. I can’t keep doing this.’ I woke up in that moment. What I realized is that my insecurities, my inadequacies, my smallness were nothing compared to what was going on and I had a choice to live a life that was completely meaningful. And what I needed was to give myself permission to feel the truth of what was going on and if I could feel that truth, I would move into action and I would move into right action.”—Clare Dakin
The people behind this effort:
Jane Brunette teaches and writes about meditation, spirituality and creating a soulful life in challenging times. She travels widely, living simply in cultures where this is still possible so that she can have time for deep reflection as she explores the intersection between spirituality, human culture and the natural world. Author of the poetry book Grasshopper Guru, her essays can be found on The Huffington Post and on her blog at flamingseed.com. She would like to thank Tesa Silvestre for planting the seed of this effort by gifting her plane ticket to Borneo so that she could meet the people of Muara Tae, and Clare Dakin of Tree Sisters for the inspiration to act on behalf of the trees and their guardians.Ruwi - Ambrosius Ruwindrijarto - has worked on behalf of indigenous peoples for many years as an advocate as well as through business development and entrepreneurship. He cofounded Telapak, an environmental NGO based in Bogor, and is a fellow of Samdhana, an organization for social and environmental renewal. Ruwi is also a member of Forest Watch Indonesia  who strives for transparency and good governance of Indonesia's forestry. In 2010, he received the Skoll Award for Social Entrepreneurship and in 2012, the Ramon Magsaysay Award, which is considered Asia's Nobel Prize. He is committed to telling the stories of those whose voices are not being heard.Acting On Behalf of:Pesuli Lati Tana Adat Takaaq  (Caring for Indigenous Lands and Forests) is a group of families in Muara Tae dedicated to being guardians of the forest and totaling approximately 160 people. Core member families include: Asuy, Singko, Sedan, Entang, Etun, Doh, Masrani, Christian, Rawm, Ketak, Jerman, Saiman, Nyiloh, Impus, Deis, Kilo, Nok, Nawi, Endo, Matih, Juru, Saeful, Lanin, Sriansah, Dahlan, Sekam, Nggong, Mus.WE WOULD ALSO LIKE TO HONOR the efforts of the following organizations who have been doing all they can to help the people of Muara Tae: The Indigenous Peoples Alliance of the Archipelago (AMAN)Forest Watch IndonesiaEnvironmental Investigation AgencySawit WatchRainforest Action NetworkTHESE VIDEOS give more background on the people of Muara Tae and their efforts to save their forest:Our Forest Our LifeMuara Tae DiariesIceberg at Muara TaeEmpowering Muara TaeQuest for Indonesian Palm Oil Threatens Native Communities
What would love do?

story:
WE MADE IT!!

Sol Not Coal is 100% funded! (6/18)

Sending love and gratitude out to our amazing community and supporters from all over the nation! In the face of great climate change challenges, together we are creating the solutions we need for a clean energy economy.

If we reach $30K by 11:59pm tonight, we will also be able to solarize The Pueblo of Tesuque Farm Greenhouse, extending the growing season for this farm that provides free organic food to elders, herbs for ceremonial purposes, and healthy food in local markets.

THANK YOU for investing in Sol Not Coal!


COMMUNITY-SCALE SOLAR 

Visible, high-impact organizations lead the way

Building by building, we can shift away from fossil-fuel energy to clean, renewable alternatives. New Energy Economy has installed solar electric systems on the buildings of community organizations and fire stations throughout Northern New Mexico, and with your investment in our Sol not Coal campaign, we can do more! 

Solar today is cost-competitive, creates local jobs, and avoids huge amounts of water use - all with none of the environmental and health hazards of coal and other fossil fuels. For local nonprofits, farms, and public agencies, solar installation allows them to redirect funds previously spent on utility bills to the vital services they provide. Help us demonstrate the tangible economic, environmental, and health benefits of solar to communities in need, and prove that the shift to renewable energy is not only necessary but possible TODAY.

THE IMPACT

The money saved by going solar will serve thousands of New Mexicans. With your help, these powerful organizations will run on renewable energy:

TEWA WOMEN UNITED

  • TWU is a Native health/cultural revitalization organization serving pueblos in Northern New Mexico since 1989. They provide education, reproductive health services, & domestic violence prevention programming.
  • A new community center will include programming space & a community midwifery hub. Installation includes energy efficiency upgrades. 

NANCY RODRIGUEZ COMMUNITY CENTER

  • This community center provides a venue for public events on the underserved southside of Santa Fe. A beloved community gathering space, it provides a kitchen and meeting space for neighborhood meetings, community cooking classes, and public education events.

MONTE VISTA FARM

  • Monte Vista Organic Farm began in 1993, when David and Loretta Fresquez started farming at their two-and-a-half-acre residence in La Mesilla, mostly as a hobby. They now farm on three additional acres in Rio Lucio to provide healthy, local food to people throughout the region.
  • New Energy Economy feels very strongly about the importance of building a low-carbon-impact food system that provides organic food locally.

PLAN OF ACTION

Help us complete funding to:

  • Install distributed solar electric energy systems.
  • Install computer monitors that in real-time record how much solar energy is produced, how much carbon pollution emissions are offset, and how much water is saved.
  • Install educational signage at each facility that explains “How Solar Works” to further educate constituents, clients, and staff.
  • Spread the tangible benefits of decentralized solar, with local models for a global transition from a fossil fuel- dependent economy to one that is clean, renewable, and resilient. 

WHY SOLARIZE?

  • Save on utility bills and redirect these funds to community programs.
  • Reduce CARBON POLLUTION, conserve WATER, and save MONEY!
  • Create local jobs in the renewable energy industry.
  • Amplify awareness about New Mexico's potential for being a national leader in solar energy. The state is ranked second for solar potential!
  • Reduce reliance on coal-fired electricity. The Public Service Company of New Mexico (PNM) provides electricity at the San Juan coal plant, which pumps 12 million tons of CO2, 18,000 tons of nitrogen oxide, and 5,500 tons of sulfur dioxide into the atmosphere every year. It also uses 6.3 billion gallons of water annually (11,000 gallons a minute). 
  • Educate key organizations and their constituents on energy solutions.
  • Debunk the utility mantra that solar is too costly/not a viable alternative.
  • Increase outreach about climate change and leverage creative solutions.
  • Build local community resilience in the face of climate disruption.

Did you know...

  • The US solar market grew by 76% in 2012 + an additional 41% in 2013. More solar was installed in the last 18 months than the 30 years prior.
  • As of November 2013, the solar industry employs 142,698 people across 50 states, up 19.9% from the previous year.

PROVEN SUCCESS- A SOLAR MOVEMENT

So far, our solarization projects have saved our partners over $150,500. The money previously spent on coal-fired electricity is now re-purposed into community programs. We've avoided over 1 million gallons of water use associated with coal energy production and offset more than 15.42 tons of carbon pollution emissions. 

Our celebrations include:

  • 2014- Chimayo fire station and Zona del Sol. (Zona del Sol is a Santa Fe Youth & Family Center that houses educational, recreational, and social service programs on the underserved south-side of Santa Fe.) 

  • 2014- Santa Fe County fire stations. (We secured $182,000 for the solarization of all County fire stations. The legislative delegation allocated part of their capital outlay dollars to this landmark project.)

  • July 2013- Tesuque fire station. (At Santa Fe County's first solar-powered fire station, the electricity bill plummeted from more than $115 to $8.65 a month, PNM's base rate. Now, PNM sends a check every month.)

  • Fall 2012- Taytsugeh Oweengeh Intergenerational Center, Pueblo of Tesuque. (The center is home to a senior center, children's library, full basketball court, and the Tribal Council's administrative offices.)

  • 2012- Cerrillos Road fire station.  (We partnered with the City of Santa Fe to install solar at its largest station. The money saved on utility bills goes toward protective equipment for firefighters on the front lines of climate change.)

  • May 2011- Crownpoint Chapter House, Navajo Nation. (The solar power system provides 100% of the electricity for this central building. Over its lifetime, the system will save $114,115 on electric utility bills, conserve 139,900 gallons of water not used in coal plant turbines, and eliminate .5 million lbs of carbon pollution.)

OUR THANKS TO YOU!

We are deeply grateful for whatever you can give. Every $5 takes us closer to a solar movement. And, we've cooked up some awesome perks for you:

  • $10- High Five + Heartfelt Thanks
  • $25- Facebook Fabulous
  • $50- Vision Shift Poster
  • $100- Let's Party!
  • $250- Hat or Bag it
  • $500- Solar Sponsor Recognition
  • $1,000- Dream With Us
  • $2,500- Dine With Us

SPREAD THE WORD!

If you can't donate, don't worry - we appreciate your support!

  • Email this link to your friends, family, and colleagues:  indiegogo.com/projects/sol-not-coal
  • Use the "Share" tool on Indiegogo to post on your FB, Twitter, etc.

ABOUT US

New Energy Economy is a registered nonprofit organization that was established in 2004 to create economic opportunity in New Mexico with reduced carbon pollution and more clean energy. We are a small organization that has achieved landmark successes, with many more on the way. Our approach is to work in partnership with diverse allies to encourage job growth, investment, and innovation in a more efficient and sustainable energy sector. 

Visit us at www.newenergyeconomy.org  andFacebook!

story:
Did you know….

... Costa Rica uses more pesticides per capita than almost any other country?!...

… and that 96% of human sewage in Costa Rica goes into the natural waterways untreated?!...

… and, that most agriculture and illegal gold mining waste go directly into the local rivers that many communities and wildlife depend on in the Osa?!

 

I'm Rachael Eplee and I became passionate about water issues once I learned a few of these dire facts about the state of the waters in this once pristine wild area. Having moved from the US to live and work in the Osa, I am excited to be leading a program called Rios Saludables de Osa (Healthy Rivers of Osa) to promote healthy waters throughout this important area in Costa Rica.

The Osa Peninsula is known as one of “the most biologically intense places on earth” because it is home to 2.5% of the planet’s biodiversity! From the lush tropical rainforests to the pristine beaches, the Osa Peninsula houses many spectacular wildlife, including unique birds, monkeys, turtles and jaguars.  Being passionate about environmental policy and planning,  I was thrilled earlier this year to move to Costa Rica to work with Osa Conservation, an environmental nonprofit organization working to protect the Osa Peninsula.

Please help us protect one of

“the most biologically intense places on earth!”

 

 

Osa Conservation launched the Rio Saludables Program in 2014 in response to various threats facing the local rivers and streams. Our program engages students and community members in monitoring and protecting the important watersheds on which they depend on for their health and well being.  By creating a sense of ownership, we empower our neighbors to take charge of gathering information about their waters and to take action to protect these vital areas.

For the future of the biodiversity and the well-being of the local community,

please help us protect these critical watersheds!


 

 

THE ISSUE AT HAND

No one should have to worry that the water they drink, bathe in and use for washing could make them sick!

Osa’s numerous streams and rivers flow through local neighborhoods and then directly out into the open waters surrounding the peninsula.  Public health, community livelihoods, marine life, and the complex natural ecosystems are all greatly threatened by polluted water in the area.

The main sources of this water contamination include:

  • Cattle ranching and agriculture, which are economic engines in Costa Rica. Despite being a very eco-friendly country, Costa Rica uses more pesticides per capita than almost any other country! Agricultural chemicals and livestock waste pollute creeks and streams which then feed into nearby rivers and marine environments.
     
  • Human waste is a big problem, with only 4% of sewage water in Costa Rica being treated before it is released into the environment! Not only is untreated sewage in our waterways gross but it is also highly dangerous. E. coli and other dangerous bacteria contaminate the water and can make people sick.
     
  • Illegal gold mining is another harmful activity that we unfortunately see a lot in the Osa. Run-off from gold mining can disrupt the course of a river and change the water’s composition, as sometimes harmful chemicals like mercury are used.

We need YOUR HELP to monitor and protect these incredibly important river systems before it is too late!

 

TEACHING OTHERS TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE

To tackle these issues, the Rios Saludables Program has established groups of “citizen scientists,” regular community members like you and me. Participating directly in conservation, these groups are trained on how to “adopt a river” by collecting water samples which are then tested and logged into a shared online map.

Please help us grow our enthusiastic network of local water warriors! While the kids love spending time alongside their stream to monitor the water’s health, the adults enjoy conducting scientific tests and gaining a sense of ownership for protecting this crucial, life-giving resource. 

The environmental skills and values learned through this program will indeed make a huge impact for future generations!

REACHING MORE PEOPLE

We have had such a positive reaction from the local communities here in the Osa.

In fact, we have more groups wanting to get involved than we can  handle -

GREAT NEWS BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP!!

The start up costs for each group is about $500 and we have many groups waiting to start! YOUR DONATION will make a HUGE DIFFERENCE:

  • We need supplies! To set up new groups, we have to provide initial equipment and training to get them started - including a backpack full of various testing supplies, site visits and education sessions.
     
  • We need to expand education! In addition to working with groups that adopt a stream, we conduct weekly water monitoring days with local elementary students. We would love to expand this to include other area schools and reach more young people.
     
  • We need to increase hands-on involvement! The children in the Osa are the next generation of conservationists, so getting them out into nature as early as possible is key. Their participation is not only fun for them, but also crucial for the future. School visits require an investment in staff time, transportation and equipment.
     

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Click "BACK IT" on the top of the page to donate to this important cause.

Our goal is to raise $5000 to grow this network of local water warriors!

Expanding community outreach and training more citizen scientists to protect their waters are crucial. Help us mitigate the impact of the water pollution by better understanding key areas that need protection and by raising awareness about why local community members should get involved. The funds we raise will go directly to providing new testing materials, training sessions, and increased education about the importance of healthy rivers.

Every donation counts.

Do it for the wildlife; do it for the people; do it for the rivers!

Our friends and neighbors in the Osa

are counting on you! 

 

THANK YOU!
story_txt:
Did you know….
... Costa Rica uses more pesticides per capita than almost any other country?!...
… and that 96% of human sewage in Costa Rica goes into the natural waterways untreated?!...
… and, that most agriculture and illegal gold mining waste go directly into the local rivers that many communities and wildlife depend on in the Osa?!
 
I'm Rachael Eplee and I became passionate about water issues once I learned a few of these dire facts about the state of the waters in this once pristine wild area. Having moved from the US to live and work in the Osa, I am excited to be leading a program called Rios Saludables de Osa (Healthy Rivers of Osa) to promote healthy waters throughout this important area in Costa Rica.
The Osa Peninsula is known as one of “the most biologically intense places on earth” because it is home to 2.5% of the planet’s biodiversity! From the lush tropical rainforests to the pristine beaches, the Osa Peninsula houses many spectacular wildlife, including unique birds, monkeys, turtles and jaguars.  Being passionate about environmental policy and planning,  I was thrilled earlier this year to move to Costa Rica to work with Osa Conservation, an environmental nonprofit organization working to protect the Osa Peninsula.
Please help us protect one of 
“the most biologically intense places on earth!”
 

 
Osa Conservation launched the Rio Saludables Program in 2014 in response to various threats facing the local rivers and streams. Our program engages students and community members in monitoring and protecting the important watersheds on which they depend on for their health and well being.  By creating a sense of ownership, we empower our neighbors to take charge of gathering information about their waters and to take action to protect these vital areas.
For the future of the biodiversity and the well-being of the local community, 
please help us protect these critical watersheds!

 
 
THE ISSUE AT HAND
No one should have to worry that the water they drink, bathe in and use for washing could make them sick!
Osa’s numerous streams and rivers flow through local neighborhoods and then directly out into the open waters surrounding the peninsula.  Public health, community livelihoods, marine life, and the complex natural ecosystems are all greatly threatened by polluted water in the area.
The main sources of this water contamination include:


Cattle ranching and agriculture, which are economic engines in Costa Rica. Despite being a very eco-friendly country, Costa Rica uses more pesticides per capita than almost any other country! Agricultural chemicals and livestock waste pollute creeks and streams which then feed into nearby rivers and marine environments. 

Human waste is a big problem, with only 4% of sewage water in Costa Rica being treated before it is released into the environment! Not only is untreated sewage in our waterways gross but it is also highly dangerous. E. coli and other dangerous bacteria contaminate the water and can make people sick. 

Illegal gold mining is another harmful activity that we unfortunately see a lot in the Osa. Run-off from gold mining can disrupt the course of a river and change the water’s composition, as sometimes harmful chemicals like mercury are used.

We need YOUR HELP to monitor and protect these incredibly important river systems before it is too late!
 

TEACHING OTHERS TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE
To tackle these issues, the Rios Saludables Program has established groups of “citizen scientists,” regular community members like you and me. Participating directly in conservation, these groups are trained on how to “adopt a river” by collecting water samples which are then tested and logged into a shared online map.
Please help us grow our enthusiastic network of local water warriors! While the kids love spending time alongside their stream to monitor the water’s health, the adults enjoy conducting scientific tests and gaining a sense of ownership for protecting this crucial, life-giving resource. 
The environmental skills and values learned through this program will indeed make a huge impact for future generations!

REACHING MORE PEOPLE
We have had such a positive reaction from the local communities here in the Osa.
In fact, we have more groups wanting to get involved than we can  handle -
GREAT NEWS BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP!!
The start up costs for each group is about $500 and we have many groups waiting to start! YOUR DONATION will make a HUGE DIFFERENCE:


We need supplies! To set up new groups, we have to provide initial equipment and training to get them started - including a backpack full of various testing supplies, site visits and education sessions. 

We need to expand education! In addition to working with groups that adopt a stream, we conduct weekly water monitoring days with local elementary students. We would love to expand this to include other area schools and reach more young people. 

We need to increase hands-on involvement! The children in the Osa are the next generation of conservationists, so getting them out into nature as early as possible is key. Their participation is not only fun for them, but also crucial for the future. School visits require an investment in staff time, transportation and equipment. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP
Click "BACK IT" on the top of the page to donate to this important cause. 
Our goal is to raise $5000 to grow this network of local water warriors!
Expanding community outreach and training more citizen scientists to protect their waters are crucial. Help us mitigate the impact of the water pollution by better understanding key areas that need protection and by raising awareness about why local community members should get involved. The funds we raise will go directly to providing new testing materials, training sessions, and increased education about the importance of healthy rivers.
Every donation counts.
Do it for the wildlife; do it for the people; do it for the rivers!
Our friends and neighbors in the Osa
are counting on you! 
 
THANK YOU!

story:
In villages across the world, billions of hours of labor are wasted each year carrying water over long distances. Families spend their time carrying water instead of attending school, building businesses or doing other daily household chores. This valuable time lost overwhelmingly contributes to keeping many families bound to poverty. Unsafe water and lack of basic sanitation cause 80% of all sickness and disease in the world. These diseases kill more people every year than all forms of violence, including war.


We are asking friends, families and anyone passionate about this cause to give resources in order to provide fresh water for a community in need. Our goal is that mothers will have clean water to cook with and their children will have a fresh drink of water located just a few steps away from their home. These wells are built to serve a community for up to 30 years and guaranteed to directly impact thousands of lives.

Thank you for checking out our project. Know that even the smallest gift helps and that you will have a hand in improving the quality of life for someone in need.

www.VocalizeYourFaith.com

story:
Wind Empowerment Athens 2014

While everyone is talking about renewable energy, power generation from small wind turbines is not thriving. The issues that are usually raised have to do with quality, reliability, and the cost of installation. However, self-constructed wind turbine projects are one sector of wind energy that is thriving.

Self-constructed wind turbines offer a real alternative, as they enable local people to build and maintain the technology, which makes all the difference.

Today, 1.4 billion people worldwide have no access to electricity. Nowadays it is a right.

Small wind turbines offer viable and sustainable means for remote communities to manage their own local resources and lift themselves out of poverty.

Wind Empowerment is an association that is active in the development of small, self-constructed wind turbines, originally designed by Hugh Piggott, to enable rural electrification.

Wind Empowerment is composed of 37 organizations in 28 different countries. We have a diverse membership: members include manufacturers of small wind turbines, associations, NGOs, universities, social enterprises, cooperatives, test sites, and 1,146 individuals.

Wind Empowerment is a platform for the exchange of knowledge and know-how that connects all members and participants. Everyone can share their experiences on what works or not in the context in which the technology is applied, on technical advances and other information, helping to make small wind turbines a more accessible technology that is sufficiently viable to provide an answer to the problem of rural electrification.

The association was created in 2011 following a meeting of several organizations grouped around the theme of self-constructed wind turbines at the World Social Forum in Dakar, Senegal.

Since that time, its members and participants, continuously evolving, have mainly communicated through our website www.WindEmpowerment.org.

Our Executive Committee meets regularly via the Internet and we have used different means of digital communication for sharing information and documents such as webinars, virtual libraries, videos, and discussion forums.

However, this type of communication has its limits, which is why we are organizing a second conference this Autumn from November 3rd to 7th, 2014. This conference will be in the same vein as the meetings in Dakar in 2011.

The event will take place at the National Technical University of Athens, Greece, where the Rural Electrification Research Group of NTUA has provided access to lecture halls, classrooms and spaces for various workshops, as well as basic and free accommodation provided by the Nea Guinea organization.

The program for the week will include:

- presentations of research work and of each member organization's activities;

- demonstrations and experiments in wind tunnels and generator test benches;

- practical workshops, including new manufacturing techniques and data acquisition systems;

- field trips to the small wind test site of NTUA in Rafina (30 min from Athens) and of wind turbines in Marathonas (45 min from Athens);

- feedback from members on what works / does not work and why - both in terms of hardware, and also on a human level.

What is the funding for?

We seek financial assistance primarily to contribute towards the travel expenses of our members coming from all continents, especially those from developing countries who cannot join us without a subsidy. These include members from AJA Mali, Craftskills East Africa (Kenya), Energizar (Argentina), KAPEG (Nepal), Kartong project (Gambia), MinVayu (India), ÉolSénégal (Senegal), among others.

Thank you for supporting Wind Empowerment!

Read the full funding proposal: https://www.dropbox.com/s/02m1occtt5rhbt4/Wind%20Empowerment%20Athens%202014.pdf

story:
"Expanding the Worth of Our Earth"

"The Sun is a massive solar generator of limitless power and we have tried for years to harness this amazing power effectively.  If you take into consideration the inefficiency of solar panels, the power losses of electronics and the limitations of lead acid batteries it is no small wonder that solar generators and chargers are not a common site in households.  

So what makes our system so special? For starters, it is affordable, portable and it tracks the position of the Sun.  Solar collectors need to face the Sun and remain at right angles to the Sun to produce optimum power , our system does that."

Dave Weaver


My Story

My name is Dave Weaver. I am a retired Coast Guard Warrant Engineer and I like to make things, mostly yard toys for my grand-daughters. I make air cannons, roller coasters, water balloon launchers and anything that will keep them coming back on weekends. I love those girls. 

Here are a couple samples of what I have done in the past. It's not a cure for cancer but it is fun.

Water Balloon Launcher



Weed Zinger

The Weed Zinger is yet another creation of mine that has changed the way we remove pesky lawn weeds.  It is a weeding tool that shoots the weed about 6' directly into a waste bin...my grand-daughters love it. It was actually my grand-daughters idea to make a game of it. 

The neighbors think I am nuts but my grand-children think it's cool and that's good enough for me. My family makes a game out of it.

Weed Zinger in Action

 


So Why Solar?

 I have always had a fascination with solar power both active and passive.  So much so that I converted my barn into a giant passive solar absorber that is thermostatically controlled.  I constructed a polycarbonate wall with aluminum extruded frames 6" in front of the garage door but flush with the exterior. When the temperature in the void exceeds 90 degrees the garage door opens exposing a wall of black corrugated steel.  The heat is more than sufficient to heat my workspace...a propane heater takes the chill off on very cold days.

Recently,  I began to experiment with active solar and the need for portable solar generation and more specifically charging storage batteries.  My fascination turned into a passion and I would like to share my findings with anyone that has ever had the notion of harnessing the Sun's power and converting it into electrical energy.

I realize that charging a battery with a solar panel is nothing new or game changing, however, I would challenge you to find an auto-tracking charger or generator that is both affordable and portable. 

Fixed Angle Panels vs. Tracking Panels

There are a lot of portable solar generators on the market but very few of them track the Sun.  A solar panel propped up at a "fixed angle" facing due south will only generate the maximum power for about an hour of the day...if the Sun is shining.  Even a 200 watt panel at a fixed position will not produce nearly as much power as a 50 watt panel that tracks the Sun all day long. Depending on your geographical location you have only a few hours a day of sunlight to replace the power you may have consumed the day before. Cloudy days will also reduce the efficiency and the output will drop off dramatically. See illustration below.


I have always wanted to produce a solar mount that was light-weight and portable and would track the position of the Sun. My goal is to create a unit that is made with readily accessible materials that can be wheeled easily into position and be operational in moments. What I am proposing is a means of charging a typical lead acid battery with a portable charging system that tracks the Sun.  

Although this system will not produce AC power, in this present state, it can produce AC power by simply plugging in a DC to AC inverter of your choosing into the provided battery housing.  There are a number of reasons why I will not include an inverter or a battery for this system. A lead-acid battery is heavy and requires special shipping requirements and an inverter is more a matter of the consumers specific needs and power requirements. A common mistake made by consumers is to expect a single storage battery to produce enough power to run multiple appliances.  That simply is not the case.  

What Can You Run?

There are a lot of applications where this system is ideal.  A camping trip is the first thing that comes to mind. Charge it during the day and run it off the battery at night using a small inverter.  A remote workshop or job site would also be ideal. In both applications it is possible to run Ac and DC loads while the system is charging if you have an inverter. perhaps the best application for this system is with a Portable Power Generator.  Duracell and Goal Zero are a couple of small lightweight units that can be charged with this solar mount. Your system would include all of the necessary connectors to charge either unit.

This system would be ideal for camping, job sites, workshops or simply just a backup for the Zombie Apocalypse. I personally use one in front of my barn to charge individual storage batteries when they run low.  I also have a 100 watt system that I have anchored to the ground with a 20' quick connect cable to the side of the barn that charges (4) 100 AH batteries. Along side the batteries is a 3000 watt inverter. 

How it Works

The portable solar mount can be easily assembled in minutes, rolled into position and stowed very quickly. It is designed to charge a deep cycle lead acid storage battery (provided by the customer) that would fit in a molded plastic battery housing (this would be provided by me). Connecting the battery to the system powers the electronics and the linear actuator, it also starts the charging process.  




The provided battery housing includes a charge-state indicator and a quick-connect power plug.  The charged battery could then be used to power a string of DC lights or to power an inverter to produce AC power. 

The solar mount can withstand a steady wind of 10-15 knots and it is resistant to water and corrosion. This system is not limited to just charging a storage battery it can easily be used to charge any number of existing "power generators" on the market (Duracell, Goal Zero, Mr. Emergency). This provides the consumer with a means of producing immediate AC power because the inverter is "built-in" to the power pack.

The Solar Tracking System Includes:

A 50 watt solar panel on an extruded aluminum frame.  

A 7 amp charge controller mounted on the solar panel

Single Axis Auto-tracking circuit in azimuth

Manual inclination adjustment

12 vdc linear actuator

Battery case w/ built-in charge state & power socket (battery not included) 

Quick-connect cables

The purpose of this campaign is not just to sell a portable solar charger that can track the Sun it is an announcement to the world that solar can be affordable, efficient and a really neat way of harnessing the Sun' energy. This is also a gentle reminder that purchasing a "fixed angle" solar panel is not nearly as efficient as it could be.  

Universal Auto-tracking Mount

It is also worth mentioning that this system can easily be adapted to accept up to a 100 watt panel.  This means it is possible to provide auto-tracking for a system that you may have already purchased.  In short, you can improve the performance of an existing system by mounting your solar panel to this mount. Your pledge of $400 would pay for a universal mount conversion (please see perk). The physical footprint of this mount is a little bit more robust and requires more extrusion and hardware. 


What We Need & What You Get

 I have dumped several thousand dollars in research and development on electronic sensors, aluminum extrusion and linear actuators. I have selected the most cost effective components that I could find but the only way to truly reduce the cost of these units is to purchase these items in bulk.  

I am looking to raise $7500 to purchase extrusion in bulk and to procure enough of the other components to assemble 50 units.  These 50 units would be given in exchange for a full pledge of $500.  I am also offering other incentives in exchange for your pledge. 

Distribution of Funds

  • $4000 dollars would be allocated toward extrusion and hardware.
  • $2000 dollars would be applied toward electronics.
  • $1500 dollars would be for actuators and to be applied toward shipping.

The Impact

I plan on making this unit affordable for everyone.  I want to keep the retail price of this system at $500.  I am already capable of producing these units but I am essentially giving them away at this price.  I am prepared to honor all pledges even if I am unsuccessful in my attempt to procure the necessary funds.  

There is no reason that the systems I plan to produce could not be used anywhere in the world.  There are parts of the world that have very long solar days that could benefit from a communal charging station. Small power packs could be provided for homes without electricity. The limiting factor is again the battery, A typical 100 AH deep cycle battery can weigh 60-70 pounds.  For this reason I started to construct small light-weight power packs that use LiFePO4 batteries instead of lead acid.  A 20 AH LiFePO4 battery weighs only 8 pounds and it can be discharged lower than 50% of capacity unlike a lead acid battery.

Pictured below is a working prototype with an internal 1200 watt inverter. This type of battery is also safer to transport with a lower shipping cost. Imagine a bank of these on a portable trailer that are powered by a large solar panel that tracks the Sun. 


So why would anyone want to have a secondary power source that generates "Free Power" that can be converted to useable power to run vital circuits during a power outage?  Who wouldn't?


Risks & Challenges

I have never attempted to raise funds through a crowd funding source before, I have always funded my own projects and managed to sell them online.  I have been selling my canvas stretching machine for 7 years and we have them all over the world (cheap plug for the Gallery Stretcher). 

There are no risks to producing this system because I have already spent the time streamlining the design and I am able to produce them now. It is merely a matter of reducing the overall cost per item to a point where I can sell them at $500.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for viewing my project.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools they are easy to help spread the word. Please take a look at the Weed Zinger it really is a fun way to remove weeds. No bending or kneeling and the weed shoots directly into the waste bin.

Thank you for any and all help.
.

Pictured below is a working prototype with an internal 1200 watt inverter. This type of battery is also safer to transport with a lower shipping cost. Imagine a bank of these on a portable trailer that are powered by a large solar panel that tracks the Sun. 




So why would anyone want to have a secondary power source that generates "Free Power" that can be converted to useable power to run vital circuits during a power outage?  Who wouldn't?

  Risks & Challenges  I have never attempted to raise funds through a crowd funding source before, I have always funded my own projects and managed to sell them online.  I have been selling my canvas stretching machine for 7 years and we have them all over the world (cheap plug for the Gallery Stretcher). 
There are no risks to producing this system because I have already spent the time streamlining the design and I am able to produce them now. It is merely a matter of reducing the overall cost per item to a point where I can sell them at $500.
  Other Ways You Can Help 
Thank you for viewing my project.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools they are easy to help spread the word. Please take a look at the Weed Zinger it really is a fun way to remove weeds. No bending or kneeling and the weed shoots directly into the waste bin.Thank you for any and all help..

story:
Why GreenifyNation.com

GreenifyNation.com is committed to creating a grassroots fundamental shift in how we green our lives, our homes, help our friends and neighbors do the same and how we keep our world clean and safe for generations to come.

A clean legacy is up to us

Regulations and rule changes, new environmental laws, government oversight, changes to big business ... these things won't make it happen alone. It's up to us, the everyday people who go to work, take care of our homes, and shop in our own neighborhoods. We are the ones who have to put out the effort and make the changes. Using social networking and the power and reach of the internet, GreenifyNation.com brings people like you and me together. Together, we enrich each others' lives and leave behind a legacy and a rich, fertile, abundant planet for our future generations.

Hi, I'm Gia Cilento and I'm creating this new online community to bring people together who want to know how to live a cleaner, greener life. Sharing what works and what doesn't in your home and in your life.

I'm not an activist, or environmentalist. I'm just a Mom and Grandma who want's to make sure my kids and grand-kid's will still have a clean, green world to live in. I grew up enjoying blue sky's, the smell of the ocean and the feel of green grass under my feet. My family, children and grandchildren deserve at least as much, and so do yours.

GreenifyNation.com is:

  • A community for people who want to be more conscious of and responsible for the health of our homes, our neighborhoods and our planet. 
  • A place to learn new ways to clean, grow and build, free from harmful chemicals and toxins. 
  • A forum to share what works best, what recipes we use at our homes, what companies and products we like best, which companies are environmentally conscious and which aren't. 
  • A source for news and information from across the green and environmental communities.
  • A Directory of green businesses, products and more with ratings and reviews from members.

We need your support

We need at least $3000 for:

  • Website theme and customization
  • Hosting and site maintenance
  • Specialized programming for the social network and community
  • Custom artwork and videos
  • Office equipment
  • Internet and in-hand promotions

If we don't meet our goal we'll build our website out as much as possible and scale back on our initial marketing plan. We'll still get things done, just a bit slower. 

If we exceed our goal, we can expand on our marketing plan and add in the green business directory.

The story behind the story

My Mom and late Step-father, Mavis and Howard Salus, started a similar effort several years ago with ENVmagazine.org. Unfortunately, Alzheimer's put a stop to Howard's efforts and hampered Mavis' forward momentum while she poured her energy into caring for her husband. 

Since his passing several months ago, Mavis and I have re-grouped and are determined to take their original vision and move it forward into the far-reaching and powerful world of social networks.

Mavis feels an urgent call to action to get people involved in making changes in their lives! Recently, she told me, "... the Colorado river no longer reaches the sea. It has dried up!  This is all so important and you can be on the cutting edge [with GreenifyNation.com]."

Help Mavis and I keep the dream alive. 

Here's what you'll get for your support

On the right side of this page are the various levels of contribution available along with the perks we're offering for each level. 

Some of the available perks:(depending on amount of contribution)
  • Your name on our exclusive Gratitude Page, a personal phone call, or a Certificate of Gratitude
  • 1 year, 5 year, or Lifetime Platinum Membership in GreenifyNation.com 
  • GreenifyNation.com wristband, coffee cup, t-shirt, ball cap, or re-usable shopping bag. 
  • A seedling tree to planted in your honor.
  • A seedling tree chosen for your heartiness zone, shipped to you to plant anywhere you wish and keep the greening going far beyond our years.
  • Exclusive GreenifyNation.com eBook: 
    "Greenify Your Home And Your Life: Recipes, instructions and suggestions for make-it-yourself cleaning and grooming products."
  • A GreenifyNation.com customized photo book highlighting the beauty and splendor of our natural surroundings.

Spread the word!

Remember, everyone can help, whether you contribute or not. 

Let's rock the boat! Take some action and share our campaign. Under the video at the top there are buttons you can use to share with your friends. Use them, spread the word. Share with your friends, your family, your co-workers, your church groups, your social networks, everyone and anyone you think would be interested in helping to create a better future for ourselves and our families.

See you at the Nation!
